Incident_Report:
Incident Report
Case Number: 25-147210
Date/Time of Incident: April 6, 2025, approximately 01:55 AM
Location: Rear parking lot, 1190 N. Cedar Ave., City of Foxridge
Reporting Officer(s): P.O. Patel (#5123), P.O. Nguyen (#4419)

On April 6, 2025, at approximately 02:06 hours, Officers Patel and Nguyen responded to a reported sexual assault at the rear parking lot of 1190 N. Cedar Avenue in the City of Foxridge. The weather was noted as light rain with a temperature of 47°F. Upon arrival, officers observed a female adult, later identified as Ari [last name withheld], seated on the curb near a gray four-door sedan with the rear passenger door slightly ajar. Ari was wrapped in a blanket provided by her friend, Kira [last name withheld], who was standing nearby.

Officers identified themselves and confirmed consent to record the interaction on body-worn cameras. Ari stated that she was assaulted by a coworker named Luis [first name only], whom she last saw departing the lot in a dark SUV at approximately 01:55. Ari reported that Luis forcibly placed her in the backseat of the gray sedan against her will despite her repeated verbal refusals, including saying “Stop” and “No.” She described an attempt to push him away and stated that he held her wrists during the incident. Ari reported soreness in her inner thighs but exhibited no visible external injuries on her face or forearms. She was alert and oriented.

Kira confirmed she received a distressing phone call from Ari at 01:58 and subsequently called 911 at 02:01. Ari recounted that they had left a bar around 01:35, and Luis offered to walk her to her car. Upon arrival at the parking lot, Luis asked to sit in the vehicle, then opened the rear door and nudged Ari inside despite her objections. Ari described Luis as a Hispanic male, mid-30s, approximately 5’10” with a medium build, wearing a navy jacket, jeans, and a black cap.

Officers requested Emergency Medical Services (EMS) for a medical evaluation and Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) exam. Ari consented to visual documentation of the vehicle’s interior prior to EMS arrival. Photographs were taken of the rear passenger door, back seat area, floorboard, and a condom wrapper found near the rear passenger footwell. The back seat fabric was torn approximately four inches at the center seam, and tissue was observed on the floorboard. The vehicle’s license plate was partially obscured by mud, and a temporary paper permit was visible inside the rear window; records later confirmed the permit was tied to dealership inventory and not registered to Ari.

Officers canvassed the area and identified a laundromat to the east with a CCTV dome camera facing the shared alley. The night attendant agreed to contact the manager to request footage covering 01:30 to 02:10 hours.

Upon EMS arrival, the lead paramedic introduced herself as Renee and explained medical and forensic options. Ari elected to proceed with the SANE exam and consented to the release of the sexual assault kit to law enforcement following the exam. Officers transported Ari and Kira to Foxridge General Hospital’s SART unit, where the sexual assault kit and clothing items (black leggings, gray hoodie, and underwear) were collected, sealed, and logged into evidence by Officer Nguyen.

An advocate met with Ari at the hospital to provide support and resources. Officers remained outside the exam room during the medical evaluation and cleared the hospital at 03:03 hours.

Summary:
- Victim: Ari [last name withheld], adult female
- Suspect: Luis [first name only], coworker, described as Hispanic male, mid-30s, 5’10”, medium build, navy jacket, jeans, black cap
- Incident: Sexual assault involving forcible placement in vehicle backseat, physical restraint, and non-consensual contact
- Evidence: Photographs of vehicle interior, condom wrapper, torn seat fabric, tissue; sexual assault kit and clothing collected at hospital
- Witness: Kira [last name withheld], friend and 911 caller
- Follow-up: CCTV footage request initiated; victim provided with advocate and medical forensic examination; evidence secured and logged

This report will be forwarded to the detective bureau for further investigation. All evidence is secured under chain of custody. The victim has been provided with resources and support services.

Prepared by:
P.O. Patel (#5123)
Date: April 6, 2025

Incident_Report:
Incident Report

Case Number: 25-149002  
Date of Incident: April 9, 2025  
Reporting Officer: Sgt. R. Salazar (#2081)  
Secondary Officer: P.O. Keane (#3775)  
Location: 601 E. Brookside, Unit 12  
Weather: Overcast, 56°F  
Time on Scene: 19:36:10 – 20:28:50  

On April 9, 2025, at approximately 19:36 hours, Sgt. R. Salazar and P.O. Keane responded to a sexual assault report at 601 E. Brookside, Unit 12. Upon arrival, officers knocked on the door and were invited inside by a female voice. The victim, identified as Elena [last name withheld], was seated at the dining table with a blanket draped over her shoulders. Elena appeared physically unharmed with no visible external injuries to her face or forearms but reported soreness in her hips and lower back.

Elena stated that the assault occurred earlier that day between 14:00 and 14:20 hours. She described waking up to find the suspect, identified as Tyler, a friend of her roommate Marissa, on top of her. Elena reported that she repeatedly said “No, stop,” pushed at him, and that he covered her mouth with his hand for several seconds. She emphasized that she did not consent to any sexual contact. Elena’s roommate Marissa was present and confirmed Tyler had left the apartment around 14:30 hours. Marissa provided Tyler’s physical description: a white male, approximately 23 years old, 5’11” tall, medium build, brown hair, and a small triangle tattoo on his wrist. She also offered Tyler’s Instagram profile and phone number for investigative purposes.

Officers conducted a consensual search of the apartment. The bedroom showed signs consistent with Elena’s account: the queen bed’s duvet was pulled halfway off, the fitted sheet was rumpled, and a pillow was found on the floor next to the east side nightstand. In the bathroom, cotton swabs and tissues with apparent blood were observed in the sink area. Elena consented to photographs of these items, which were taken by officers; however, collection was deferred to the Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) team. Elena confirmed she had not showered since the incident and had changed her shirt, which was located in the laundry basket.

A canvass of the hallway was conducted. Neighbor Daria from Unit 11 reported hearing a muffled voice around 14:10 hours but could not discern any words. Her contact information was obtained for follow-up. Officers requested building management to preserve any available surveillance footage. Management confirmed cameras were only located in the lobby, and footage from 13:30 to 15:00 hours and 18:30 to 19:30 hours was requested and preserved.

EMS was called to the scene at 19:37 hours, and Elena agreed to be transported to Memorial Medical Center for evaluation and forensic examination by the SANE team. An advocate was also requested to assist the victim. At the hospital, officers received Sexual Assault Kit #MMC-25-0409-142 and clothing evidence, including sweatpants and the original shirt, which was retrieved from the laundry in a sealed bag via EMS chain of custody. Officer Keane formally received the evidence at 20:18 hours.

Sgt. Salazar promptly emailed the Detective Unit with suspect identifiers and social media information to aid in the investigation. The officers cleared the hospital at 20:28 hours.

Victim rights pamphlets and instructions on evidence preservation were provided to Elena. The investigation remains ongoing, with efforts focused on identifying and locating the suspect Tyler, reviewing lobby surveillance footage, and processing collected evidence.

End of Report.

Incident_Report:
Incident Report

Case Number: 25-151118  
Date/Time of Incident: April 12, 2025, approximately 10:40 p.m.  
Date/Time Reported: April 12, 2025, 23:09  
Location: 410 S. Pine St., Unit 7  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Martinez (#4217)  
Secondary Officer: P.O. Chin (#3364)  
Weather Conditions: Clear, 61°F  

Narrative:

On April 12, 2025, at approximately 23:09 hours, I, Officer Martinez (#4217), along with Officer Chin (#3364), responded to a call regarding a sexual assault report at 410 S. Pine St., Unit 7. Upon arrival, we proceeded to the third-floor exterior corridor and knocked on the door marked “7.” A female voice responded, “It’s open,” and we entered with consent.

Inside, we found the victim, later identified as Nadia [last name withheld], seated on the floor near a coffee table, wrapped in a hoodie. She provided her date of birth and contact information. Nadia reported that the assault occurred around 10:40 p.m. earlier that evening in her bedroom.

Nadia stated that the suspect was a co-worker named Sean [last name withheld], from the marketing team. She described the incident as follows: Sean came over to drop off her laptop charger, and they had been drinking wine in the kitchen. Sean attempted to kiss her, which she declined. Despite her refusal, he followed her to the bedroom, pushed her onto the bed, and continued his advances. Nadia repeatedly told him “Stop” and stated, “I did not consent.” She also reported telling Sean to stop, to which he responded, “Don’t make this a thing.”

Upon examination, I observed redness approximately 1 cm in diameter on the inner right wrist of the victim. No other visible injuries were noted on her face or hands. With her consent, photographs of the injury were taken. The bedroom showed signs of disturbance consistent with the victim’s account: the bedroom door was open, the bed sheet was rumpled, and a lamp was knocked over but the bulb remained intact.

Neighbor Tina from Unit 9 reported hearing a loud thud around 22:45 but did not observe anyone leaving the unit. Nadia confirmed she had not showered or changed clothes since the incident. She was wearing a black dress and a cardigan, both of which were documented but not collected at the scene pending the Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination.

EMS and SANE services were requested and arrived promptly. Nadia consented to a sexual assault examination and agreed to release the collected evidence kit to law enforcement. The sexual assault kit (FGH-25-0412-224) and clothing bags containing the dress and cardigan were received and secured by me at 23:36 hours, maintaining proper chain of custody.

I requested preservation of building lobby surveillance footage from 21:30 to 23:30 via an emailed notice, which was confirmed by management under ticket #PM-88214.

Nadia was transported by EMS to Foxridge General SART for further medical evaluation and evidence collection. I provided Nadia with a case card and explained the investigative process and her rights.

Officers cleared the hospital at 23:58 hours.

End of report.  
Officer Martinez (#4217)

Incident_Report:
Incident Report

Case Number: 25-152771  
Date of Report: April 14, 2025  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Doyle (#3198)  
Secondary Officer: P.O. Kravitz (#2902)  
Location: Campus Quad near Library Steps; Dorm A, Room 214  
Weather Conditions: Windy, 52°F  
Time on Scene: 16:43:58 – 18:01:40

Narrative:

On April 14, 2025, at approximately 16:43 hours, I, P.O. Doyle, along with P.O. Kravitz, responded to a sexual assault report at the Campus Quad near the Library Steps. Upon arrival, we located the victim, identified as Jada [last name withheld], seated on a bench accompanied by her friend, Kellie. After obtaining Jada’s consent to record the interview, she reported that a classmate had assaulted her in her dormitory room the previous night.

Jada stated the incident occurred between approximately 01:30 and 01:50 hours. She described that after studying together in the lounge, the suspect, identified only by his first name, Marcus, who is a classmate from her chemistry class, walked her back to her dorm. Marcus requested to enter her room, to which she consented for a brief period. Jada recounted that Marcus kissed her, which she rejected by pulling away and verbally expressing her lack of consent. Inside the room, Marcus allegedly pushed her onto the bed despite her repeated verbal refusals, including saying “No, stop,” and attempting to push him away. At one point, Marcus covered her mouth briefly when she protested.

A physical examination of Jada revealed a small linear redness approximately 0.5 cm in length on her left cheek near the hairline. With her consent, photographs of the injury were taken. Jada confirmed she had not showered since the incident but had changed her T-shirt at 09:00 hours on the day of the report. The original T-shirt was located in her hamper and was collected later by the Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) team for evidentiary purposes.

We proceeded with Jada’s consent to Dorm A, Room 214, for scene documentation. Observations included rumpled bed linens and a tipped desk chair; no damage to property was noted. Jada provided a physical description of the suspect as a tall male, approximately 6’1”, wearing a black hoodie and gray joggers.

Dorm Resident Assistant Devon reported seeing a tall male exit the hallway near Room 214 at approximately 01:55 hours but could not identify the individual. I contacted campus security to request video footage from hallway cameras covering the time frame of 01:00 to 02:30 hours to assist in identifying the suspect.

Emergency Medical Services (EMS) were requested and arrived on scene. Jada consented to a SANE examination and was subsequently transported by EMS to University Hospital SART at 16:47 hours. At the hospital, evidence was collected, including Sexual Assault Kit #UH-25-0414-302, Clothing Bag A containing shorts, and Clothing Bag B containing the original T-shirt, which was sealed by the SANE nurse. Officer Kravitz received the evidence at 17:13 hours, maintaining the chain of custody.

I emailed the campus police investigations unit with the suspect’s information and the camera footage request. A campus advocacy center representative was contacted and arrived at the hospital at approximately 17:45 hours to provide support to the victim.

At 18:01 hours, after completing all necessary procedures and ensuring the victim was in appropriate care, P.O. Kravitz and I cleared the hospital.

This report is submitted for further investigation and follow-up by the campus police department and university authorities.

Respectfully submitted,  
P.O. Doyle (#3198)

Incident_Report:
Incident Report

Case Number: 25-154388
Date/Time of Report: April 16, 2025, 22:10
Reporting Officer: P.O. Gomez (#2740)
Secondary Officer: P.O. Li (#2631)
Location of Incident: Parking Structure, Level 2, Bay D-12

Narrative:

On April 16, 2025, at approximately 21:12 hours, Officers Gomez and Li responded to a report of a sexual assault at the Level 2 parking structure, Bay D-12. Upon arrival, officers located the victim, identified as Miriam [last name withheld], standing near a silver hatchback vehicle accompanied by her friend, Noor.

Officer Gomez initiated contact and obtained consent to record the interview. Miriam reported that she was sexually assaulted by her ex-boyfriend, identified as Daniel, in the back seat of a vehicle approximately one hour prior to our arrival, placing the incident between 20:10 and 20:20 hours. She stated that she repeatedly said “Please stop” and attempted to move away during the assault. Miriam appeared alert and coherent, with no visible injuries, but reported experiencing nausea and headache.

Miriam identified the suspect as Daniel, who was last seen leaving the parking structure in a blue sedan around 20:25 hours. She did not consent to the sexual contact. Noor corroborated the timeline, stating that Miriam called her immediately after Daniel left and asked her to come to the scene.

Officers conducted a preliminary examination of the vehicle’s interior with Miriam’s consent. Items observed included a jacket, tissue, hair tie, and a twisted seatbelt in the back seat. A condom wrapper was found on the floor behind the driver’s seat. Photographs of the vehicle’s interior were taken; however, no evidence was collected at the scene.

Officer Gomez canvassed the area for surveillance cameras and identified CCTV coverage at the parking structure’s entry and exit points. Contact was made with security guard Alan, who confirmed the presence of cameras and agreed to preserve footage from 19:45 to 20:45 hours. A formal request for this footage was submitted.

Miriam consented to a hospital evaluation and a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) exam. EMS was requested and arrived promptly at 21:15 hours. Miriam was transported to Foxridge General Hospital’s Sexual Assault Response Team (SART) unit for further medical evaluation and evidence collection. She had not changed clothing or showered since the incident; her jeans and sweatshirt were documented and collected as evidence, along with underwear, all sealed in evidence bags.

At 21:41 hours, Officer Gomez received the Sexual Assault Kit (#FGH-25-0416-411) and clothing evidence, maintaining chain of custody. Officer Li emailed the Investigations Unit with suspect information and requested the parking garage surveillance footage.

The officers cleared the hospital at 22:06 hours, concluding their involvement at the scene.

All procedures were conducted in accordance with department protocols for sexual assault investigations. The case remains open pending review of forensic evidence and surveillance footage.

End of Report.

I said no.” 03:25:12 — Observation: bed linens disturbed; pillow on floor; bedside lamp upright. No visible injuries on Lena’s face/hands; reports wrist pain. 03:25:26 — Suspect: “Evan,” acquaintance from social gathering at same house earlier. 03:25:36 — Time reported: “Around 2:55 a.m.” 03:25:42 — Yates requests EMS; Lena consents to SANE. 03:25:50 — Direct quotes documented: “I said ‘No, stop’,” “He held my wrists,” “I did not consent.” 03:26:01 — Brower photographs room with consent; no evidence collected pending SANE. 03:26:12 — Housemate “Mitch” states he saw a male run out the back door at approx. 03:05. 03:26:25 — Yates requests exterior camera footage from neighbor’s porch cam; neighbor agrees to share between 02:30–03:15. 03:26:41 — Lena: “I haven’t changed clothes.” Clothing documented: T-shirt, shorts. 03:26:52 — EMS arrival. End of transcript.
Incident_Report:
Incident Report

Case Number: 25-155902  
Date/Time of Incident: April 18, 2025, approximately 2:55 a.m.  
Location: 118 Baxter Avenue, Rear Bedroom  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Yates (#3504)  
Secondary Officer: P.O. Brower (#3512)  
Weather Conditions: Drizzle, 45°F  

Narrative:

On April 18, 2025, at approximately 3:24 a.m., Officers Yates and Brower responded to a call regarding a reported sexual assault at 118 Baxter Avenue. Upon arrival at 3:24:50 a.m., officers approached the rear entry of the single-family residence. Entry was made with the consent of the resident, identified as Lena [last name withheld], who led officers to the rear bedroom where the incident reportedly occurred.

Lena stated that the suspect, identified as “Evan,” an acquaintance from a social gathering held earlier at the same residence, pushed her onto the bed against her will. She reported verbally refusing his advances, stating “I said no,” and “I said ‘No, stop’.” Lena further described that the suspect held her wrists during the assault and emphasized that she did not consent to any sexual contact. The time of the assault was estimated by Lena to be around 2:55 a.m.

Upon visual inspection of the bedroom, officers noted disturbed bed linens and a pillow lying on the floor. The bedside lamp remained upright. No visible injuries were observed on Lena’s face or hands; however, she reported experiencing pain in her wrists consistent with being held forcibly. Lena was wearing a T-shirt and shorts and confirmed she had not changed clothes since the incident.

Officer Brower photographed the bedroom scene with Lena’s consent. No physical evidence was collected at the scene pending a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination. EMS was requested and arrived promptly at 3:26:52 a.m. Lena consented to a SANE examination and was transported to Memorial SART for forensic medical evaluation at 3:27:09 a.m.

A housemate named Mitch provided a statement indicating he observed a male individual running out the back door of the residence at approximately 3:05 a.m., shortly after the alleged assault. Officers requested and obtained consent from a neighbor to access exterior porch camera footage covering the time frame from 2:30 a.m. to 3:15 a.m. The neighbor agreed to share the footage, which was subsequently requested to be digitally transferred to the Evidence Unit inbox.

At 3:54 a.m., the Sexual Assault Kit (S.A.K.) #MMC-25-0418-059 was received along with two clothing bags containing Lena’s T-shirt and shorts. Officer Brower took custody of the evidence, maintaining the chain of custody. Contact information for the neighbor providing video footage was collected by Officer Yates.

An advocate was requested to provide support to Lena during the process. Officers cleared the scene at 4:18 a.m.

All procedures were conducted in accordance with department protocols for sexual assault investigations. The case remains open pending review of forensic evidence and video footage.

End of Report.  
Officer Yates (#3504)  
April 18, 2025

Transcript: [BWC — Primary: P.O. Reyes (#2147); Secondary: P.O. Malik (#3052). Call Type: Sexual Assault Report. CAD#: 25-240011. Date: 2025-09-04. Weather: Clear, 74°F. Location: 118 Harbor View — Apartment 3C Living Room. Time on scene: 21:07:13–22:01:55.] 21:07:13 — Video activates at hallway; officers announce presence. 21:07:26 — Contact: Resident “Ava” opens door, steps back to give space. Voice calm but shaky. 21:07:35 — Reyes: “My name is Officer Reyes. This is Officer Malik. We can talk wherever you feel most comfortable. Do you want water, a seat, or a blanket?” 21:07:52 — Ava nods to couch; blanket visible. 21:08:02 — Consent for recording: “I’m recording to document our conversation. If you need a break at any time, say so.” Ava: “Okay.” 21:08:20 — Scene scan: coffee table with two cups, phone, tissues; bedroom door closed. 21:08:37 — Open prompt: “Tell me what you’re able to share, in your own words, starting wherever makes sense.” 21:08:58 — Ava: “He’s a coworker. He came over to drop off a charger. We talked, then he… I told him to stop.” Tears. 21:09:26 — Reyes offers pause and tissues; normalizes reactions: “It’s common to feel shaken. You’re in control of this conversation.” 21:09:51 — Clarification: “What words or actions did you use when you wanted it to stop?” Ava: “I said ‘no, this isn’t okay’ and tried to push his hand.” 21:10:18 — Documentation: Notes exact phrasing and gestures. 21:10:34 — Malik photographs in situ after verbal consent: living room, hallway, bedroom threshold; preserves angles, includes scale and overviews, mid-range, close-ups. 21:11:02 — Evidence options explained: “A Sexual Assault Forensic Exam is available. It’s free, you can have an advocate, and you can do it now or within several days. It doesn’t obligate you to press charges.” Ava: “I want that.” 21:11:34 — Reyes requests medical dispatch for SANE availability; logs time. 21:11:49 — Open questions: “What happened from when he arrived to when he left?” Ava gives timeline: arrival 19:30, tea, discussion about project, kiss she did not initiate, said “no,” he persisted with hand under waistband, she moved away, he blocked path; she said “I need you to leave,” he left at 20:20 after grabbing charger. 21:13:42 — Reflective summary: “You described saying ‘no,’ moving away, and asking him to leave, and he blocked your path before leaving at about 8:20.” Ava: “Yes.” 21:14:08 — Sensory/memory cues: “Anything you recall about sounds, smells, or statements you want documented?” Ava: “He said, ‘Don’t make it weird.’ He wore a blue hoodie.” 21:14:44 — Preservation: Advises not to bathe or change clothes if comfortable until exam; offers paper bags for clothing if changed. Ava still wearing same jeans and top. Paper sheet provided for seating. 21:15:32 — Consent to collect digital evidence: Ava agrees to email screenshots of texts from suspect after leaving (“sorry if I pushed”). Officers photograph screen with time/date and capture contact label. 21:16:27 — Witnesses: Neighbor “Liam” may have seen him leave. Reyes asks if Ava wants contact now or later; she prefers later. 21:16:58 — Scene canvass: Malik knocks on 3B; no answer; leaves card. 21:17:21 — Documentation of demeanor: “Ava intermittently tearful, coherent, oriented; no visible external injuries; complains of hip soreness.” Offers EMS; Ava declines transport, requests exam at SANE site. 21:18:36 — Safety planning: “Is he expected at your workplace tomorrow? Do you want a protective order referral?” Ava asks for advocate. Reyes calls advocacy hotline on speaker with Ava’s permission; connects. 21:20:04 — Suspect info: Name, description, vehicle plate partially known. Reyes notes to request building CCTV from 19:15–20:45; contacts property manager via after-hours line; email request sent on camera, time-stamped. 21:21:48 — Chain of custody prepped: Evidence envelopes labeled but not sealed on camera; will be sealed at station if clothing provided after exam. 21:22:19 — Miranda not applicable; no suspect present. 21:22:33 — Clarifying contradictions avoided; focus remains on Ava’s account; no leading. 21:25:10 — Ava requests break; officers stop questions, remain present. 21:29:42 — Resume with consent. “What do you want to happen next?” Ava: “The exam and I’ll decide about charges after.” 21:30:21 — Transport arranged to SANE facility with advocate meeting there. Officers explain she can do a blind kit if undecided about reporting. 21:32:04 — Closing summary read back: time of arrival/departure, statements, physical interactions, requests for leave, suspect clothing, messages. Ava confirms accuracy. 21:34:12 — Officers provide case number, contact card, victim rights sheet, and resource list. 21:36:09 — Malik secures scene; final photos. 21:38:25 — Reyes logs evidence requests: building CCTV pull, phone extraction warrant if needed (only with consent or warrant), interview request for suspect at later date in controlled setting. 21:41:50 — Ava opts to stay with friend; officers arrange friend pickup. 21:50:33 — Departure; report notes trauma-informed approach, evidence preservation steps, and pending items. 22:01:55 — End of BWC.
Incident_Report:
Incident Report

Case Number: 25-240011  
Date: September 4, 2025  
Location: 118 Harbor View, Apartment 3C  
Reporting Officers: P.O. Reyes (#2147), P.O. Malik (#3052)  
Call Type: Sexual Assault Report  
Weather: Clear, 74°F  
Time on Scene: 21:07:13 – 22:01:55

Narrative:

On September 4, 2025, at approximately 21:07 hours, Officers Reyes and Malik responded to a sexual assault report at 118 Harbor View, Apartment 3C. Upon arrival, officers announced their presence and were met by the resident, identified as Ava, who opened the door and stepped back to allow entry. Ava appeared calm but exhibited signs of distress, including a shaky voice and intermittent tearfulness.

Officers offered Ava water, seating, and a blanket, to which she nodded and chose the couch with a blanket provided. Consent to record the interview was obtained, and officers explained the purpose of the recording and the option to pause at any time. The living room was observed to contain a coffee table with two cups, a phone, tissues, and a closed bedroom door.

Ava began her account by stating that the suspect was a coworker who came to her apartment to drop off a charger. She described that after some initial conversation, the suspect initiated unwanted physical contact. Ava stated, “I told him to stop,” and became tearful. When asked to clarify, Ava reported saying “no, this isn’t okay” and attempting to push the suspect’s hand away. Officers documented her exact phrasing and gestures.

Officer Malik photographed the scene with Ava’s verbal consent, capturing the living room, hallway, and bedroom threshold from multiple angles to preserve the environment. Officers informed Ava about the availability of a Sexual Assault Forensic Exam (SAFE), emphasizing that it was free, could include an advocate, and did not obligate her to press charges. Ava expressed her desire to proceed with the exam.

Ava provided a detailed timeline: the suspect arrived at approximately 19:30, they shared tea and discussed a work project. The suspect then kissed Ava without her initiation. She said “no,” but he persisted by placing his hand under her waistband. Ava moved away, and when she asked him to leave, he blocked her path. He eventually left at approximately 20:20, taking the charger with him. Ava recalled the suspect wearing a blue hoodie and saying, “Don’t make it weird.”

Officers advised Ava not to bathe or change clothes to preserve evidence and offered paper bags should she need to change. Ava was still wearing the same clothing. She consented to provide digital evidence by emailing screenshots of texts from the suspect, including an apology message stating, “sorry if I pushed.” Officers photographed the phone screen to document this evidence.

Ava identified a neighbor, Liam, who might have witnessed the suspect’s departure. Officers attempted contact with Liam at Apartment 3B but received no response and left a contact card. Ava was intermittently tearful but coherent and oriented. She reported soreness in her hip but declined EMS transport, opting instead for the SAFE at a medical facility.

Safety planning was discussed, including the suspect’s potential presence at Ava’s workplace the following day and the option for a protective order. Ava requested an advocate, and Officer Reyes connected her to the advocacy hotline with her permission.

Suspect information, including partial vehicle plate and description, was noted. Officers requested building CCTV footage from 19:15 to 20:45 and contacted the property manager via after-hours line, following up with an email request. Chain of custody procedures were initiated for evidence envelopes, which were labeled but not sealed on camera; sealing would occur at the station if clothing was provided after the exam.

No Miranda warnings were necessary as the suspect was not present. Officers maintained a trauma-informed approach, avoiding leading questions and focusing on Ava’s account. After a brief break at Ava’s request, questioning resumed with her consent. Ava expressed her intention to undergo the exam and decide on pressing charges afterward.

Transport to the SAFE facility was arranged, with an advocate scheduled to meet Ava there. Officers explained the option of a blind kit if she was undecided about reporting. A closing summary of Ava’s statements and timeline was read back and confirmed for accuracy.

Officers provided Ava with the case number, contact card, victim rights sheet, and a list of resources. Officer Malik secured the scene with final photographs. Evidence requests for building CCTV and potential phone extraction were logged, pending consent or warrant. An interview request for the suspect was noted for a later controlled setting.

Ava chose to stay with a friend, and officers arranged for the friend’s pickup. The officers departed the scene at approximately 21:50 hours. The report reflects a trauma-informed response, thorough evidence preservation, and pending investigative actions.

End of Report.  
Officer Reyes (#2147)  
Officer Malik (#3052)

Transcript: [BWC — Primary: Sgt. Patel (#1876); Secondary: P.O. Ortega (#2688). Call Type: Sexual Assault Report. CAD#: 25-240029. Date: 2025-09-05. Weather: Light rain, 66°F. Location: Riverfront Park Pavilion. Time on scene: 06:42:11–07:38:20.] 06:42:11 — Camera activates as officers approach covered picnic tables. 06:42:24 — Complainant “Mina,” wrapped in foil blanket provided by bystander EMT, is seated with friend “Jess.” 06:42:38 — Introductions and options: “We can move to the cruiser for warmth or stay here—your choice.” Mina chooses cruiser. 06:43:12 — Consent to record; acknowledgment of right to pause. 06:43:40 — Grounding: Sgt. Patel offers paced breathing; affirms: “You’re not in trouble. You get to decide what to share.” 06:44:05 — Free narrative: Mina: “I met him near the food trucks after the concert. We walked toward the path. He kissed me. I said I didn’t want more. He kept trying.” 06:44:56 — Clarifying without judgment: “What words did you use? What did he say?” Mina: “I said ‘no’ twice and ‘I want to go back.’ He said ‘just a minute.’” 06:45:41 — Physical description captured; clothing; approximate height; baseball cap with team logo. 06:46:10 — Timeline scaffold: “From leaving the trucks to returning here, what stands out?” Mina notes location under pedestrian bridge, 22:15–22:30 window; described pushing his hands away; he squeezed her wrist. 06:47:32 — Injury check; Mina reports wrist soreness and a scrape on knee from stepping off curb. Officers photograph with consent; scale ruler and color card used. 06:48:29 — Evidence preservation: Advises on SANE exam; explains benefits and limits; offers advocate and transport. Mina consents to exam. 06:49:14 — Scene considerations: Rain may affect trace; officers note to canvass early. 06:49:38 — Witness identification: Jess saw Mina return upset at 22:40; brief statement captured; full interview deferred. 06:50:22 — CCTV prospects: City cameras at Riverfront Gate and food truck line; Patel radios dispatch to flag relevant feeds for retention request; logs times. 06:51:15 — Open prompt for sensory details: “Any words he used you remember?” Mina: “He said, ‘You’re so tense, relax.’” 06:51:52 — Map sketch: Sgt. draws quick map; Mina marks route; sketch photographed. 06:52:33 — Suspect contact post-incident: none reported. 06:52:49 — Transport plan: EMS checks vitals; Mina declines hospital transport but accepts SANE at affiliated clinic; advocate en route. 06:53:36 — Non-evidentiary support: Safety planning around rides home, sharing location with friend, and how to report if suspect reappears. 06:54:24 — Language access not needed; English primary. 06:54:41 — Search considerations: No immediate suspect; no detentions or stops conducted without description match and legal basis. 06:55:19 — Officers return to pavilion to begin area canvas. 06:56:07 — Canvas: Food truck vendors recall a man in navy windbreaker; one vendor points to private camera on truck; owner agrees to share copy; contact info collected; consent form signed on camera. 06:58:43 — Environmental notes: Rain runoff near path; mud prints photographed with and without scale; not seized yet pending CSI. 07:00:11 — Mina requests break; questioning pauses; camera records ambient audio only, no probing. 07:06:22 — Resume with consent. “Is there anything you’re worried we’ll misunderstand?” Mina: “That I talked to him first. But I said no.” Patel affirms: “Your choices earlier don’t negate consent.” 07:07:18 — Documentation emphasizes Mina’s verbal refusals and physical resistance, sequence, and suspect statements. 07:09:05 — Victim rights sheet reviewed; case number provided; instructions for records. 07:10:34 — Transport to clinic coordinated; advocate meets at entrance; friend rides separately. 07:12:58 — Officers secure potential evidence until CSI arrives; yellow barrier tape placed with Parks approval. 07:18:46 — Dispatch advises city camera retention initiated. 07:26:19 — Quick debrief between officers: ensure no leading language in report; quote verbatim statements. 07:34:55 — Officers clear after Mina departs safely. 07:38:20 — End.
Incident_Report:
Incident Report

Case Number: 25-240029  
Date: September 5, 2025  
Location: Riverfront Park Pavilion  
Reporting Officer: Sgt. Patel (#1876)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Ortega (#2688)  
Weather Conditions: Light rain, 66°F  
Time on Scene: 06:42:11 – 07:38:20

Narrative:

On September 5, 2025, at approximately 06:42 hours, Sgt. Patel and P.O. Ortega responded to a call regarding a reported sexual assault at Riverfront Park Pavilion. Upon arrival, officers located the complainant, identified as Mina, seated under a covered picnic table alongside her friend, Jess. Mina was wrapped in a foil blanket provided by a bystander EMT. Officers introduced themselves and offered Mina the option to move to the patrol cruiser for warmth; she elected to do so.

After obtaining Mina’s consent to record the interview and informing her of her rights, Sgt. Patel initiated a grounding technique involving paced breathing and reassured Mina that she was not in trouble and had control over what she chose to share. Mina provided a free narrative account, stating that she met the suspect near the food trucks following a concert. They walked toward a path where the suspect kissed her. Mina stated she expressed refusal by saying “no” twice and “I want to go back,” but the suspect persisted, responding with “just a minute.”

Mina described the suspect as wearing a baseball cap with a team logo, approximately [height not specified in transcript], and provided details on his clothing. She recalled the incident occurring between 22:15 and 22:30 under the pedestrian bridge. Mina reported physically pushing the suspect’s hands away and that he squeezed her wrist. She noted soreness in her wrist and a scrape on her knee, which officers photographed using a scale ruler and color card for documentation.

Officers advised Mina on the benefits and limitations of a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) exam and offered transportation and advocacy services. Mina consented to the exam and declined hospital transport but agreed to be taken to an affiliated clinic where an advocate was en route. EMS personnel checked her vital signs on scene.

Jess, the witness, reported seeing Mina return visibly upset at approximately 22:40. A brief statement was recorded, with a full interview deferred for later. Officers identified potential CCTV footage from city cameras located at the Riverfront Gate and near the food truck line. Sgt. Patel coordinated with dispatch to flag and retain relevant footage.

A quick sketch map of the route Mina and the suspect took was drawn and photographed. Mina confirmed no contact with the suspect post-incident. Officers conducted an area canvas, during which food truck vendors recalled seeing a man in a navy windbreaker. One vendor pointed to a private camera on their truck; the owner consented to share the footage and signed a consent form.

Environmental conditions, including rain runoff near the path and mud prints, were documented and photographed with scale but not seized pending Crime Scene Investigation (CSI) arrival. Officers placed yellow barrier tape around the pavilion area with Parks Department approval to preserve the scene.

Mina requested a break during questioning, which was honored with the camera recording ambient audio only. Upon resuming, Mina expressed concern that her initial interaction with the suspect might be misunderstood; Sgt. Patel reassured her that her verbal refusals and physical resistance were valid and emphasized in documentation.

Victim rights were reviewed with Mina, and she was provided with the case number and instructions for obtaining records. Transport to the clinic was coordinated, with the advocate meeting Mina at the entrance and her friend traveling separately.

Officers secured all potential evidence until CSI arrived. Dispatch confirmed that city camera retention had been initiated. A brief debrief between officers ensured the report would avoid leading language and include verbatim statements from Mina.

At approximately 07:35 hours, officers cleared the scene after confirming Mina’s safe departure.

End of Report.

approximate height. 17:45:18 — Li requests HR to retain badge activity, sends preservation letter. 17:46:41 — No leading questions; officers avoid character judgments, focus on who, what, when, where, how, and exact quotes. 17:48:07 — Rosa asks about no-contact: advised on internal HR and criminal options; provided form for temporary order information. 17:49:36 — Review and summarize back to Rosa; she confirms and signs statement acknowledging voluntary nature. 17:51:22 — Officers clear scene to begin follow-up canvass of cameras. 18:19:38 — End.
Incident_Report:
Incident Report

Case Number: 25-240047
Date: September 5, 2025
Time on Scene: 17:22 to 18:19
Location: 77 Redwood Office Park, Stairwell B Landing and Floor 3 Conference Room
Reporting Officer: P.O. Li (#2631)
Assisting Officer: P.O. Gomez (#2740)
Weather: Sunny, 82°F

Narrative:

On September 5, 2025, at approximately 17:22 hours, Officers Li and Gomez responded to a call regarding a sexual assault report at 77 Redwood Office Park, specifically at Stairwell B Landing. Upon arrival, building security was present and assisted in locating the complainant, identified as Rosa, a female in her mid-30s. Rosa was found seated on a step at the mid-level landing, visibly upset and clutching her phone.

Officer Li introduced himself and offered Rosa the choice of location for the interview. Rosa elected to proceed to an empty conference room on Floor 3 for privacy and comfort. After obtaining Rosa’s consent to record the interview and explaining the purpose, Officer Li prompted her to provide a free narrative of the incident.

Rosa stated that she works on the 4th floor and that the suspect cornered her between the 3rd and 4th floors in Stairwell B. She reported that the suspect placed his hand on her despite her clear verbal objection, stating “stop” and “I have to go back to work.” Rosa described prior interactions with the suspect as cordial but clarified that there was no romantic relationship. The suspect allegedly said to her, “Don’t act like you don’t want it,” which was documented verbatim by Officer Gomez.

Spatial details were clarified with Rosa’s assistance; she identified the exact step and wall where the incident occurred. Officers photographed the area with Rosa’s consent, including measurements of the handrail height. A physical injury was noted: redness on Rosa’s upper arm, which was photographed with a scale for documentation.

Building security was requested to preserve access logs and video footage from 16:45 to 17:10 hours covering Stairwell B and adjacent corridors. An email was sent to property management with the incident number to ensure preservation of evidence.

Witnesses were identified: a coworker named Dev who observed Rosa returning upset, and an HR representative named Ally who was notified. Rosa consented to Ally’s presence for support during the interview, though officers maintained an independent record.

Rosa chose to conduct the interview in English. She was offered a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) exam and was informed of options for immediate, delayed, or no exam, including clothing collection procedures. Rosa elected to delay the exam and was advised on preserving potential evidence by avoiding washing the affected area.

Digital evidence was collected, including a text message from the suspect sent at 17:01 stating, “We good?” A screenshot with time metadata was captured, and Rosa consented to a forensic download of her phone data at a later time via consent or warrant.

The suspect was not present on scene, and officers refrained from contact to preserve investigative integrity. Rosa accepted emotional support via a hotline advocate who joined the call.

Rosa described how she escaped by stepping down and saying “No,” then exiting through the door on the 3rd floor. A scene walkthrough was conducted with Rosa’s consent; the path was documented, and the door latch was found to function normally. Lighting conditions were noted as good, and cameras were likely to have captured entry and exit.

Rosa requested assistance in informing her supervisor. Officers provided a brief statement template that allowed her to share information without disclosing details she was not ready to discuss. Safety planning options were reviewed, including schedule changes, security escorts, and protective order information.

Officers clarified next steps, explaining that a formal recorded interview could be scheduled later and that today’s account was preliminary. Rosa was reminded that her participation level was voluntary.

After a short break, Rosa recalled the suspect’s appearance, noting he wore a gray quarter-zip and an ID badge with a red lanyard. Approximate height was provided. Officers requested HR to retain badge activity records and sent a preservation letter.

Throughout the interview, officers avoided leading questions and character judgments, focusing on factual details and exact quotes. Rosa inquired about no-contact options and was advised on internal HR and criminal procedures, receiving a form with temporary order information.

The interview concluded with a review and summary of Rosa’s statement, which she confirmed and signed, acknowledging the voluntary nature of her participation.

At 17:51 hours, officers cleared the scene to begin a follow-up canvass of security cameras. The investigation remains ongoing.

End of Report.

Incident_Report:
Incident Report

Case Number: 25-240061  
Date of Incident: September 6, 2025  
Location: City Library, Study Room 2C  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Hwang (#2984)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Cutter (#3110)  
Weather Conditions: Overcast, 70°F  
Time on Scene: 13:11:18 – 14:05:40

Narrative:

On September 6, 2025, at approximately 13:11 hours, P.O. Hwang and P.O. Cutter responded to a sexual assault report at the City Library, specifically Study Room 2C. Upon arrival, the scene was secured, and the complainant, identified as Elise, was present along with a librarian named Marta. After Elise requested privacy, the librarian consented and exited the room.

Initial introductions were made, seating arrangements were offered, and consent to record the interview was obtained. Ground rules were established to ensure Elise’s comfort, including the option to pause or stop the interview at any time. Elise was encouraged to provide a free narrative of the incident.

Elise reported that while studying in the room, the suspect closed the door and began touching her without consent. She stated, “We were studying. He closed the door. He started touching me. I said ‘No, I don’t want that.’” When she resisted, the suspect laughed and persisted, prompting Elise to move his hand away and stand up. Throughout the interview, officers maintained a trauma-informed approach, asking open-ended questions and reflecting key points without interruption or leading statements.

The physical environment was documented, including the position of a chair angled under the door knob. Elise explained she placed the chair after the suspect left to prevent re-entry. Officers photographed the scene and restored the chair to its original position to clarify which actions occurred post-incident.

Elise reported no visible injuries but described feelings of nausea and anxiety. Emergency Medical Services were offered; however, Elise declined transport but requested to speak with a victim advocate. Information regarding Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) services was provided, and Elise elected to consider this option later. Officers supplied written materials outlining timeframes and confidentiality related to forensic examinations.

Regarding evidence, the library’s corridor cameras were identified as potentially relevant. Officer Hwang requested preservation of footage from 12:10 to 12:50, and a written request was documented on body-worn camera footage. A fellow student named Jon was identified as a possible witness who may have knocked on the door around 12:40; his contact information was obtained.

Elise presented a text message from the suspect sent after the incident, stating, “Sorry if I pushed boundaries.” This message was photographed with a timestamp. The interview was conducted entirely in English, and no interpreter was required.

Sensory details were elicited, with Elise recalling the suspect saying, “Come on, it’s just us.” Safety measures were discussed, and Elise accepted an escort to exit the library and arrange transportation. Officers maintained a steady, supportive tone throughout, avoiding surprise questions and ensuring Elise’s comfort.

A scene diagram was sketched and annotated by Elise, then photographed for documentation. Officers refrained from making credibility assessments or leading comparisons, opting to use direct quotes in the report. Follow-up procedures were explained, including scheduling a formal interview when Elise feels ready, and providing case contact information.

Elise inquired about a no-contact order; officers explained the process and connected her with victim services. A brief walkthrough with the librarian was conducted to locate security cameras and note retention policies.

After a period of rest, during which officers maintained presence without further questioning, Elise indicated readiness to leave. She was escorted safely to a rideshare vehicle, and the CAD was updated accordingly. Officers returned to collect additional camera angle notes before concluding the scene at 14:05 hours.

All actions were conducted in accordance with department protocols, ensuring a trauma-informed, respectful, and thorough response to the complainant’s report.

End of Report.  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Hwang (#2984)  
Date: September 6, 2025

Incident_Report:
Incident Report

Case Number: 25-240078  
Date/Time of Incident: September 6, 2025, approximately 16:20–16:50  
Location: Community Pool, Staff Locker Room A  
Reporting Officer: Sgt. Kim (#1907)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Alvarado (#2256)  
Weather: Hot, 89°F  

Narrative:

On September 6, 2025, at approximately 17:09 hours, Sgt. Kim and P.O. Alvarado responded to a call regarding a sexual assault report at the Community Pool, specifically in Staff Locker Room A. Upon arrival, officers were met by the facility manager who directed them to the complainant, identified as Tara, a lifeguard at the pool.

Tara requested to speak privately in an office, and with the manager’s consent, the officers complied. At 17:10, Sgt. Kim obtained Tara’s consent to record the interview and explained her rights, including the option to pause or stop the recording at any time.

Tara provided a free narrative account of the incident. She stated that after finishing her shift, she entered the staff locker room where a male coworker followed her. She reported that the coworker engaged in unwanted touching despite her verbal objections, stating “Stop. Not okay.” Tara recalled pushing his hand away and stepping back to create distance. She also placed her bag between them as a physical barrier. The suspect was later identified as wearing a red swim parka.

Officers documented the scene by photographing the locker room entry, interior layout, and signage indicating restricted staff-only access. Care was taken to respect the privacy of other staff members, avoiding any filming of individuals changing or in vulnerable positions. No visible injuries were noted on Tara; however, she reported lingering anxiety and soreness in her wrist. With her consent, photographs of any redness or marks were taken.

Tara was informed of the Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination options. She elected to undergo the exam after arranging shift coverage. An advocate was offered and accepted to provide support.

A potential witness, coworker Neil, was identified as possibly having overheard Tara’s verbal objection. Contact information was collected for a follow-up interview to be conducted privately. Officers requested preservation of door camera footage covering the timeframe from 16:20 to 16:50, which the manager agreed to. Additionally, badge swipe logs were requested to verify the suspect’s movements, as he reportedly left the premises early.

To ensure Tara’s safety and comfort, a safety plan was discussed and agreed upon, including adjusting work schedules to avoid overlapping shifts with the suspect. Sgt. Kim facilitated the creation of a sketch map illustrating the positions of Tara and the suspect during the incident, which was photographed for evidence.

Throughout the interview, officers refrained from expressing opinions about the individuals involved, focusing solely on factual actions, words, and timing. Tara was advised of her options to pursue criminal charges, administrative action, both, or neither, emphasizing her right to make an informed decision.

The manager was briefed on evidence preservation protocols and reminded of the department’s non-retaliation policy. Transportation arrangements were made to escort Tara to the exam site, and she was provided with a rights sheet and a list of available resources.

At 18:03 hours, officers cleared the scene. Follow-up tasks were logged, including retrieval of CCTV footage, badge swipe logs, scheduling of witness interviews, and monitoring the status of the SANE exam.

End of report.

Incident Report  
Case Number: 25-240093  
Date of Incident: September 6, 2025 (evening)  
Date of Report: September 7, 2025  
Location: Office Park Lot C — Bay 19  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Doyle (#3198)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Kravitz (#2902)  

On September 7, 2025, at approximately 07:21 hours, Officers Doyle and Kravitz responded to a sexual assault report at Office Park Lot C, Bay 19. Upon arrival, we met with the reporting party, identified as Noor, who was standing next to her vehicle. Noor was cooperative and preferred to conduct the interview in a shaded area nearby.

After introductions and explaining the process, including the option to take breaks and the availability of advocacy services, Noor consented to have the interview recorded. She provided a free narrative account of the incident, stating that the previous evening after work, while being driven by the suspect in the backseat of a coworker’s carpool vehicle, the suspect engaged in unwanted touching despite her verbal objections. Noor stated she told the suspect to stop and used phrases such as “No, I don’t want this” and “Take me home.”

We clarified the sequence of events with non-leading questions. Noor described the route taken, including a stop in the parking lot, and confirmed the suspect’s behavior during the ride. She reported that the suspect briefly engaged the child safety lock from the driver’s controls, which prevented her from opening the door; Noor pulled the door handle twice to attempt to exit.

With Noor’s consent, officers documented the backseat area of the vehicle, taking photographs of the seat covers and a tissue box. No signs of disturbance or damage were noted. Noor reported a bruise beginning to form on her thigh; she consented to photographs of the injury with a scale for reference. Emergency Medical Services were offered but declined in favor of a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) clinic appointment scheduled for later that day.

Digital evidence was reviewed, including text messages from the suspect to Noor, with one message stating, “Sorry if I crossed a line.” This message was captured and preserved. Officers also noted a witness statement from a neighbor who observed Noor arrive home visibly upset the previous evening; contact information for the witness was recorded.

Officers discussed evidence preservation options with Noor, including the possibility of submitting clothing for forensic examination after her medical exam. Safety options were reviewed, including the process for obtaining a protection order and workplace liaison support.

Officers requested CCTV footage from the office park’s property management covering the time frame of 18:05 to 18:45 on the previous evening to corroborate Noor’s account. A scene diagram depicting seating positions in the vehicle was created and photographed.

Noor inquired about pressing charges; officers informed her of the timelines involved and emphasized that reporting the incident today preserves her options for future legal action. The interview was conducted in a trauma-informed, non-judgmental manner, respecting Noor’s prior interactions with the suspect.

At approximately 08:17 hours, the interview concluded. Noor was provided with a resource sheet, the case number, and a plan for transport to the SANE clinic and follow-up interview. The case remains under active investigation.

End of report.  
P.O. Doyle (#3198)  
P.O. Kravitz (#2902)

Incident Report

Case Number: 25-240108  
Date of Incident: September 7, 2025  
Location: 60 Orchard Co-Op, Room 3B Common Area  
Reporting Officers: P.O. Carter (#1842), P.O. Velasquez (#2079)  
Time on Scene: 18:12:52 – 19:06:11  
Weather: Overcast, 71°F  
Call Type: Sexual Assault Report

Narrative:

On September 7, 2025, at approximately 18:12 hours, Officers Carter and Velasquez responded to a sexual assault report at 60 Orchard Co-Op, specifically in the Room 3B common area. Upon arrival, officers made contact with the reporting party, identified as “Piper,” who was accompanied by roommates nearby. Piper requested to speak privately, and officers complied by relocating the interview to a private room within the facility.

At 18:13, officers obtained Piper’s consent to record the interview and established ground rules for the conversation. Piper provided a free narrative account of the incident, stating that earlier that day, between approximately 16:30 and 16:45, she and the suspect were watching a movie in her room. Piper stated she explicitly communicated that she did not want to engage in any sexual activity. Despite this, the suspect attempted to initiate sexual contact. Piper responded by saying “No,” physically moving the suspect’s hand away, standing up, and opening the door to exit the room.

Officers documented Piper’s exact quotes and actions as described. Photographs of the room layout were taken with Piper’s consent, ensuring that personal items were avoided. The photos included the door, bed, and the path leading to the hallway to provide context for the scene.

A roommate who was nearby reported hearing raised voices and observed the suspect leaving the room quickly. Contact information for the roommate was collected for potential follow-up. Piper was informed about the Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) program and chose to delay the examination at that time. Officers provided guidance on timeframes for evidence collection and advised Piper to preserve clothing worn during the incident.

Digital evidence was collected, including messages from the suspect, one of which read, “Can we talk?” Safety planning was discussed in detail. Piper agreed to stay with a roommate, lock her door, and call police if the suspect returned. Officers also discussed no-contact options and provided information on protective measures.

Emotional support was offered, and Piper accepted a call with an advocate, which was conducted on speakerphone. The interview was conducted entirely in English, and no interpreter was required. Officers carefully avoided any commentary that could affect Piper’s credibility and summarized the information to ensure accuracy.

Follow-up tasks were logged, including requests for building entry logs and review of campus security camera footage near the lobby. Piper inquired about reporting the incident to campus authorities. Officers explained the parallel reporting processes and emphasized that the decision to report to campus was hers to make.

The interview concluded at 19:06 hours. Piper was provided with the case number, a contact card for the investigating officers, and a resource list including counseling and support services.

This report is submitted to document the initial response and investigation steps taken in relation to the sexual assault report at 60 Orchard Co-Op on September 7, 2025.

Prepared by:  
P.O. Carter (#1842)  
Date: September 7, 2025

Incident Report  
Case Number: 25-240119  
Date/Time of Incident: September 7, 2025, approximately 20:10–20:45  
Date/Time Reported: September 8, 2025, 16:58–17:52  
Location: 1100 Lakeside Boat Ramp Picnic Table and Dock Area  
Reporting Officer: Sgt. Salazar (#2081)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Keane (#3775)  
Weather: Mild, 73°F  

Narrative:  
On September 8, 2025, at approximately 16:58 hours, Sgt. Salazar and P.O. Keane responded to a call regarding a sexual assault report at the public boat ramp picnic area located at 1100 Lakeside. Upon arrival, officers met with the reporting party, identified herein as “Hannah” for confidentiality, who was present at the picnic table near the boat ramp. Officers offered a quieter location for the interview; Hannah elected to remain seated in the patrol SUV with the door open for comfort and privacy.

After obtaining Hannah’s consent to record the interview, officers explained her options regarding the reporting process and evidence collection. Hannah provided a free narrative account, stating that on the previous evening, between approximately 20:10 and 20:45, she had met an acquaintance at the boat ramp. They sat together on the dock, during which the acquaintance engaged in unwanted sexual contact despite Hannah’s verbal refusals, including saying “No, stop.” She described the sequence of events, noting that after the unwanted contact, she stood up and left the area, heading toward the parking lot lights.

Hannah reported no visible injuries but described soreness resulting from the incident. Emergency medical services were offered but declined. Officers requested and received cooperation from marina staff to obtain CCTV footage from the marina and parking lot cameras covering the time frame of the previous evening’s incident. Screenshots of text messages sent by the suspect after the incident, including a message stating “I misread,” were captured and documented as evidence.

Hannah was informed of Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) options and chose to undergo a forensic medical examination. Transport to the medical facility was arranged, and a victim advocate was notified to provide support. Officers took photographs of the general scene, ensuring no intrusion on public privacy, and noted the lighting conditions at the time.

Potential witnesses were identified, including a fisherman nearby who may have observed the interaction. A business card was left on the windshield of a vehicle believed to be associated with the suspect, with permission from marina staff. Security logs were also reviewed for additional information.

Safety planning was discussed; Hannah shared her location with a friend, and officers provided information regarding restraining orders and protective measures. Throughout the interview, officers maintained a neutral tone, avoided leading questions, and did not minimize prior interactions between Hannah and the suspect.

A summary of the interview was read back to Hannah, who confirmed the details and added that the suspect was wearing cologne at the time. This detail was documented. Follow-up tasks were assigned, including coordination with detectives for a formal interview and retrieval of camera footage.

The interview concluded at approximately 17:52 hours. All evidence and documentation were secured for further investigation.

End of Report.  
Sgt. Salazar (#2081)  
P.O. Keane (#3775)

Case Number: 15  
Date of Incident: September 8, 2025  
Location: 700 Grand Hotel, Room 1221 Sitting Area  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Ebner (#2339)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Fox (#2577)

Weather Conditions: Cloudy, 69°F  

On September 8, 2025, at approximately 22:09 hours, officers Ebner and Fox were dispatched to the 700 Grand Hotel in response to a reported sexual assault. Upon arrival, security personnel escorted the officers to Room 1221, where the complainant, identified as Mae, was present along with a friend.

At 22:10, officers obtained Mae’s consent to record the interview and offered the option for her friend to remain in the room. Mae requested that her friend stay quietly during the interview. Mae provided a free narrative account of the incident, stating that the initial interaction involved consensual kissing. However, she reported that the suspect engaged in non-consensual touching despite her repeated verbal refusals. Mae stated she said “No” multiple times, and the suspect initially persisted, saying “Come on,” before ceasing his actions after she stood up and pointed toward the door.

Officers clarified the sequence of events without assigning blame, ensuring Mae felt in control of the narrative. Mae confirmed that the suspect attempted to continue after her refusals but stopped when she physically indicated her desire to end the encounter.

To support the investigation, officers requested access to hotel hallway surveillance footage covering the time frame from 21:00 to 22:15 and obtained keycard access logs through hotel security. A consent letter for recording was documented. Scene documentation included wide, mid-range, and close-up photographs of the sitting area, door, and lighting conditions. Officers maintained neutrality in their observations, noting no signs of disorder or disturbance in the room.

Mae was informed about Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) options and provided with informational packets and paper bags for preserving clothing as potential evidence, should she decide to pursue medical examination later. During the interview, officers captured digital evidence, including messages from the suspect stating, “Can we talk?”

A witness, a neighboring guest in Room 1223, reported hearing voices during the relevant time frame. Security personnel were tasked with contacting the witness for further information, and officers collected preliminary details.

For Mae’s safety and comfort, arrangements were made for her to remain with her friend overnight. The hotel offered a room change, and officers ensured Mae had a new key and instructions on securing the lock.

Before concluding the interaction, officers summarized the information provided, confirming details without leading questions and emphasizing Mae’s autonomy and control over the process. Follow-up tasks were identified, including coordination with detectives and tracking evidence preservation deadlines.

The officers concluded their on-scene activities at 23:04 hours.

End of Report.

At approximately 16:06 hours on September 9, 2025, Officers Ortega and Wynn responded to a call regarding a sexual assault report at City Beach, specifically near Dune Path 3 Bench. Upon arrival, officers made contact with the reporting party, identified as “Aria,” seated on a bench in the vicinity. Due to wind noise interfering with audio recording, Officer Ortega offered to relocate to a quieter location; however, Aria preferred to proceed to the nearby beach office for the interview.

At 16:07, after obtaining Aria’s consent to record the interview, officers explained the available options for reporting and evidence collection. Aria provided a free narrative account of the incident, describing an initial consensual interaction involving kissing, followed by non-consensual touching. Aria stated that she verbally expressed “Stop” and physically moved away from the subject, who briefly followed her. The officers carefully clarified the timeline and positions of both parties during the incident, documenting exact quotes used by Aria and the subject to ensure accuracy.

Officers noted the possibility of obtaining surveillance footage from a nearby lifeguard tower camera that may cover the corridor where the incident occurred. A request for this footage was logged, and beach office staff were cooperative in facilitating this process. Photographs of the general area were taken to document the scene; however, officers did not collect footprints or other physical trace evidence due to the elapsed time since the incident and the public nature of the location. This limitation was explicitly noted in the report.

Aria was informed of Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) options and elected to undergo a forensic medical examination. Officers also inquired about potential witnesses and were informed that a jogger may have passed through the area during the relevant timeframe. A witness card was left at the beach kiosk, and information about an anonymous social media tip line was provided to encourage additional leads.

Safety considerations were addressed; Aria confirmed she had a ride arranged. Officers provided her with a resource sheet containing support services, the case number, and instructions for follow-up procedures. Throughout the interaction, officers maintained a trauma-informed approach, ensuring the pacing of the interview was sensitive and non-leading, and all documentation was neutral and factual.

The interview and on-scene investigation concluded at 17:01 hours. The case remains open pending review of surveillance footage and any additional witness information.

End of Report.

Case Number: 25-240162  
Date: September 9, 2025  
Location: 500 Market St., Office Suite 610 Quiet Room  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Li (#2631)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Gomez (#2740)  
Weather: Overcast, 68°F  
Time on Scene: 10:19:45 – 11:12:33

On September 9, 2025, at approximately 10:19 hours, Officers Li and Gomez responded to a call regarding a sexual assault report at 500 Market Street, Office Suite 610. Upon arrival, officers met with the reporting party, identified as “Maya,” who was accompanied by a Human Resources (HR) representative at her request. Officers clarified the independent criminal investigation process and obtained Maya’s consent to record the interview, informing her of her right to pause or stop the recording at any time.

Maya provided a free narrative account of the incident, describing unwanted physical contact that occurred in the phone room of the office. She stated that the suspect engaged in unwanted touching despite her verbal objection, saying, “No, this is not okay.” Maya indicated that the suspect persisted briefly before she exited the room. Officers carefully clarified the sequence of events, direct quotes, and physical positions involved without making any character judgments.

To preserve evidence, officers requested badge logs and surveillance footage from the corridor cameras near the phone room. A formal preservation request was sent to the appropriate department. Maya was informed of Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) options but declined the examination; however, she accepted an information packet for future reference.

Digital evidence was also collected, including an email from the suspect containing the statement, “Apologies if I made you uncomfortable.” This email was photographed, and its header information was preserved. The department’s IT unit was instructed to archive the email under a retention hold to prevent deletion.

Officers identified a potential witness, a coworker who reported hearing the phone room door close abruptly during the time of the incident. Contact information for the witness was obtained for follow-up.

Regarding Maya’s safety, the HR representative arranged a schedule change to minimize contact with the suspect. Officers provided Maya with information about obtaining a protection order should she choose to pursue one.

At 11:12 hours, officers read back a summary of the interview and investigative steps to Maya, who confirmed the accuracy of the report. The interview concluded without further incident.

This report will be forwarded to the Sexual Assault Unit for continued investigation. All evidence and statements have been documented and secured in accordance with department protocols.

End of Report.

Incident_Report:
Incident Report

Case Number: 25-240201  
Date/Time of Incident: September 10, 2025, approximately 23:40–23:56  
Location: 44 Easton Bar, Patio Nook  
Reporting Officer: Sgt. Patel (#1876) and P.O. Ortega (#2688)  
Weather Conditions: Clear, 72°F

Narrative:

On September 10, 2025, at approximately 00:22 hours, officers Sgt. Patel and P.O. Ortega responded to a call regarding a sexual assault at 44 Easton Bar, specifically the patio nook area. Upon arrival, officers were guided by bar staff to a quieter corner of the patio where the reporting party, identified as “Skye,” a female in her mid-20s, was seated with a friend named “Jules.” After introductions and obtaining consent to record the interview, Skye elected to move to the bar’s staff office to provide her statement.

Skye was offered water and informed that she could pause or stop the interview at any time. She began her narrative by stating that she had met a male individual near the patio heaters, specifically heater number two. She described initiating a brief kiss with the man, who was later identified by Skye as “Evan.” Skye stated that after the kiss, she told the man she did not want to proceed further. Despite her verbal refusals, including saying “No, stop,” the man placed his hand under her skirt and touched her thigh. Skye reported pushing his hand away and verbally telling him to stop, but he continued to touch her, saying “Relax” and “You’re fine.” She then moved away from the heater, stepped left, and walked inside the bar to find her friend Jules.

The suspect was described as approximately 5 feet 10 inches tall, with a beard, wearing a blue cap with a brewery logo, a gray hoodie, and dark jeans. Skye noted additional identifying features including a thin silver ring on his right index finger, a woven bracelet with blue threads on his wrist, and the scent of citrus cologne.

Skye reported no visible injuries but complained of thigh soreness, anxiety, and nausea. Emergency medical services were offered but declined. Officers informed Skye about the availability of a Sexual Assault Forensic Exam (SAFE/SANE) at no cost, with or without filing a police report. After discussing timing and procedures, Skye elected to undergo the exam that evening. The on-call Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner was requested to respond.

With the consent of the bar manager, Sgt. Patel documented the scene by photographing the patio area, heater #2, the bench, and lighting conditions. The manager also confirmed the presence of CCTV cameras covering the patio and entrance. Officers requested preservation of footage from 23:20 to 00:15 hours, and the manager signed consent forms to retain and copy the recordings. An email request was sent to the camera system administrator.

Witness statements were obtained from Jules, who reported seeing Skye enter the bar upset around 23:56 and overhearing her say “He wouldn’t stop.” Another potential witness, a patron named “Mack,” may have observed the interaction near the heaters; contact information was collected via the bar manager for follow-up.

Skye identified the suspect as “Evan” and showed officers an Instagram profile she believed matched him. Officers photographed the profile screen, including the visible handle and timestamp. Skye consented to a possible forensic download of messages if any occur but preferred to delay signing the consent form.

Throughout the interview, officers employed trauma-informed techniques, slowing the pace when Skye became tearful and validating her feelings. Safety planning was discussed; Jules agreed to accompany Skye to the clinic and then home. Officers reviewed rideshare safety, options for a no-contact order if the suspect is identified, and the bar’s trespass policy.

Victim rights were reviewed, and an advocacy hotline was contacted with Skye’s permission. An advocate was arranged to meet Skye at the clinic. No suspect was present at the scene, and officers instructed bar staff to notify them if a person matching the description returned. No detentions were made due to lack of lawful basis.

A summary of the incident was read back to Skye, who confirmed its accuracy and added details about the suspect’s ring. Officers prepared chain-of-custody materials, including paper bags and labels, should Skye choose to submit clothing after the exam. Environmental factors such as moderate patio lighting and heater fan noise potentially affecting audio on CCTV were documented.

At approximately 00:43 hours, officers coordinated transport for Skye to the SANE facility, with the bar providing a security escort to an alley for privacy. Follow-up tasks were logged, including obtaining CCTV copies, identifying the suspect via social media and bar tabs between 22:30 and 00:10, and re-contacting the potential witness “Mack.”

Officers cleared the scene at 01:14 hours after Skye departed with the advocate. Throughout the response, officers maintained a professional and neutral demeanor, avoiding leading questions or commentary on credibility.

End of report.
