Incident Report

Case Number: 25-240214  
Date of Report: September 10, 2025  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Li (#2631)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Gomez (#2740)  
Location: 2130 Briarwood Ln., Apt 1D  
Weather: Overcast, 67°F  
Time on Scene: 12:11:42 – 13:08:15  

On September 10, 2025, at approximately 12:11 hours, Officers Li and Gomez responded to a call regarding a sexual assault report at 2130 Briarwood Lane, Apartment 1D. Upon arrival, the resident, identified as Iris, promptly opened the door and invited officers inside to discuss the incident at the kitchen table. Consent to record the interview was obtained and explained to Iris, including the option to pause and the use of open-ended questions.

Iris provided a free narrative account of the events that transpired the previous evening. She stated that she and the suspect watched a television show together and engaged in cuddling. At one point, she expressed that she did not want to proceed further, but the suspect continued to touch her chest and hips despite her verbal refusals. Iris recalled explicitly saying “No,” “Not okay,” and “Stop,” to which the suspect responded, “Come on, you’re into it.” The timeline established by Iris indicated that the suspect arrived around 20:00 hours, the show ended at approximately 21:10, and the unwanted touching occurred between 21:15 and 21:25. Iris asked the suspect to leave, and he departed at 21:30.

With Iris’s consent, Officer Gomez documented the scene by photographing the living room couch, throw blanket, path to the front door, and lighting conditions. Iris was still wearing the same leggings from the previous evening. Officers informed her that clothing collection was optional and could be facilitated through a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) exam, which she elected to undergo later that day. Paper evidence bags were provided should she change clothing prior to transport.

A medical assessment revealed no visible injuries; however, Iris reported soreness. Emergency Medical Services were offered but declined. Iris indicated she would discuss pain management options with the SANE nurse during the exam.

Neighbor Liam was identified as a potential witness after reporting hearing muffled voices around 21:20 hours. Contact information was obtained for a follow-up interview. Additionally, officers documented a text message sent by the suspect after leaving, which read, “Sorry if I pushed too far.” The message was photographed with timestamps, and Iris consented to a later download of digital evidence.

During safety planning, Iris confirmed that the suspect did not have a key to her apartment. Officers advised her on the option to change locks and provided information on protective orders. When asked what helped her end the interaction, Iris stated she stood up, pointed to the door, and firmly told the suspect, “I need you to go.” She also recalled sensory details including the suspect’s aftershave scent and a canvas jacket with a torn cuff.

Officers coordinated with the property manager to preserve exterior CCTV footage covering 20:45 to 21:45 hours. An email request for the footage was recorded on camera. Iris was connected with a local advocacy service, and an advocate joined the call to explain exam options and available support.

A summary of the interview was read back to Iris, who confirmed its accuracy and added that the suspect had parked a black Honda Civic near parking spot 12, with a partial license plate reading “8DL—.” Follow-up tasks were assigned, including canvassing for the vehicle, reviewing municipal cameras, and scheduling a formal interview when Iris is ready.

The officers concluded their on-scene investigation at 13:08 hours.

End of Report.

Incident Report

Case Number: 25-240226  
Date/Time of Incident: September 11, 2025, approximately 15:30–15:50  
Location: Boardwalk Underpass — North Ramp  
Reporting Officer(s): P.O. Hwang (#2984), P.O. Cutter (#3110)  
Weather Conditions: Cloudy, 65°F  

Narrative:

On September 11, 2025, at approximately 16:05 hours, Officers Hwang and Cutter responded to a call regarding a sexual assault report at the Boardwalk Underpass, North Ramp. Upon arrival at 16:05:03, officers met with the reporting party, hereafter referred to as “Nova,” under the shaded area of the underpass. After obtaining consent to record the interview, Nova expressed a preference to relocate to the nearby lifeguard office for privacy and comfort, which officers facilitated.

Nova provided a free narrative of the incident, stating that she and the suspect had walked from the beach to the underpass area. During this time, the suspect began touching her inappropriately under the bridge. Nova stated she verbally told the suspect to “Stop” and physically moved away. Despite this, the suspect attempted to touch her again. Nova described the timeline of events occurring roughly between 15:30 and 15:50. She recounted that the suspect said, “Why are you acting shy?” to which she responded “No” twice. She then stepped into sunlight near the ramp, at which point the suspect ceased following her.

Officers documented the scene by photographing the ramp, the shaded area, and the adjacent path. Ambient sounds such as tide noise and lighting conditions at approximately 16:10 were noted for context. No disturbances or additional claims were reported at the scene.

A preservation request was made for footage from the city pole camera located on the boardwalk, covering the timeframe from 15:15 to 16:00, to assist with the investigation. Dispatch logs confirm the request was submitted.

Medical assessment revealed no visible injuries on Nova, though she reported experiencing stress and a scrape sustained earlier unrelated to the incident. Emergency Medical Services were offered but declined. Officers provided information regarding Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) services, explaining the process and timelines. Nova elected to consider this option at a later time and was given a written guide and a blind kit for evidence preservation.

Officers attempted to identify potential witnesses. A surfer known as “Leo” was mentioned as possibly passing by during the incident. Officers left a business card and tipline QR code at the local surf shop to encourage any witnesses to come forward.

Nova described the suspect as wearing a red baseball cap, a white t-shirt with “SEASIDE” printed on it, and carrying a skateboard. She later added that the suspect had a wrist tattoo depicting waves. Nova reported no immediate digital communications from the suspect and had blocked his phone number. Officers noted this action and clarified that it would not affect the investigation.

Safety planning was discussed; Nova confirmed she had a ride home arranged. Officers offered to return any property if necessary and provided a resource list for support services.

At 16:14, officers read back a summary of the report to Nova, who confirmed the accuracy and added the detail regarding the wrist tattoo. Follow-up actions were outlined, including retrieval of CCTV footage, canvassing the surf shop for additional information, and scheduling a formal interview.

The interaction concluded at 17:01 hours.

End of Report.  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Hwang (#2984)  
Secondary Officer: P.O. Cutter (#3110)

Not okay.’” 10:33:22 — Clarify sequence and positions; Sage points to inside bench where it happened, then stepping back to doorway. 10:34:08 — Scene documentation: photos of bench, tool wall, narrow aisle; measurement of aisle width to understand proximity; neutral descriptions only. 10:35:06 — Quotes: suspect said “No one’s around,” Sage said “Stop, I don’t want this.” 10:35:34 — Medical: No visible injuries; reports being shaken; EMS declined. 10:36:02 — SANE options explained; Sage chooses exam; transport coordinated to clinic; advocate contacted with permission. 10:36:58 — Witnesses: Garden coordinator heard raised voices after; contact info obtained. 10:37:29 — Access logs: Shed lock sign-in sheet photographed; request to preserve 09:45–10:45. 10:38:21 — Safety planning: Coordinator agrees to adjust volunteer schedule to prevent overlap; trespass option discussed if suspect returns. 10:39:14 — Sensory cues: smell of soil and cedar; suspect wore green work gloves and a faded cap. 10:39:47 — Digital: none; they don’t exchange numbers. 10:40:06 — Summary read back; Sage confirms; adds that suspect blocked aisle briefly before she stepped around; detail documented without inference. 10:41:18 — Follow-up: sign-in sheet copy, CCTV at park entrance, formal interview scheduling. 11:29:18 — End.
Incident_Report:
Incident Report

Case Number: 21  
Date of Incident: September 11, 2025  
Location: Community Garden Shed  
Reporting Officers: Sgt. Kim (#1907), P.O. Alvarado (#2256)  
Time on Scene: 10:31:55 – 11:29:18  
Weather: Hot, 88°F  

On September 11, 2025, at approximately 10:31 hours, Sgt. Kim and P.O. Alvarado responded to a report of a sexual assault at the Community Garden Shed. Upon arrival, the officers were greeted by the reporting party, identified as “Sage,” a community volunteer. Consent to record the interview was obtained, and Sage selected a picnic table under shade near the shed for the interview.

Sage provided a free narrative of the incident, stating that while sorting tools with the suspect inside the shed, the suspect placed his hand on her waist and attempted to make further physical contact. Sage immediately told the suspect to stop, stating, “Stop. Not okay.” To clarify the sequence and positions, Sage pointed to the bench inside the shed where the incident occurred and then stepped back to the doorway to demonstrate her movements.

Officers documented the scene with photographs of the bench, tool wall, and the narrow aisle where the interaction took place. Measurements were taken of the aisle width to understand the proximity between Sage and the suspect. The officers maintained neutral descriptions without inference. Sage recalled the suspect saying, “No one’s around,” while she responded, “Stop, I don’t want this.” No visible injuries were observed on Sage, who reported feeling shaken but declined emergency medical services at the scene.

SANE (Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner) options were explained to Sage, who elected to undergo a forensic medical examination. Transport to the clinic was coordinated, and with Sage’s permission, a victim advocate was contacted to provide support. The garden coordinator, who was a witness to raised voices following the incident, provided contact information for follow-up.

Officers obtained and photographed the shed’s lock sign-in sheet and requested preservation of records covering the time frame from 09:45 to 10:45 to assist with the investigation. Safety planning was discussed with the garden coordinator, who agreed to adjust volunteer schedules to prevent overlap between Sage and the suspect. The option to pursue trespass orders if the suspect returned was also discussed.

Sensory details were noted, including the smell of soil and cedar in the shed. The suspect was described as wearing green work gloves and a faded cap. No digital communication between Sage and the suspect was reported, as they did not exchange phone numbers.

A summary of the interview was read back to Sage, who confirmed the accuracy and added that the suspect briefly blocked the aisle before she stepped around him. This detail was documented without inference. Follow-up actions included obtaining a copy of the sign-in sheet, reviewing CCTV footage from the park entrance, and scheduling a formal interview with the suspect.

The officers concluded their on-scene investigation at 11:29 hours. All evidence and statements were collected and secured for further investigation.

Report prepared by:  
Sgt. Kim (#1907)  
P.O. Alvarado (#2256)  
Date: September 11, 2025

Incident_Report:
Incident Report

Case Number: 25-240251  
Date of Incident: September 12, 2025  
Location: 500 City Gardens — Gazebo Area  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Doyle (#3198)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Kravitz (#2902)  
Weather Conditions: Sunny, 82°F  
Time on Scene: 17:59 to 18:55

Narrative:

On September 12, 2025, at approximately 17:59 hours, Officers Doyle and Kravitz responded to a call regarding a sexual assault report at the 500 City Gardens, specifically near the gazebo area. Upon arrival, the officers met with the reporting party, identified as “Remi,” who was seated on the grass near a group of adolescents. To ensure privacy and minimize distress, the officers suggested relocating the conversation to the nearby park office, to which Remi consented.

At 18:00, after obtaining verbal consent to record the interview, Remi provided a free narrative account of the incident. Remi stated that while sitting on the grass talking with the suspect, the individual began touching them inappropriately. Remi immediately said, “No, stop,” but the suspect responded by laughing and dismissing the objection. Clarifying questions established the timeline of the incident between approximately 17:10 and 17:25 hours. Remi described standing up quickly, stepping away from the suspect, and walking toward the gazebo area.

Remi recalled the suspect saying, “Don’t be dramatic,” in response to the refusal, while Remi reiterated, “I said no.” Officers documented the scene by photographing the lawn area, the path leading to the gazebo, and a nearby bench. Notes were made regarding the lighting conditions, which were neutral, and the presence of several adolescents nearby, indicating a moderately populated area.

Remi reported soreness in the knee, attributed to standing up quickly during the incident. A photograph of the knee was taken with a measurement scale for documentation purposes. Emergency Medical Services (EMS) were offered but declined by Remi. The officers informed Remi of Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) options, and Remi elected to pursue a delayed medical examination. Officers provided informational materials and paper evidence bags for potential collection of personal items.

Witness information was gathered, including contact details for a witness named “Ava,” who had approached Remi shortly after the incident. For safety planning, Remi indicated plans to leave the park with a roommate. Officers provided a resource list for support services and confirmed the case number for follow-up.

Digital evidence was collected, including a screenshot of a direct message sent by the suspect on a social media application stating, “You’re overreacting.” The screenshot included the timestamp and the suspect’s handle. Additionally, a request was made to preserve CCTV footage from the park entrance camera covering the time frame of 16:45 to 17:45 hours to assist in the investigation.

Before concluding the interview at 18:55, Remi confirmed the summary of events and added identifying details about the suspect, noting that the individual wore a black beanie and had a bicycle chained nearby.

The officers ensured that Remi was aware of available resources and next steps. The investigation remains ongoing.

End of Report.  
P.O. Doyle (#3198)  
P.O. Kravitz (#2902)

Incident Report  
Case Number: 23  
Date of Incident: September 11, 2025  
Report Date: September 12, 2025  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Ebner (#2339)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Fox (#2577)  
Location: Office Park Lot C — Bay 42  
Weather Conditions: Clear, 79°F  
Time on Scene: 07:28:21 to 08:24:39  

Narrative:  
On September 12, 2025, at approximately 07:28 hours, Officers Ebner and Fox responded to a sexual assault report at Office Park Lot C, Bay 42. Upon arrival, officers met with the reporting party, identified here as “Priya,” near her sedan. After obtaining her consent to record the interview, Priya elected to remain in the lobby area rather than relocate to the conference room.

Priya provided a free narrative of the incident, stating that after work on the previous day, September 11, 2025, the suspect offered her a ride. While seated in the backseat of the suspect’s vehicle, she reported that the suspect touched her leg and hip without consent. Priya stated she verbally objected by saying “No, stop,” after which the suspect briefly ceased the contact.

Further questioning clarified the timeline and locations involved. Priya indicated that the suspect’s vehicle pulled into Bay 42 at approximately 18:22 hours, and she exited the vehicle at 18:25 hours. During the interaction, the suspect reportedly said, “Come on, it’s fine,” to which Priya responded firmly, “No. Take your hand off me.”

Officers conducted a visual inspection and photographic documentation of the backseat area of the suspect’s vehicle with Priya’s consent. No claims were made regarding the condition or cleanliness of the vehicle’s interior. Priya also disclosed the presence of a bruise forming on her body, which was photographed with a measurement scale for evidentiary purposes. Emergency Medical Services (EMS) were offered on scene; however, Priya declined immediate medical attention, opting instead to pursue a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination at a later time.

Digital evidence was collected, including a text message sent by the suspect at 19:02 hours stating, “We good?” This message was captured and preserved as part of the investigation. Additionally, a coworker witness reported seeing Priya exit the suspect’s vehicle quickly, and this contact information was logged for follow-up.

A preservation request was submitted for CCTV footage from the lot cameras covering the time frame between 18:10 and 18:40 hours to corroborate the timeline and vehicle movements. Safety planning was discussed with Priya, including providing contact information for the company’s Human Resources liaison and resources related to protective orders. Priya was also provided with the case number for reference.

Before concluding the interview at 08:24 hours, officers read back a summary of the report to Priya, who confirmed the accuracy and added that the suspect’s vehicle is a blue SUV equipped with a roof rack.

This report will be forwarded to the Sexual Assault Unit for further investigation. All evidence collected, including photographs, digital communications, and witness statements, has been logged and secured according to department protocol.

End of Report.

Narrative:

On September 13, 2025, at approximately 21:47 hours, Officers Carter (#1842) and Velasquez (#2079) responded to a call classified as a sexual assault report at 75 Willow Glen, Unit 3D. Upon arrival, the victim, identified as Keira (last name withheld for privacy), invited officers into the living room. A roommate was present at the time. Keira requested that her roommate remain in the living room during the interview, which officers confirmed and respected.

After obtaining verbal consent to record the interview and explaining trauma-informed ground rules, Keira provided a free narrative of the incident. She stated that she had invited the suspect to her residence to talk and watch a television show. Initially, the interaction was consensual, including a kiss. However, the suspect then attempted to place his hand inside her pants. Keira clearly stated that she said “No, I don’t want this,” and pushed his hand away twice. She then moved toward the door, at which point the suspect left the premises at approximately 20:15 hours.

Officers documented the scene with Keira’s consent, taking photographs of the bedroom doorway, bed, and the path leading to the living room. Care was taken to maintain the victim’s privacy by avoiding any personal documents or items in the photographs.

Keira reported no visible physical injuries but described experiencing anxiety and shaking following the incident. Emergency Medical Services (EMS) were offered but declined by Keira. She was informed about Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) options and chose to delay the medical examination. She was provided with informational materials and paper bags for potential evidence preservation.

Digital evidence was collected, including a screenshot of a text message from the suspect stating, “Did I go too far?” The message headers were documented for investigative purposes.

The roommate, who was present during the incident, confirmed hearing Keira say “No” and agreed to provide a formal statement at a later time.

Officers conducted a safety assessment, verifying that all locks were secure and that Keira’s phone emergency contacts were up to date. A resource list containing support services was provided, along with the case number for future reference.

Before concluding the interview at 22:41 hours, officers read back a summary of the report to Keira for confirmation. She confirmed the accuracy and added that the suspect was wearing a gray hoodie with paint stains at the time of the incident.

This report will be forwarded to the Sexual Assault Unit for further investigation. All evidence and statements have been logged and secured in accordance with department protocols.

End of Report.  
P.O. Carter (#1842)  
September 13, 2025

Reporting Officer: P.O. Hwang (#2984)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Cutter (#3110)  
Weather Conditions: Cloudy, 66°F

Narrative:

On September 13, 2025, at approximately 21:12 hours, Officers Hwang and Cutter responded to a report of a sexual assault at the rooftop patio of 88 Lakeview Towers. Upon arrival, building security escorted the officers to a quieter corner of the rooftop where the involved parties were located.

The complainant, identified as Monroe, requested to speak privately in the stairwell landing. Consent to record the conversation was obtained. Monroe provided a free narrative stating that while seated on a couch during a social gathering, she explicitly declined any sexual advances. Despite her verbal refusal, the suspect placed his hand up her shirt. Monroe stated she said “Stop,” but the suspect attempted the same action again. During clarification, Monroe described their seated positions and recounted the suspect’s response, which included the phrase, “Don’t be stiff.”

The officers documented the scene by photographing the couch area and the access door to the rooftop. The lighting was noted as moderate, and there was ambient noise from the crowd. Monroe displayed no visible injuries but reported feeling discomfort. Emergency Medical Services (EMS) were offered but declined by Monroe.

Monroe was informed of Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) options and elected to undergo an exam that evening. An advocate was contacted and arranged to meet Monroe at the clinic to provide support.

A witness, identified as Monroe’s friend “Rae,” reported seeing Monroe leave the gathering appearing upset. Contact information for Rae was obtained for potential follow-up.

Digital evidence was collected, including a screenshot of a Discord message sent by the suspect at 21:05 hours stating, “I thought we were vibing.” This message was preserved as part of the investigation.

Officers discussed safety planning with Monroe, including the building’s offer of an escort and explained no-contact options. Monroe was provided with the case number for reference.

Before concluding the interview, the officers read back a summary of Monroe’s statement, which she confirmed as accurate. Monroe added that the suspect was wearing a denim jacket with a band patch at the time of the incident.

The officers remained on scene until 22:08 hours, ensuring Monroe’s safety and that all pertinent information and evidence were collected.

End of Report.

On September 14, 2025, at approximately 18:05 hours, officers Sgt. Salazar and P.O. Keane responded to a call regarding a sexual assault report at the Summer Street Fair, specifically at Storage Tent L-9 in the vendor area. Upon arrival, the complainant, identified as “Nika,” requested privacy and was escorted to the command tent. Consent to record the interview was obtained.

Nika provided a free narrative account of the incident. She stated that while inside the storage tent, an individual placed his hands on her without consent. She verbally expressed her objection by saying, “Stop. Not okay.” Despite her refusal, the individual persisted and attempted to kiss her. Nika described her actions following the unwanted contact, indicating that she stepped behind a table and then exited the tent through the lane.

Officers documented the scene by photographing the interior of the tent, including boxes and the exit flap. The descriptions were factual and neutral, avoiding any assumptions regarding the condition of the area.

A medical assessment was conducted visually; no injuries were apparent. Emergency Medical Services (EMS) were offered but declined by Nika. The Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination was discussed, and Nika elected to undergo the exam that evening. An advocate was contacted to provide support.

A witness, vendor “Tess,” reported observing Nika leaving the tent visibly upset. Tess’s contact information was obtained for further follow-up.

Officers requested preservation of CCTV footage from gate cameras operated by the fair organizers, specifically covering the time frame from 17:20 to 18:00, to assist with the investigation.

Safety planning was addressed with fair staff, who agreed to adjust schedules to separate Nika and the suspect. The option to trespass the suspect from the event was explained.

During the summary review, Nika confirmed the details provided and added that the suspect was wearing a staff lanyard with the initials “RM.”

The incident report was concluded at 19:01 hours. Further investigation will continue based on the information and evidence collected.

End of report.

Narrative:

On September 15, 2025, at approximately 22:01 hours, I, P.O. Ebner, along with P.O. Fox, responded to a call regarding a sexual assault report at 52 Laurel Bistro. Upon arrival, we were directed to the manager’s office where we met with the reporting party, identified as “Camila.” After obtaining her consent to record the interview, Camila provided a free narrative of the incident.

Camila stated that after the restaurant had closed, while she was in the staff locker room, a male individual touched her chest without consent. She immediately told him, “No, stop,” and then left the area. When asked to clarify the sequence of events, Camila recounted that the suspect said to her, “Don’t be weird,” during the encounter. She described the suspect as wearing a chef’s coat with a name stitched on it, though she did not recall the exact name.

Following the interview, we proceeded to document the scene. Photographs were taken of the locker room entrance, the aisle, and posted signage. Care was taken to maintain privacy, and no images were captured of any individuals changing clothes. A visual inspection revealed no visible injuries on Camila. We explained the options for a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination, and Camila chose to delay the medical exam at this time.

We then interviewed a coworker who reported hearing a locker door slam around the time of the incident. This witness confirmed hearing a physical contact but did not see the event directly. No digital evidence such as text messages was available, as Camila and the suspect did not communicate via text.

We requested preservation of CCTV footage from the back hallway camera covering the time frame between 21:10 and 21:50 to assist with the investigation. The manager agreed to adjust Camila’s work schedule to enhance her safety and prevent further contact with the suspect. Officers provided Camila with resources for support and safety planning.

At 22:07, a summary of the report was read back to Camila, who confirmed the accuracy of the information and added the detail regarding the suspect’s chef coat. The investigation at the scene concluded at 22:58.

This report will be forwarded to the detective unit for further investigation. All evidence collected, including photographs and recorded statements, have been logged and secured.

Respectfully submitted,  
P.O. Ebner (#2339)  
52 Laurel Bistro Sexual Assault Incident  
September 15, 2025

Incident Report  
Case Number: 25-240349  
Date: September 15, 2025  
Location: 700 Grand Hotel, Room 605  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Carter (#1842)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Velasquez (#2079)  

On September 15, 2025, at approximately 21:02 hours, officers Carter and Velasquez responded to a sexual assault report at the 700 Grand Hotel, Room 605. Upon arrival, hotel security escorted the officers to the room where the complainant, identified as Lena (last name withheld for privacy), was present. Consent to record the interview was obtained from Lena prior to proceeding.

Lena provided a free narrative of the incident, stating that earlier in the evening she and the suspect had consumed drinks together at the hotel bar. Upon returning to Room 605, the suspect placed his hand inside her dress without her consent. Lena immediately told him to stop, but he attempted the same action again. When questioned about the sequence of events, Lena recalled that the suspect said, “You’re into this.” She then stood up, pointed toward the door, and the suspect left the room.

Officers documented the scene thoroughly, taking photographs of the sitting area, the door, and the lighting conditions within the room. A request was made to preserve keycard logs for the time period between 20:15 and 21:20 to verify entries and exits. Additionally, hallway CCTV footage was requested to assist in corroborating the timeline.

A medical assessment was conducted visually; no visible injuries were observed on Lena. The option of a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination was discussed, and Lena elected to proceed with the exam to ensure proper evidence collection and medical care.

Witness information was gathered from a neighboring room occupant who reported hearing voices during the relevant timeframe. Hotel security collected this information, and officers planned to follow up on this lead.

Digital evidence was also noted, including a text message from the suspect to Lena stating, “Can we talk?” This message was captured and preserved for investigative purposes.

For Lena’s safety, hotel management arranged for a room change, and officers ensured that the new room’s locks and security chain were properly engaged. Officers provided Lena with information on available resources, including counseling and victim support services.

During the summary read-back, Lena confirmed the details of her statement and added that the suspect was wearing a blue blazer adorned with a hotel event pin at the time of the incident.

The officers remained on scene until 21:58 hours, concluding the initial investigation and ensuring the complainant’s safety and well-being.

This report will be forwarded to the Sexual Assault Unit for further investigation. All evidence, including photographs, keycard logs, CCTV footage, digital communications, and witness statements, will be compiled and submitted accordingly.

End of report.  
P.O. Carter (#1842)  
P.O. Velasquez (#2079)

On September 16, 2025, at approximately 13:18 hours, Officers Doyle and Kravitz responded to a report of a sexual assault at the City Library, specifically in the Archives Room. Upon arrival, we met with the reporting party, hereafter referred to as “Wren,” in the library’s administrative office. Wren consented to have the interview recorded via body-worn cameras.

Wren provided a free narrative account of the incident, stating that while in the Archives Room, the suspect made unwanted physical contact. Wren stated, “In the archives room he touched me. I said ‘No, I don’t want that.’ He kept trying for a moment.” When asked to clarify the sequence of events, Wren recalled the suspect saying, “No one comes down here,” indicating an attempt to isolate the location.

Wren was informed of Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) options for medical and forensic evaluation but was undecided on proceeding. A witness, a library volunteer, reported seeing Wren and the suspect exit the Archives Room separately. Contact information for this witness was collected for follow-up.

Digital evidence was also documented, including an email received from the suspect apologizing for the incident. The email headers and content were preserved for investigative purposes.

Safety planning was addressed; Wren was escorted to their vehicle to ensure safe departure from the scene. A resource sheet containing support services and the case number was provided.

Before concluding the interview, Wren reviewed a summary of the report and confirmed its accuracy. Wren added that the suspect was wearing a cardigan with elbow patches during the incident.

Incident Report

Case Number: 25-240375  
Date/Time of Incident: September 16, 2025, approximately 19:20–19:55  
Location: Midtown Gym, Locker Room B Corridor  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Li (#2631)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Gomez (#2740)  
Weather: Sunny, 84°F  

On September 16, 2025, at approximately 20:01 hours, Officers Li and Gomez responded to a report of a sexual assault at the Midtown Gym, specifically in the Locker Room B corridor. Upon arrival, officers met with the victim, identified as “Tara” (name withheld for privacy), near the corridor area. The gym manager was present at the scene. Consent to record the interview was obtained from Tara, and the parties moved to a private office within the gym to ensure confidentiality during the statement.

Tara provided a free narrative of the incident, stating that while she was near the lockers, the suspect approached and cornered her. She reported verbally expressing “No, stop” to the individual. Despite her refusal, the suspect touched her waist and chest over her clothing. Tara recalled the suspect saying “Just a sec” during the encounter. She described feeling wrist soreness caused by pushing the suspect’s hand away. Photographs of the injury were taken with a scale for documentation purposes.

Officers documented the scene by photographing the corridor and the entrance to the locker area, taking care to maintain the privacy of other gym patrons. Tara declined emergency medical services at the scene but agreed to be examined later by a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE).

A witness, a gym member, was identified who reported hearing Tara say “Stop” during the incident. Contact information for the witness was obtained for potential follow-up. Officers requested preservation of CCTV footage from the gym’s hallway cameras covering the time frame from 19:20 to 19:55 to assist with the investigation.

Tara indicated that she and the suspect do not communicate via text or digital messaging, and no digital evidence was available. The gym management agreed to suspend the suspect’s access to the facility pending the outcome of the investigation to ensure Tara’s safety.

Officers provided Tara with information on available resources, including victim support services and counseling. A summary of the statement and investigative steps was read back to Tara, who confirmed its accuracy. She added that the suspect was carrying a towel with a black stripe at the time of the incident.

The officers concluded their on-scene investigation at 20:57 hours. The case remains open and under active investigation. Further follow-up will include review of CCTV footage, witness interviews, and coordination with the SANE examination results.

Respectfully submitted,  
P.O. Li (#2631)  
Midtown Police Department

Incident_Report:
On September 17, 2025, at approximately 06:11 hours, officers responded to a reported sexual assault at the 260 Depot Lofts freight corridor. The weather at the time was light rain with a temperature of 66°F. Upon arrival, Sergeant Salazar (#2081) and Police Officer Keane (#3775) met with the reporting party, identified as “Sloane,” near the freight corridor office. Sloane consented to have the interaction recorded on body-worn cameras.

Sloane provided a free narrative account of the incident, stating that while checking shipments in the freight corridor, an unidentified male approached and touched her inappropriately. She immediately told him “No, stop,” after which the suspect attempted to touch her a second time. Following this, Sloane moved to a more open area within the corridor, at which point the suspect left the scene.

Officers conducted a thorough documentation of the scene, taking photographs of the freight corridor, surrounding boxes, and the nearest exit points. The lighting conditions were noted as neutral, with no obstructions affecting visibility. A medical assessment was conducted; no visible injuries were observed on Sloane. The Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) program was explained to her as an option for further medical evaluation and evidence collection, but Sloane was undecided on whether to pursue this at that time.

Witnesses were identified and interviewed. A loader working nearby reported seeing Sloane exit the area visibly upset. Contact information for this witness was recorded for potential follow-up. Officers also requested preservation of CCTV footage from the loading dock cameras covering the timeframe of 05:30 to 06:15 hours to assist in the investigation.

Safety planning was addressed with Sloane, including possible schedule adjustments to avoid contact with the suspect and advisement regarding trespassing if the individual was determined to be a non-employee. Resources for victim support and counseling were provided.

During a summary review of the incident, Sloane confirmed the details previously given and added that the suspect was wearing a neon vest with the word “Vendor” printed on the back, which may assist in identifying the individual.

The officers concluded their on-scene investigation at 07:05 hours. The case remains open pending further investigation, including review of CCTV footage and follow-up interviews. All evidence and reports have been properly documented and submitted for continued processing.

Upon arrival, officers made contact with the reporting party, identified as “Mira,” who was located on the backyard patio. Consent to record the interview was obtained from Mira at 12:02:58.

Mira immediately objected, stating “No, stop,” and moved away from the suspect. When officers sought to clarify the sequence of events, Mira recalled the suspect saying, “Don’t be shy,” during the interaction.

Incident Report  
Case Number: 25-240489

Location: Stairwell B, 77 Redwood Office Park  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Gomez (#2740)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Li (#2631)  
Weather Conditions: Sunny, 84°F  

Narrative:  
On September 20, 2025, at approximately 17:18 hours, Officers Gomez and Li responded to a report of a sexual assault at 77 Redwood Office Park, Stairwell B. Upon arrival, we met the reporting party, identified here as “Rosa,” accompanied by building security personnel. Rosa consented to have the interaction recorded on body-worn cameras.

Rosa provided a free narrative of the incident, stating that while in the stairwell between floors, an unidentified male suspect cornered her. She reported verbally telling the suspect, “Stop, I have to go,” but he persisted in touching her arm and hip despite her objections. Rosa indicated that she exited the stairwell using the door on the third floor.

Officers documented the scene by photographing the stairwell landing, handrail, and exit door. Measurements were taken, including the height of the handrail, to assist with the investigation. Neutral notes were recorded to maintain an objective account of the environment.

A medical examination of Rosa revealed redness on her upper arm consistent with her report of unwanted touching. Photographs of the injury were taken with a scale for reference. The Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) program was discussed with Rosa, who opted for a delayed medical examination rather than an immediate one.

During the interview, a text message from the suspect to Rosa was captured on her phone, reading “We good?” This message was logged as potential evidence. Additionally, a coworker witnessed Rosa returning to her workspace visibly upset; this witness contact was documented.

CCTV footage from stairwell and corridor cameras covering the time frame of 16:45 to 17:10 was identified as relevant. Preservation of this footage was requested to assist in identifying the suspect and corroborating Rosa’s account.

Safety planning was addressed with Rosa, including providing contact information for the company’s Human Resources liaison and instructions on obtaining a protective order. Rosa was given the case number for follow-up.

Before concluding the interview at 18:13, Rosa confirmed the summary of her statement and added that the suspect was wearing a gray quarter-zip sweater at the time of the incident.

The investigation remains open pending review of CCTV footage and further leads. Rosa was advised on available resources and follow-up procedures.

End of report.  
P.O. Gomez (#2740)

Incident_Report:
On September 21, 2025, at approximately 10:14 hours, officers Sgt. Kim (#1907) and P.O. Alvarado (#2256) responded to a report of sexual assault at Office Suite 610, specifically in the phone room. The weather was clear with a temperature of 76°F. Upon arrival, officers met with the reporting party, identified as “Maya,” who was accompanied by a representative from Human Resources (HR) at her request. Maya consented to have the interaction recorded and was informed about the independent criminal process available to her.

Maya provided a free narrative account of the incident, stating that while in the phone room, the suspect touched her after she had explicitly said “no.” She recounted that the suspect said, “Don’t be like that,” during the encounter. Officers clarified the sequence of events and documented her statements verbatim. 

The scene was documented thoroughly, including photographs of the phone room door and interior. Badge logs and corridor CCTV footage were requested and preserved to assist with the investigation. Officers noted no visible injuries on Maya and discussed the option of a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination. Maya declined the medical examination but was provided with information regarding the procedure and her options.

Digital evidence was also preserved; an email apology from the suspect was secured with full headers, and an IT retention hold was requested to prevent deletion or alteration of relevant electronic communications. 

Officers identified and contacted a coworker who reported hearing the phone room door open and close quickly around the time of the incident, potentially serving as a witness. Safety planning was addressed with Maya, including a schedule change to avoid contact with the suspect. She was provided with a resource sheet containing support services and the case number for follow-up.

Before concluding the interaction at 11:12 hours, officers reviewed the summary of the report with Maya, who confirmed the details and added that the suspect was wearing a red lanyard at the time of the incident.

This report will be forwarded to the Sexual Assault Unit for further investigation. All evidence, including photographic documentation, digital communications, and witness statements, has been preserved in accordance with department protocols. Maya was advised of her rights and the ongoing investigative process. The case remains open pending further inquiry.

Transcript: [BWC — Primary: Sgt. Patel (#1876); Secondary: P.O. Ortega (#2688). Call Type: Sexual Assault Report. CAD#: 25-240561. Date: 2025-09-23. Weather: Clear, 72°F. Location: Harbor Promenade — Bench 4 near Kiosk. Time on scene: 21:03:11–22:01:27.] 21:03:11 — Bodycam activates as officers approach a lit promenade bench. “Skye,” mid-20s, sits with a jacket around her shoulders; kiosk attendant stands nearby. 21:03:26 — Introductions; clear explanation of recording and choices: “We can talk here, by the patrol car, or at the kiosk office—your choice.” Skye chooses kiosk office. 21:04:02 — Inside office, door ajar: consent to record; right to pause and to request breaks; offer of water. 21:04:28 — Free narrative prompt: “Please share what you’re able, in your own words, starting where it makes sense.” Skye: “We walked from the pier. He put his hand on me near the benches. I said, ‘No, not okay.’ He kept trying.” 21:05:21 — Reflective summary to ensure accuracy: “You said you used ‘No, not okay,’ and he continued to touch you near Bench 4.” Skye: “Yes.” 21:05:44 — Non-leading sequencing: “What happened from the time you left the pier to when you came in here?” Skye describes leaving the pier around 20:25, pausing by street musicians, sitting on Bench 4 at 20:40, consensual hugging, then his hand inside her waistband; she said “No, stop,” shifted away, he tried again while saying “Relax”; she stood and walked to kiosk at 20:47. 21:07:13 — Quotes captured verbatim: suspect said “Relax,” “You’re fine.” Skye said “No, stop,” and “I don’t want this.” 21:07:49 — Physical identifiers: about 5'11", medium build, dark baseball cap with a gull logo, navy windbreaker, jeans, white sneakers; faint citrus cologne. 21:08:31 — Medical: reports hip soreness; no visible injuries; EMS offered; Skye declines transport; officer documents her choice without judgment. 21:09:12 — Evidence options: explain SANE exam availability, cost-free, advocate support, blind kit option, typical timeframes up to five days. Skye requests exam tonight; dispatch notifies on-call SANE; advocate looped in via hotline on speaker with Skye’s consent. 21:10:42 — Scene documentation: With kiosk manager’s consent, Patel photographs Bench 4 (overview/mid/close), path lighting, and proximity to musician area; includes a north arrow in one photo for orientation. 21:11:58 — CCTV prospects: City camera at lamppost 12; request for preservation 20:15–21:00 submitted via dispatch; kiosk has a dome camera pointed toward the walkway; manager agrees to export upon IT approval; officers email preservation letter on camera. 21:13:22 — Witnesses: Kiosk attendant reports Skye arrived tearful around 20:50; musician “Carla” may have seen the pair; officers collect Carla’s contact from a flyer and leave a card in her tip jar with permission. 21:14:51 — Digital: Skye does not know suspect’s last name; met through a mutual friend “Evan” at a group hang earlier; Skye shows group chat with first name and profile photo; officers capture screenshots with timestamps and visible handles; note that further identification may require consent-based download or warrant. 21:16:29 — Trauma-informed pacing: Pause offered when Skye becomes tearful; Patel normalizes responses: “It’s common to feel shaken. We’ll go at your pace.” 21:17:12 — Clarify exit mechanics: “What helped you end the interaction?” Skye: “Standing up and saying ‘I’m leaving now.’” 21:17:42 — Environmental notes: Street performance drumbeat audible; lighting moderate; a tree partially obstructs lamppost camera angle; documented as potential limitation. 21:18:34 — Safety planning: Arrange transport to clinic; friend “Jules” en route to meet Skye; discuss protective order options if suspect identity confirmed; provide resource packet and case number. 21:19:56 — Summary read back, using Skye’s words: consensual hugging followed by non-consensual touching; her explicit verbal refusals; his statements; her physical actions to disengage; timeline 20:25–20:50; locations identified. Skye confirms; adds suspect wore a woven bracelet with blue thread on right wrist. 21:21:38 — Chain-of-custody prep: paper bags and labels available if Skye chooses to submit clothing post-exam; reiterate no obligation to proceed criminally to have evidence collected. 21:22:31 — Officers coordinate clinic arrival with advocate; kiosk provides a private exit to reduce crowd exposure. 21:24:05 — Follow-up tasks logged: pull lamppost cam; identify “Evan” and group chat members; re-contact musician Carla; check nearby rideshare pickup cam between 20:45–21:00. 21:58:12 — Officers clear after Skye departs safely with advocate; tone remains neutral; no leading questions; no credibility commentary. 22:01:27 — End of BWC.
Incident_Report:
Incident Report

Case Number: 25-240561  
Date/Time of Incident: September 23, 2025, approximately 20:25 to 20:50  
Location: Harbor Promenade, Bench 4 near Kiosk  
Reporting Officer: Sgt. Patel (#1876) and P.O. Ortega (#2688)  
Weather Conditions: Clear, 72°F  

Narrative:

On September 23, 2025, at approximately 21:03 hours, officers Sgt. Patel and P.O. Ortega responded to a call reporting a sexual assault at the Harbor Promenade, specifically near Bench 4 adjacent to the kiosk. Upon arrival, officers located the reporting party, identified as Skye, a female in her mid-20s, seated on the bench with a jacket draped over her shoulders. A kiosk attendant was present nearby.

After introductions and explanation of recording procedures, Skye elected to move to the kiosk office for privacy and to provide her statement. Officers ensured informed consent for recording, explained her rights including the ability to pause or request breaks, and offered water. The interview was conducted in a trauma-informed manner, with officers normalizing emotional responses and pacing the conversation according to Skye’s comfort.

Skye provided a free narrative account beginning with her and the suspect walking from the pier at approximately 20:25. They paused briefly near street musicians before sitting on Bench 4 around 20:40. She described initially consensual hugging, which escalated when the suspect placed his hand inside her waistband without consent. Skye verbally objected multiple times, stating “No, stop,” and “I don’t want this,” but the suspect persisted, telling her to “Relax” and “You’re fine.” Skye physically shifted away and ultimately stood up, declaring “I’m leaving now,” and proceeded to the kiosk at approximately 20:47.

Physical description of the suspect was documented: approximately 5 feet 11 inches tall, medium build, wearing a dark baseball cap with a gull logo, navy windbreaker, jeans, white sneakers, and faint citrus cologne. Skye also noted the suspect wore a woven bracelet with blue thread on his right wrist.

Skye reported soreness in her hip area but no visible injuries. Emergency Medical Services were offered but declined. Officers informed Skye of the availability of a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) exam, which is cost-free and includes advocate support. Skye requested the exam that evening. Dispatch was notified, and an advocate was connected via hotline with Skye’s consent.

Scene documentation included photographs of Bench 4 from multiple angles, path lighting, and proximity to the musician area. A north arrow was included for orientation. Officers submitted a request for preservation of city CCTV footage from lamppost camera 12 covering 20:15 to 21:00 and coordinated with the kiosk manager to secure footage from the kiosk’s dome camera.

Witness information was collected from the kiosk attendant, who reported Skye arrived tearful around 20:50. A street musician named Carla, who may have observed the interaction, was identified via contact information on a flyer. Officers left a business card in Carla’s tip jar with permission for future contact.

Digital evidence was partially obtained through screenshots of a group chat where Skye identified the suspect by first name and profile photo. Further identification efforts, including identifying “Evan,” the mutual friend through whom Skye met the suspect, were noted as follow-up tasks.

Environmental conditions were documented: moderate lighting, audible street performance drumbeats, and a tree partially obstructing the lamppost camera’s view, noted as a potential limitation for video evidence.

Safety planning was conducted, including arranging transport to the clinic where Skye’s friend “Jules” was en route to meet her. Protective order options were discussed contingent on suspect identification. A resource packet and case number were provided.

Officers prepared chain-of-custody materials for potential evidence collection, including paper bags and labels, emphasizing that Skye was under no obligation to proceed criminally to have evidence collected.

Follow-up tasks logged included retrieval of CCTV footage, identification of “Evan” and group chat members, re-contacting witness Carla, and reviewing nearby rideshare pickup cameras between 20:45 and 21:00.

At 21:58 hours, officers cleared the scene after ensuring Skye departed safely with the advocate. Throughout the interaction, officers maintained a neutral tone, avoided leading questions, and refrained from commenting on credibility.

End of report.

Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case Number: 37  
Date: September 23, 2025  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Li (#2631)  
Secondary Officer: P.O. Gomez (#2740)  
Location: City Transit Hub — Parking Level 2 Stairwell  
Time on Scene: 07:18:25 – 08:15:59  
Weather: Overcast, 66°F  

On September 23, 2025, at approximately 07:18 hours, Officers Li and Gomez responded to a sexual assault report at the City Transit Hub, Parking Level 2 stairwell. Upon arrival, officers met with the reporting party, identified as “Rosa,” near the stairwell door. Building security personnel were present at the scene.

After obtaining Rosa’s consent to record the interview, officers offered three locations for the statement: the stairwell office, the security control room, or the patrol vehicle. Rosa elected to proceed in the security control room. The interview was conducted in a trauma-informed manner, with officers pacing the conversation slowly, avoiding interruptions, and validating Rosa’s experience.

Rosa provided a free narrative account of the incident, stating that between Levels 2 and 3 of the stairwell, an unidentified male individual touched her hip and chest over her coat. Rosa immediately told the individual, “No, stop.” The male briefly blocked her path at the landing, during which Rosa said, “I have to get to work” and “Move, please.” The male responded, “Come on, we’ve joked before.” Rosa then exited through the Level 2 door at approximately 07:03 to 07:05.

Officers documented the scene with the assistance of building security. Photographs were taken of Landing 2.5, the handrail, the door to Level 2, and the positions of surveillance camera domes. Measurements of the handrail height and landing width were recorded to provide context for the incident location.

A physical examination of Rosa revealed redness on her upper arm. Rosa consented to photographs of the injury with a scale for documentation purposes. Emergency Medical Services were offered but declined; Rosa preferred to visit a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) clinic later that day. Officers provided Rosa with written guidance regarding the exam window and the availability of a forensic evidence collection kit (blind kit).

Building security confirmed the presence of surveillance cameras covering the Level 2 stairwell and corridor. A preservation request was placed for footage from 06:45 to 07:30. Control room personnel exported thumbnail images to verify coverage, noting potential glare from an open-air vent that might affect image clarity.

A witness, identified as “Dev,” a commuter, reported seeing Rosa exit the corridor appearing upset at approximately 07:05. Contact information was obtained, and a follow-up interview was scheduled.

Digital evidence was also collected. Rosa received a Microsoft Teams message at 07:40 from the suspected individual stating, “We good?” A screenshot of the message, including profile and timestamp, was captured. Rosa consented to provide her device for forensic examination if necessary. Officers noted that employer IT could place a legal hold on relevant communications.

Safety planning was discussed, and a transit escort plan was arranged for Rosa for the next several days. Officers offered to connect Rosa with her workplace Human Resources department should she desire administrative separation. Resource and rights information sheets were provided.

Language was confirmed as English, and no interpreter was required. A summary of Rosa’s account was read back to her, including the physical description of the suspect: approximately 5'9" tall, wearing a gray quarter-zip sweater, a red lanyard, and a smartwatch with a green band. Rosa confirmed the accuracy of these details.

Officers prepared for chain-of-custody procedures, explaining that Rosa could submit her outerwear for evidence collection after her medical exam, with full control over evidence decisions.

Follow-up tasks were identified, including obtaining surveillance exports, interviewing the witness Dev, requesting IT retention of digital communications, and scheduling a formal statement at Rosa’s convenience.

The incident report concludes with the officers leaving the scene at 08:15 hours. All evidence and documentation were secured per department protocol. The case remains open pending further investigation.

Location: City Library — Reading Nook A. Time on scene: 12:58:06–13:56:50.] 12:58:06 — Officers meet “Elise” with librarian “Marta”; Elise requests privacy in study room; consent to record obtained; librarian steps out. 12:58:38 — Free narrative: “We were reviewing notes. He closed the door and touched me. I said, ‘No, I don’t want that.’ I moved his hand and stood up.” 12:59:27 — Clarify sequence with open prompts: “What words did you use? What did he say?” Elise: “I said ‘Stop’ and ‘No.’ He said ‘Come on, it’s just us.’” 13:00:22 — Scene documentation: photos of door, chair positions, desk, and a chair Elise placed under handle after he left; Hwang documents which positions are post-incident to avoid confusion. 13:01:44 — Medical: no visible injuries; Elise reports elevated anxiety; EMS offered; she prefers to speak to advocate and consider SANE later; info and timelines provided. 13:02:51 — Digital: suspect texted “Sorry if I pushed boundaries”; screenshot captured with timestamp; Elise consents to provide device later for forensic imaging if she chooses. 13:03:49 — Witnesses: Student “Jon” knocked at 12:40; contact gathered; full interview to be scheduled. 13:04:31 — CCTV prospects: corridor camera outside Reading Nook A; preservation requested 12:10–12:55; librarian notes 14-day retention; request logged same-day. 13:05:36 — Sensory details: Elise recalls peppermint gum and a small scar on suspect’s left eyebrow. 13:06:15 — Safety planning: Offer escort to exit; Elise accepts; discuss no-contact order options and library trespass procedures. 13:07:08 — Trauma-informed pacing and language: “You are in control of what you share. We can pause at any time.” Elise pauses twice; officers wait silently and resume only on her cue. 13:08:14 — Summary read back using Elise’s phrasing; confirmation received; addendum: suspect wore a navy hoodie with white drawstrings. 13:09:23 — Follow-up tasks: obtain CCTV, schedule detailed interview later in quiet setting, coordinate with advocate. 13:56:50 — End.
Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case Number: 38  
Date/Time of Incident: September 24, 2025, approximately 12:40 PM  
Location: City Library — Reading Nook A  
Reporting Officers: P.O. Hwang (#2984), P.O. Cutter (#3110)  
Weather: Cloudy, 68°F  

On September 24, 2025, at approximately 12:58 PM, Officers Hwang and Cutter responded to a report of a sexual assault at the City Library, specifically in Reading Nook A. Upon arrival, officers met with the reporting party, identified here as “Elise,” who was accompanied by librarian Marta. Elise requested privacy and consented to move to a study room to provide her statement. Librarian Marta exited the room to ensure privacy, and consent to record the interview was obtained from Elise.

Elise provided a free narrative of the incident, stating that she and the suspect had been reviewing notes when the suspect closed the door and touched her inappropriately. Elise stated she verbally objected by saying “No, I don’t want that,” moved his hand away, and stood up. When officers sought clarification on the exact words exchanged, Elise reported that she said “Stop” and “No,” to which the suspect responded, “Come on, it’s just us.”

Officers documented the scene by photographing the door, chair positions, desk, and a chair Elise had placed under the door handle after the suspect left, noting which positions were post-incident to avoid confusion. Elise reported no visible physical injuries but indicated elevated anxiety. Emergency Medical Services (EMS) were offered but declined, as Elise preferred to speak with an advocate first and consider a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination later. Officers provided information regarding timelines and available resources.

Digital evidence was noted when Elise disclosed that the suspect had sent a text message stating, “Sorry if I pushed boundaries.” A screenshot of this message was captured with a timestamp. Elise consented to provide her device later for forensic imaging if she chose to proceed.

A potential witness, a student named Jon, was identified; he reportedly knocked on the door at approximately 12:40 PM. Contact information was collected, and a full interview was scheduled for a later time. Officers also requested preservation of CCTV footage from the corridor camera outside Reading Nook A, covering the time frame from 12:10 PM to 12:55 PM. The librarian confirmed that footage is retained for 14 days, and a preservation request was logged the same day.

Elise recalled sensory details about the suspect, including the scent of peppermint gum and a small scar on his left eyebrow. Safety planning was discussed, and Elise accepted an escort to exit the library. Officers explained options for no-contact orders and library trespass procedures.

Throughout the interview, officers employed trauma-informed practices, allowing Elise to control the pace and content of her disclosure. Elise paused twice during the interview; officers waited silently and resumed questioning only upon her indication. A summary of the statement was read back to Elise using her own phrasing, which she confirmed as accurate. An addendum noted that the suspect was wearing a navy hoodie with white drawstrings.

Follow-up tasks were outlined, including obtaining the CCTV footage, scheduling a detailed interview in a quieter setting, and coordinating with a victim advocate. The interview concluded at 1:56 PM.

This report will be forwarded to the investigative unit for further action. All evidence and statements have been documented and secured according to department protocols.

Reporting Officer:  
P.O. Hwang (#2984)  
Date: September 24, 2025

Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case Number: 39  
Date: September 24, 2025  
Location: Community Pool — Staff Office and Locker A Area  
Reporting Officer: Sgt. Kim (#1907)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Alvarado (#2256)  

On September 24, 2025, at approximately 17:06 hours, officers responded to the Community Pool following a report of a sexual assault. Upon arrival, officers made contact with the reporting party, identified as “Tara,” a lifeguard at the facility. Tara requested that her manager step outside to speak privately with officers. Consent to record the interview was obtained from Tara.

Tara provided a free narrative account of the incident. She stated that after she had clocked out from her shift, an individual followed her into Locker A. While inside the locker area, the suspect touched her chest over her swimsuit without consent. Tara immediately told the individual to stop, stating, “Stop, not okay.” When questioned about the suspect’s response, Tara recalled the suspect saying, “Don’t be tense.” The officers documented these statements verbatim.

To preserve the integrity of the scene and respect privacy, officers photographed only the corridor leading to Locker A, the door to the locker, and the restricted access sign posted nearby. Ambient noise and lighting conditions were noted for the record.

Tara reported experiencing soreness in her wrist, which was photographed with a measurement scale for documentation purposes. Emergency Medical Services (EMS) were offered on scene; however, Tara elected to undergo a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination later that evening. An advocate was contacted to provide support.

Officers identified a potential witness, a coworker named Neil, who may have overheard Tara’s verbal objection (“Stop”) during the incident. Contact information for Neil was recorded for follow-up.

Access logs from the badge reader outside Locker A were requested and preserved for the time frame between 16:20 and 16:50 to assist in identifying the suspect and corroborating the timeline.

A safety plan was discussed with Tara, including adjustments to her work schedule to avoid contact with the suspect. Information regarding the issuance of a no-contact order was provided. The manager confirmed the facility’s anti-retaliation policy to ensure Tara’s protection from any adverse actions.

Before concluding the interview, officers read back a summary of Tara’s statement for accuracy. Tara confirmed the details and added that the suspect was wearing a red team parka and had a whistle lanyard at the time of the incident.

The interview and scene documentation concluded at 18:03 hours. All evidence and statements were secured for further investigation.

End of Report.

Transcript: [BWC — Primary: P.O. Doyle (#3198); Secondary: P.O. Kravitz (#2902). Call Type: Sexual Assault Report. CAD#: 25-240612. Date: 2025-09-25. Weather: Clear, 77°F. Take me home.’” 07:26:11 — Clarify sequence of drive, parking, and her exit; quotes documented; suspect said “We’re just having fun.” 07:27:02 — Vehicle documentation with consent: photos of backseat seating, door handles, and child lock switch; neutral description; no claims about “disturbance.” 07:28:19 — Medical: bruise forming on thigh; Noor consents to photos with scale; EMS offered; she opts for SANE later today. 07:29:11 — Digital: text “Sorry if I crossed a line” captured; Noor consents to later device imaging if she chooses. 07:29:49 — Witnesses: Neighbor saw her arrive upset; contact captured. 07:30:22 — CCTV: garage entry/exit and Bay 19 camera; preservation request 18:05–18:45 previous day; property management alerted by email. 07:31:37 — Safety planning: workplace liaison, protective order info; resource packet and case number provided. 07:32:24 — Summary read back; Noor confirms; adds suspect briefly activated child locks; she tried handle twice before exiting; detail documented precisely. 08:23:18 — End.
Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case Number: 25-240612  
Date/Time of Report: September 25, 2025, 07:24–08:23 hours  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Doyle (#3198)  
Secondary Officer: P.O. Kravitz (#2902)  
Location: Midtown Garage, Bay 19, Lot C  

On September 25, 2025, at approximately 07:24 hours, Officers Doyle and Kravitz responded to a call classified as a Sexual Assault Report at Midtown Garage, Bay 19. Upon arrival, we met with the reporting party, identified as Noor (last name withheld for privacy), near her vehicle parked in Lot C. Noor consented to the interview being recorded and was offered the option to conduct the interview in the security office for comfort; she elected to sit on a shaded bench adjacent to the vehicle.

Noor provided a free narrative of the incident, stating that on the previous day after work, while seated in the backseat of a vehicle driven by the suspect, he touched her thigh and attempted to lift her skirt without her consent. Noor stated she verbally objected, saying, “No, stop. Take me home.” She described the suspect’s response as, “We’re just having fun.” Noor detailed the sequence of events, including the drive to the garage, parking, and her attempts to exit the vehicle.

With Noor’s consent, officers conducted a thorough documentation of the vehicle’s interior and exterior, including photographs of the backseat seating area, door handles, and the child lock switch. The documentation was neutral and factual, with no indications of disturbance noted at the time of inspection. Noor reported that the suspect briefly activated the child locks, which she attempted to disengage twice before successfully exiting the vehicle.

A physical examination revealed a bruise forming on Noor’s thigh consistent with her account. She consented to photographic documentation of the injury using a scale for reference. Emergency Medical Services were offered on scene; however, Noor declined immediate medical attention, opting instead to undergo a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination later that day.

Digital evidence was also collected with Noor’s consent. A text message from the suspect stating, “Sorry if I crossed a line,” was captured. Noor agreed to allow imaging of her device at a later time should she choose to proceed with further digital evidence collection.

Witness information was obtained from a neighbor who observed Noor arriving at the location visibly upset. Contact information for the witness was recorded for potential follow-up.

Surveillance footage from the garage’s CCTV system was requested and preserved, covering the timeframe from 18:05 to 18:45 on the previous day. Property management was notified via email to ensure retention of relevant video evidence.

Officers provided Noor with safety planning resources, including contact information for her workplace liaison and details regarding protective orders. A resource packet and the case number were given to Noor for her reference.

The summary of the interview and evidence collection was read back to Noor, who confirmed the accuracy of the report and added clarifying details regarding the child lock activation and her attempts to exit the vehicle.

The investigation remains open pending further follow-up, including the SANE examination and potential digital evidence analysis.

End of report.  
P.O. Doyle (#3198)  
P.O. Kravitz (#2902)

I said I didn’t want sex. He touched me under my shirt. I said ‘No, stop,’ and opened the door.” 18:09:49 — Clarify sequence; quotes captured; suspect said “Don’t be like that.” 18:10:28 — Scene documentation: photos of bedroom doorway, couch position, and path to hall; privacy maintained; officers angle cameras down when others pass. 18:11:19 — Medical: none visible; Piper reports anxiety; SANE discussed; she prefers delayed exam; paper bags provided in case she later submits clothing. 18:12:17 — Digital: message “Can we talk?” preserved; screenshot with timestamp captured. 18:12:46 — Witnesses: roommate heard “No” and saw suspect leave quickly; contact obtained. 18:13:19 — Safety: campus no-trespass option explained; victim services connected; case number provided. 18:13:54 — Summary read back; Piper confirms; adds suspect wore a plaid shirt and smelled of cigarette smoke. 19:05:40 — End.

Incident Report

Case Number: 25-240624  
Date of Incident: September 25, 2025  
Location: Campus Housing, Room 3B Lounge  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Carter (#1842)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Velasquez (#2079)  
Weather Conditions: Overcast, 71°F  
Time on Scene: 18:08:32 to 19:05:40

Narrative:

On September 25, 2025, at approximately 18:08 hours, Officers Carter and Velasquez responded to a call regarding a sexual assault report at the campus housing complex, specifically Room 3B Lounge. Upon arrival, officers made contact with the reporting party, identified as “Piper,” who was accompanied by her roommates. Piper requested to speak privately in the lounge area, and consent to record the interview was obtained.

Piper provided a free narrative of the incident, stating that she and the suspect had been watching a movie in her room when the suspect touched her under her shirt despite her verbal refusal. She explicitly stated, “I said I didn’t want sex,” and when the suspect continued, she said “No, stop,” and opened the door to end the interaction. Officers clarified the sequence of events, during which Piper recounted the suspect’s response as “Don’t be like that.”

The officers documented the scene by photographing the bedroom doorway, the position of the couch, and the path leading to the hallway to preserve the physical context of the incident. Privacy was maintained throughout the process; officers angled their cameras downward when other individuals passed through the area.

A medical assessment was conducted visually; no physical injuries were observed. Piper reported experiencing anxiety related to the incident. The Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) exam was discussed with Piper, who expressed a preference to delay the medical examination at this time. Paper bags were provided for the preservation of any clothing she might later submit as evidence.

Digital evidence was preserved, including a message from the suspect stating, “Can we talk?” A screenshot with a timestamp was captured for investigative purposes.

Roommates who were present during the incident were interviewed. One roommate reported hearing Piper say “No” and observed the suspect leaving the room quickly. Contact information for the witness was obtained for follow-up.

Officers explained the campus no-trespass option to Piper and connected her with victim services for ongoing support. The case number was provided to Piper for reference.

Before concluding the interview at 19:05 hours, a summary of the report was read back to Piper for confirmation. She affirmed the accuracy of the account and added that the suspect was wearing a plaid shirt and smelled of cigarette smoke.

The investigation remains open pending further evidence collection and follow-up interviews.

End of Report.  
P.O. Carter (#1842)  
P.O. Velasquez (#2079)

Transcript: [BWC — Primary: Sgt. Salazar (#2081); Secondary: P.O. Keane (#3775). Call Type: Sexual Assault Report. CAD#: 25-240637. Date: 2025-09-26. Weather: Mild, 73°F. Location: Lakeside Park — Boat Dock Bench. I said I didn’t want anything sexual. He touched me anyway. I said ‘No, stop.’” 16:57:38 — Clarify sequence; quotes documented; she said “Let me go” when he held her waist; he said “Just a sec.” 16:58:35 — Scene documentation: photos of dock, bench, and path lighting; note water sound may affect camera audio. 16:59:22 — Medical: minor redness; photo with scale; SANE chosen; transport and advocate arranged. 17:00:14 — Witness potential: fisherman “Ari” may have been nearby; contact through marina office; card left at community board. 17:00:56 — Digital: text “I misread” preserved. 17:01:19 — CCTV: parking cameras; preservation 22:10–23:00; ranger staff cooperative. 17:02:06 — Safety planning: friend pickup; restraining order info; resource sheet. 17:02:42 — Summary read back; Hannah confirms; adds suspect wore a gray crewneck and boat shoes. 17:54:47 — End.
Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case Number: 42  
Date/Time of Report: September 26, 2025, 16:56–17:54  
Reporting Officer: Sgt. Salazar (#2081)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Keane (#3775)  
Location: Lakeside Park — Boat Dock Bench  

On September 26, 2025, at approximately 16:56 hours, Sgt. Salazar and P.O. Keane responded to a sexual assault report at Lakeside Park, specifically near the boat dock bench area. Upon arrival, officers met with the reporting party, identified as “Hannah” for confidentiality purposes. Hannah consented to have the interaction recorded via body-worn cameras. Due to ambient noise near the dock, officers and Hannah relocated to the nearby ranger office to conduct a quieter and more private interview.

Hannah provided a free narrative account of the incident, stating that the previous evening she had been sitting on the dock with the suspect. She explicitly communicated that she did not want any sexual contact. Despite her clear refusal, the suspect proceeded to touch her inappropriately. Hannah recalled verbally telling the suspect “No, stop,” and when he held her waist, she said “Let me go,” to which the suspect responded, “Just a sec.” These direct quotes were documented verbatim during the interview.

Officers conducted a thorough scene documentation, taking photographs of the dock, bench, and surrounding path lighting. It was noted that the ambient sound of water could potentially interfere with audio recordings captured by body-worn cameras. A medical examination revealed minor redness consistent with the reported contact; photographs of the injury were taken with a measurement scale for evidentiary purposes. Hannah opted for a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination, and arrangements were made for her transport to the medical facility as well as for an advocate to accompany her.

Potential witnesses were identified, including a fisherman known as “Ari,” who may have been present near the scene at the time of the incident. Officers attempted to contact Ari through the marina office and left a business card on the community board to facilitate further communication. Digital evidence was preserved, including a text message from the suspect stating, “I misread,” which may pertain to the incident. Additionally, parking lot CCTV footage covering the timeframe of 22:10 to 23:00 was preserved with cooperation from ranger staff.

Safety planning was discussed with Hannah, including arrangements for a friend to pick her up and information regarding restraining orders and available community resources. During the summary read-back, Hannah confirmed the accuracy of the report and added a description of the suspect’s clothing, noting he wore a gray crewneck sweatshirt and boat shoes.

The interview and evidence collection concluded at approximately 17:54 hours. All information has been documented and forwarded to the investigative unit for further action. The victim has been provided with appropriate support and resources.

End of report.  
Sgt. Salazar (#2081)
