I said ‘No, stop.’ I left.” 22:01:51 — Clarify sequence and quotes; suspect said “Don’t be weird.” 22:02:21 — Scene documentation: photos of corridor, locker entrance, and camera placement; privacy maintained; avoid filming other staff changing. 22:03:19 — Medical: none visible; SANE options explained; Camila chooses delayed exam; info provided. 22:03:58 — Witness: coworker heard locker door slam; contact recorded. 22:04:27 — CCTV: back hallway camera; preservation 21:00–21:50 requested. 22:04:57 — Safety planning: schedule separation; resource sheet; case number. 22:05:25 — Summary read back; Camila confirms; adds suspect wore a chef coat with name stitched. 22:58:55 — End.
Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case Number: 25-240651  
Date/Time of Report: September 26, 2025, 22:00–22:58  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Ebner (#2339)  
Secondary Officer: P.O. Fox (#2577)  
Location: Restaurant Staff Locker Room Corridor  
Weather: Cloudy, 69°F  

On September 26, 2025, at approximately 22:00 hours, Officers Ebner and Fox responded to a call regarding a sexual assault report at a local restaurant. Upon arrival, we met with the reporting party, identified as Camila (last name withheld for privacy), in the manager’s office. Camila consented to have the interaction recorded on body-worn cameras. At her request, the manager exited the room to allow for a private interview.

Camila provided a free narrative of the incident. She stated that after the restaurant had closed, while in the locker room hallway, a male coworker touched her chest over her shirt without consent. She immediately told him, “No, stop,” and then left the area. When asked to clarify the sequence of events, Camila recalled that the suspect responded by saying, “Don’t be weird.” She further described the suspect as wearing a chef’s coat with his name stitched on it.

Following the interview, officers documented the scene by taking photographs of the corridor, the entrance to the locker room, and the placement of security cameras in the area. Care was taken to maintain privacy and avoid capturing images of other staff members who might have been changing at the time.

A medical assessment was conducted visually; no visible injuries were noted on Camila. She was informed about the option of a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) exam, including the possibility of a delayed exam. Camila chose to delay the exam and was provided with information on how to access medical and forensic services at a later time.

A coworker who was identified as a potential witness reported hearing a locker door slam around the time of the incident. Contact information for this witness was recorded for follow-up.

Officers requested preservation of CCTV footage from the back hallway camera covering the timeframe between 21:00 and 21:50 to assist with the investigation.

Safety planning was discussed with Camila, including the possibility of schedule separation from the suspect to prevent further contact. She was provided with a resource sheet containing support services and was given the case number for reference.

At the conclusion of the interview, the summary of the report was read back to Camila, who confirmed its accuracy and added the detail regarding the suspect’s attire.

The officers remained on scene until 22:58, ensuring all necessary documentation and evidence preservation steps were completed. The case remains open pending further investigation.

End of report.  
P.O. Ebner (#2339)  
P.O. Fox (#2577)

Time on scene: 21:04:29–22:02:18.] 21:04:29 — Security escorts officers to room; “Mae” present with friend; consent to record; friend remains per Mae’s request. 21:04:56 — Free narrative: “We kissed. I said no to more. He put his hand inside my dress. I said ‘No, stop.’ He tried again once before leaving.” 21:05:46 — Clarify sequence; quotes documented: he said “You’re into this”; she stood and pointed to the door. 21:06:33 — Scene documentation: photos of seating area, door, and lighting; keycard logs and hallway CCTV preservation requested 20:30–21:20. 21:07:31 — Medical: none visible; SANE discussed; Mae undecided; given info and paper bags for clothing if she chooses exam later. 21:08:22 — Digital: message “Can we talk?” captured; headers photographed. 21:08:53 — Witness: neighbor in 1223 heard voices; security provides contact; follow-up planned. 21:09:24 — Safety planning: hotel offers room change; officers confirm Mae understands locking mechanisms; resources and case number provided. 21:10:09 — Summary read back; Mae confirms; adds suspect wore a navy blazer with a conference pin. 22:02:18 — End.
Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case Number: 25-240664  
Date/Time of Incident: September 27, 2025, approximately 20:30–21:20  
Location: 700 Grand Hotel, Room 1221  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Carter (#1842)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Velasquez (#2079)  

On September 27, 2025, at approximately 21:04 hours, officers were dispatched to the 700 Grand Hotel in response to a sexual assault report. Upon arrival, security personnel escorted officers to Room 1221, where the victim, identified as Mae, was present along with a friend who remained at Mae’s request. Consent to record the interview was obtained from Mae.

Mae provided a free narrative account of the incident. She stated that she and the suspect kissed, but when she declined further advances, the suspect put his hand inside her dress. Mae verbally expressed “No, stop,” and the suspect attempted the same action once more before leaving the room. When officers sought to clarify the sequence of events, Mae recalled the suspect saying, “You’re into this,” to which she responded by standing and pointing toward the door, indicating her desire for him to leave.

Officers documented the scene by photographing the seating area, the door, and the lighting conditions within the room. Additionally, keycard access logs and hallway CCTV footage covering the timeframe from 20:30 to 21:20 were requested for preservation to assist in the investigation.

A medical examination was discussed with Mae. No visible injuries were observed at the time of the interview. Mae was informed about the option of a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) exam but was undecided. She was provided with informational materials and paper bags to preserve any clothing should she choose to undergo the exam at a later time.

Digital evidence was also collected. Officers photographed a message on Mae’s phone that read, “Can we talk?” including the message headers, which may be relevant to the investigation.

A witness, a neighbor residing in Room 1223, reportedly heard voices during the incident timeframe. Security personnel provided contact information for the witness, and a follow-up interview is planned.

Hotel staff offered Mae a room change for her safety. Officers confirmed that Mae understood the locking mechanisms of the new room and provided her with resources, including the case number for reference.

Before concluding the interview at 22:02 hours, the summary of the report was read back to Mae, who confirmed the accuracy of the information. She added that the suspect was wearing a navy blazer with a conference pin at the time of the incident.

The investigation remains active. Follow-up actions include reviewing keycard logs, CCTV footage, and interviewing the witness. Mae has been provided with support resources and advised on her options moving forward.

Report prepared by:  
P.O. Carter (#1842)  
Date: September 27, 2025

Incident Report  
Case Number: 25-240678  
Date: September 27, 2025  
Location: City Library — Archives Room  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Doyle (#3198)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Kravitz (#2902)  
Weather: Overcast, 68°F  
Time on Scene: 13:15 to 14:12  

On September 27, 2025, at approximately 13:15 hours, Officers Doyle and Kravitz responded to a call regarding a sexual assault report at the City Library, specifically in the Archives Room. Upon arrival, officers met with the reporting party, identified as “Wren,” in the administrative office. Consent to record the interview was obtained.

Wren provided a free narrative account of the incident, stating that while in the Archives Room, an individual touched them inappropriately. Wren stated, “In archives he touched me. I said ‘No, I don’t want that.’ He said ‘No one comes down here.’ I left.” Officers clarified the sequence of events and documented precise quotes. Wren described repositioning toward the door in an attempt to leave the area.

Officers proceeded to document the scene, taking photographs of the Archives Room door, desk, and chair. The librarian on duty preserved the sign-in log for the time period between 12:30 and 13:00 hours for further investigation.

A medical examination was discussed with Wren. No visible injuries were noted at the time of the interview. The Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) service was offered and explained; however, Wren was undecided about proceeding with a medical examination. Information regarding medical and counseling resources was provided.

Witness information was collected from a volunteer who reported seeing Wren and the suspect exit the Archives Room separately. Contact information for the witness was obtained for follow-up.

Digital evidence was also addressed. Officers preserved the header of an email containing an apology from the suspect. A request for a legal hold on relevant IT records was submitted to the library’s IT department.

For safety, officers escorted Wren to their vehicle upon completion of the interview. Wren was provided with resource information and the case number for reference.

Before concluding the interview, the summary of the report was read back to Wren for confirmation. Wren confirmed the details and added that the suspect was wearing a cardigan with elbow patches.

The investigation remains open pending further follow-up with witnesses, digital evidence analysis, and potential medical examination. All evidence and statements have been documented and secured in accordance with department protocols.

End of report.  
Reported by: P.O. Doyle (#3198)  
Assisted by: P.O. Kravitz (#2902)

Incident Report

Case Number: 25-240691  
Date of Incident: September 28, 2025  
Location: Midtown Gym — Corridor to Locker B  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Li (#2631)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Gomez (#2740)  
Weather Conditions: Sunny, 84°F  
Time on Scene: 20:03 to 21:02

Narrative:

On September 28, 2025, at approximately 20:03 hours, Officers Li (#2631) and Gomez (#2740) responded to a sexual assault report at Midtown Gym, located in the corridor leading to Locker B. Upon arrival, the officers met with the reporting party, identified as “Tara,” at the front desk. The gym manager escorted Tara to a private office to ensure confidentiality and safety. Consent to record the interview was obtained from Tara prior to beginning the statement.

Tara provided a free narrative account of the incident, stating that while near the lockers, an unidentified male individual touched her inappropriately despite her verbal refusal. She stated, “Near the lockers he touched me even though I said no. I said ‘Stop’ and moved his hand.” Officers clarified the sequence of events, during which Tara recalled the suspect saying, “Just a sec,” before the contact occurred.

The officers documented the scene by photographing the corridor and entrance area, taking care to maintain privacy and avoid capturing any unrelated individuals. Tara reported soreness in her wrist, which was photographed with a scale for evidentiary purposes. Emergency Medical Services (EMS) were offered on scene; however, Tara opted for a delayed Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination.

A witness, a gym member, corroborated Tara’s account by stating they heard Tara say “Stop” during the incident. The officers also requested preservation of CCTV footage from hallway cameras covering the time frame between 19:20 and 19:55 to assist with the investigation.

In accordance with gym policy and to ensure safety, the manager suspended the suspect’s access to the facility immediately. Tara was provided with resources, including contact information for victim support services and the case number for reference.

Before concluding the interview, Tara confirmed the summary of her statement and added a descriptive detail that the suspect was carrying a towel with a black stripe.

The officers remained on scene until 21:02 hours, ensuring all necessary documentation, evidence collection, and victim support measures were completed.

End of Report.

Incident Report

Case Number: 25-240703  
Date/Time of Incident: September 28, 2025, approximately 05:30–06:15 hours  
Location: Depot Lofts — Freight Corridor  
Reporting Officer: Sgt. Salazar (#2081)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Keane (#3775)  
Weather Conditions: Light rain, 66°F  

Narrative:

On September 28, 2025, at approximately 06:13 hours, I, Sgt. Salazar, along with P.O. Keane, responded to a call regarding a sexual assault report at the Depot Lofts freight corridor. Upon arrival, we met with the reporting party, who identified herself as “Sloane,” inside the freight office. After obtaining her consent to record the interview, Sloane provided a free narrative of the incident.

Sloane stated that while she was checking shipments in the freight corridor, a male individual touched her after she explicitly said “no.” She immediately stepped away from the suspect. When asked to clarify the sequence of events, Sloane recalled that the suspect responded by saying, “It’s fine.” She described the suspect as wearing a neon vest and identified him as a vendor.

We proceeded to document the scene, taking photographs of the freight corridor, pallet area, and all exits to preserve evidence and provide context for the investigation. No visible injuries were noted on Sloane during the examination. We discussed the option of a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination with her; however, she was undecided at that time.

A witness, identified as a loader working in the area, reported seeing Sloane exit the freight corridor visibly upset. This contact was logged for further follow-up. We also requested preservation of CCTV footage from the loading dock cameras covering the timeframe of 05:30 to 06:15 hours to assist in identifying the suspect and corroborating the victim’s account.

Safety planning was discussed with Sloane, including potential schedule adjustments to avoid contact with the suspect and advisement that if the suspect was a third-party vendor, a trespass warning could be issued to prevent future access to the premises. We provided Sloane with resources for support and counseling and issued a case number for reference.

At 07:09 hours, the interview concluded after reading back a summary of the report to Sloane, who confirmed the accuracy of the information and reiterated the suspect’s description.

This report will be forwarded to the investigative unit for further action, including review of CCTV footage and follow-up interviews. All evidence and documentation have been secured in accordance with department protocols.

End of report.  
Sgt. Salazar (#2081)

On September 29, 2025, at approximately 12:04 hours, Officers Ebner and Fox responded to a call classified as a sexual assault report at the residence located at 18 Rosewood. Upon arrival, officers met with the reporting party, identified as “Mira,” on the backyard patio. Consent to record the interview was obtained, and privacy was maintained throughout the interaction, with a nearby neighbor waving but not interfering.

Mira provided a free narrative of the incident, stating that while seated on the outdoor couch, the suspect placed his hand under her top without consent. She immediately told him “No, stop,” after which he attempted the action once more. The timeline of the incident was clarified to have occurred between 11:30 and 11:45 a.m. During this time, the suspect reportedly said, “Don’t be shy.” Officers documented these quotes verbatim.

Scene documentation included photographs of the patio area, specifically the couch, coffee table, and sliding door. Officers noted the presence of shadows and the height of the privacy fence, which could be relevant to the investigation.

Mira was examined for visible injuries; none were observed. The option of a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination was discussed with her. Mira chose to delay this examination but was provided with information on how to proceed should she decide to pursue it later.

A witness, a neighbor who was watering plants nearby, reported seeing the suspect leave the area quickly following the incident. Contact information for this witness was obtained and recorded.

Digital evidence was preserved, including a text message from the suspect to Mira stating, “Sorry if I went too far.” Officers provided Mira with safety planning resources, including arranging for a friend to pick her up and a resource sheet containing support services. The case number was also provided.

Before concluding the interview at 13:01 hours, Mira confirmed the summary of her statement and added identifying details about the suspect. She described him as wearing a knit beanie, white sneakers, and having a small anchor tattoo on his forearm.

This report will be forwarded to the detective unit for further investigation. All evidence and statements have been documented and preserved according to department protocol.

End of report.  
P.O. Ebner (#2339)

Upon arrival at the ranger station adjacent to the trail, we met with the reporting party, identified as “Bree,” who consented to have the interaction recorded via body-worn cameras.

Bree provided a free narrative account of the incident. She stated that she and the suspect had stopped at the Meadow Spur location when the suspect placed his hand inside her waistband without consent. Bree immediately told the suspect to stop and stepped back to create distance. When asked to clarify the sequence of events, Bree recalled that the suspect reassured her by saying, “We’re alone, it’s fine,” despite her clear objection.

The officers documented the scene with photographs taken at sunset, capturing the spur, a nearby bench, and the approach path. It was noted that lighting conditions would become limited after approximately 19:30 hours, which could affect visibility in the area.

A minor scratch was observed on Bree’s skin, which was photographed with a scale for evidentiary purposes. Emergency Medical Services (EMS) were offered to Bree, but she declined immediate medical attention. Bree was informed about the availability of a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) for further examination, which she later agreed to pursue.

A potential witness, described as a jogger who may have passed by the area during the incident, was mentioned. A witness card was pinned to the nearby board to encourage any individuals with information to come forward.

No digital evidence such as photos or videos from Bree’s devices was provided at the time of the report.

Safety planning was discussed with Bree, including arrangements for a friend to pick her up from the location. She was also provided with a resource sheet containing contact information for support services and was given the case number for reference.

Before concluding the interview, Bree confirmed the accuracy of the summary read back by the officers. She added that the suspect was carrying a pack with distinctive orange straps and had a metal mug clipped to it, which may assist in identifying the individual.

The officers remained on scene until 20:02 hours, ensuring Bree’s safety and completing all necessary documentation.

This report will be forwarded to the appropriate investigative unit for follow-up. Bree has been advised on her rights and the available support services.

Respectfully submitted,  
P.O. Doyle (#3198)  
P.O. Kravitz (#2902)

Transcript: [BWC — Primary: Sgt. Patel (#1876); Secondary: P.O. Ortega (#2688). Call Type: Sexual Assault Report. CAD#: 25-240901. Date: 2025-10-04. Weather: Clear, 72°F. Location: 44 Easton Bar — Patio Nook. Time on scene: 00:27:14–01:19:58.] 00:27:14 — Bodycam activates as officers enter patio lined with heaters and string lights. Music thumps; laughter nearby. 00:27:26 — “Skye,” mid-20s, sits with friend “Jules.” She’s tearful, mascara smudged; Sgt. Patel murmurs to Ortega, “Busy night energy.” 00:27:41 — Intro includes consent to record. Patel offers options but adds, “It’s loud here, and these things can be lengthy—your call if you have the stamina.” Skye nods to staff office. 00:28:09 — In office, Patel opens with a narrowing prompt: “Walk me through the part where things crossed a line, not the whole night.” Skye recounts meeting a man by the heaters, brief kissing, then his hand up her thigh; she said “No, stop,” he said “Relax,” tried again, she left. 00:29:17 — Patel: “Okay, so we’re talking about a short interaction, seconds maybe?” Skye: “A minute, maybe.” 00:29:31 — Observation aside on camera: “No visible injuries.” Ortega writes “makeup/runny.” 00:29:49 — Leading clarification: “You kissed him first, right? And out here people are pretty close together—it can feel flirty.” Skye: “We kissed. I still said no.” 00:30:18 — Patel nods, then pivots: “He didn’t force you to stay. You walked away.” Skye: “Yes, I left.” 00:30:36 — Evidence options couched with friction: “There’s a forensic exam, but it’s a long process and might not show much for an outside touch over clothes. We can still do it.” Skye hesitates; Jules says, “Maybe tomorrow?” Patel: “That’s fine; lots of people wait.” 00:31:42 — CCTV: Manager says cameras “mostly face doors.” Patel responds, “These patio angles are usually not helpful,” and doesn’t push for immediate preservation beyond a casual “If you can save around midnight, great.” 00:32:28 — Scene documentation is perfunctory: one wide shot of heater area, no scale, no lighting notes. 00:33:01 — Witness handling: Jules gives statement; Patel interjects, “And you were drinking too, yeah?” Jules: “Two.” Patel later remarks quietly to Ortega, “Friends feed each other lines.” 00:33:49 — Suspect description captured loosely; Patel paraphrases: “Blue hat? Or gray? Doesn’t matter; common here.” Skye: “Blue with a logo.” 00:34:22 — Digital evidence: Skye mentions an Instagram handle; Patel glances and says, “We can look at that later; don’t worry about screenshots tonight.” 00:34:58 — Tone shifts to normalizing: “Out here, mixed signals happen. People get handsy by heaters.” Skye looks down. 00:35:19 — Timeline is compressed by leading: “So, you were fine until the second touch, then you left immediately?” Skye: “He touched twice. I said no both times.” 00:35:54 — Safety planning truncated: “Go with your friend. If you see him again, tell the bouncer.” Rights sheet handed over quickly without explanation. 00:36:32 — Patel summarizes with minimizing language: “Brief patio contact, no force, you withdrew and he didn’t follow. We’ll note it.” Skye: “He said ‘Relax.’” Patel: “We got that.” 00:37:11 — After Skye steps out, Patel comments to Ortega on camera: “Not much there. Probably a misread.” 00:37:42 — No advocate call placed; SANE discussed as “optional, probably low yield.” 00:38:19 — Case notes emphasize alcohol, crowd, consensual kissing pre-incident. 00:39:02 — Manager suggests the guy paid with card; Patel says, “If you find it easily, email it, but don’t spend your night.” No formal preservation letter recorded. 00:40:15 — Exit plan: “We’ll give you a case number. Think it over. If you want to add details tomorrow, call us.” 01:19:58 — Clear. Report voiceover while walking off patio: “Likely misunderstanding; minimal evidence; victim unsure.” End.
Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case Number: 25-240901  
Date/Time of Incident: October 4, 2025, approximately 00:27 to 01:20 hours  
Location: 44 Easton Bar — Patio Nook  
Reporting Officer: Sgt. Patel (#1876)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Ortega (#2688)  
Call Type: Sexual Assault Report  

Narrative:  
On October 4, 2025, at approximately 00:27 hours, Sgt. Patel and P.O. Ortega responded to a sexual assault report at the 44 Easton Bar, specifically the patio nook area. Weather conditions were clear with a temperature of 72°F. Upon arrival, officers observed a lively atmosphere with music playing and patrons socializing under string lights and patio heaters.

The complainant, identified as Skye, a woman in her mid-20s, was located seated with a friend named Jules. Skye appeared visibly upset, tearful with smudged mascara. After obtaining consent to record the interview, officers escorted Skye to a quieter staff office to discuss the incident in detail.

Skye recounted meeting a man near the heaters earlier that evening. She described a brief interaction involving consensual kissing, followed by the man placing his hand on her thigh. Skye stated she said “No, stop” and the man responded with “Relax,” but he attempted the contact again. She then left the area immediately. Skye estimated the entire interaction lasted approximately one minute. There were no visible injuries noted on Skye, aside from makeup that appeared to be running due to tears.

Officers clarified that Skye initiated the kissing but emphasized that she withdrew consent when the man touched her thigh. Skye confirmed she left the vicinity voluntarily and the man did not follow her. Officers discussed the option of a forensic exam with Skye, explaining it could be a lengthy process and might yield limited evidence due to the contact occurring over clothing. Skye hesitated and deferred the decision, with her friend suggesting she consider it the following day. Officers respected this choice and did not insist on immediate examination.

The bar manager indicated that CCTV cameras were primarily positioned to monitor entrances and exits, with limited coverage of the patio area. Officers requested preservation of footage around midnight but did not submit a formal preservation request. Scene documentation was minimal, consisting of a single wide-angle photograph of the heater area without scale or lighting notes.

Jules provided a witness statement and disclosed consuming two alcoholic beverages. Sgt. Patel expressed concern that friends might influence each other’s accounts. The suspect was described vaguely; Skye identified the man’s hat as blue with a logo, though officers noted this was a common item in the area.

Skye mentioned the suspect’s Instagram handle, but officers deferred digital evidence collection to a later time. The tone of the interview included normalization of the social environment, with officers noting that “mixed signals” and “people getting handsy by heaters” were common occurrences. Safety advice was brief, recommending Skye stay with her friend and report any further contact to security personnel.

Sgt. Patel summarized the incident as a brief contact without force, emphasizing that Skye withdrew and the suspect did not pursue her. The suspect’s statement “Relax” was noted. No advocate was contacted, and the Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) exam was discussed but deemed optional and likely low yield. The case notes highlighted factors such as alcohol consumption, crowd density, and the consensual kissing preceding the incident.

The bar manager suggested the suspect paid with a card; officers requested that if the payment information was easily accessible, it could be emailed to the department but advised not to prioritize this during the night. No formal evidence preservation letter was issued.

Skye was provided with a case number and encouraged to contact the department if she wished to add details later. The officers cleared the scene at approximately 01:20 hours. Sgt. Patel’s concluding remarks indicated the incident was likely a misunderstanding with minimal evidence and the victim’s uncertainty about the event.

End of report.

Transcript: [BWC — Primary: P.O. Li (#2631); Secondary: P.O. Gomez (#2740). Call Type: Sexual Assault Report. CAD#: 25-240912. Date: 2025-10-04. Weather: Overcast, 67°F. Location: 2130 Briarwood Ln. — Apt 1D Living Room. Time on scene: 12:15:02–13:06:44.] 12:15:02 — Li’s camera shows a tidy living room. “Iris” sits at the table, composed. Li whispers to Gomez, “Looks staged neat.” 12:15:19 — Consent to record. Li opens with a constraining prompt: “Let’s focus on the specific touch you’re reporting. We don’t need a play-by-play of the whole evening.” 12:15:42 — Iris recounts cuddling during a show, then saying she didn’t want more; he touched her chest and hip; she said “No,” asked him to leave. 12:16:28 — Li: “You invited him here though, and there was some consensual physical contact first?” Iris: “We cuddled.” 12:16:44 — Minimizing aside: “Rooms get messy after parties; this looks normal.” Gomez scans and takes only two photos. 12:17:03 — SANE presented with discouraging framing: “For a brief touch over clothes, exams don’t always show anything. It’s a long day; you can always think about it.” Iris pauses, says she’ll decide later. 12:17:41 — Li presses timeline: “Ten minutes total?” Iris: “Longer than that.” Li writes “brief encounter” anyway. 12:18:09 — Digital: text from suspect “Sorry if I pushed too far.” Li glances: “Save it; we’ll see if it matters.” No screenshot taken on scene. 12:18:37 — Possible neighbor witness; Li decides not to knock: “Weekday lunch—people nap.” 12:18:54 — Leading on motive: “Any arguments recently? Ex involved? People sometimes report after breakups.” Iris: “No.” Li nods but notes “relationship context unclear.” 12:19:32 — Iris describes pushing his hand away twice. Li paraphrases as “hesitation.” 12:19:56 — Safety planning reduced to “Keep your phone on you.” Rights sheet handed over without walkthrough. 12:20:19 — CCTV mention from property manager ignored: “Those cameras usually don’t catch inside doorways.” No preservation request made. 12:20:46 — Li summarizes with diminishing language: “Cuddling escalated, you said stop, he left. No injuries, no witnesses, low evidentiary value.” Iris appears deflated. 12:21:28 — On camera, Gomez mutters, “Probably messy boundaries.” 12:21:47 — Li provides case card; suggests, “Sleep on it. If you want to do the exam tomorrow, that’s fine.” 13:06:44 — Clear. Post-scene narration in hallway: “She’s very composed; feels rehearsed. Document as ‘ambiguous.’” End.
Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case ID: 52  
Date/Time: October 4, 2025, 12:15 PM – 1:06 PM  
Location: 2130 Briarwood Ln., Apt 1D, Living Room  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Li (#2631)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Gomez (#2740)  
Call Type: Sexual Assault Report  
CAD#: 25-240912  

On October 4, 2025, at approximately 12:15 PM, Officers Li and Gomez responded to a sexual assault report at 2130 Briarwood Lane, Apartment 1D. Upon arrival, the scene was observed to be a tidy living room. The reporting party, identified as “Iris,” was seated at a table appearing composed and calm. Officer Li noted quietly to Officer Gomez that the scene appeared “staged neat.”

After obtaining consent to record the interview, Officer Li began with a focused prompt, requesting Iris to concentrate on the specific physical contact she was reporting rather than providing a detailed account of the entire evening. Iris recounted that she and the suspect had been cuddling while watching a show. She stated that she communicated her desire to stop further contact, but the suspect touched her chest and hip over her clothing despite her verbal refusal. She asked the suspect to leave the premises.

Officer Li clarified that Iris had invited the suspect to the residence and that some consensual physical contact had occurred initially, to which Iris confirmed they had cuddled. Officer Gomez conducted a brief scan of the apartment and took two photographs, noting the environment appeared consistent with normal post-party conditions.

A Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) was presented to Iris but framed the examination as optional, noting that brief contact over clothing often yields limited forensic evidence and that the decision to proceed could be made later. Iris expressed hesitation and indicated she would consider the exam at a later time.

Officer Li pressed for a timeline, suggesting the encounter lasted approximately ten minutes; Iris responded that it was longer, though Li documented the incident as a “brief encounter.” A text message from the suspect was reviewed on scene, reading, “Sorry if I pushed too far.” Officer Li saved the message for potential future relevance but did not take a screenshot at that time.

A potential neighbor witness was considered, but officers decided against knocking due to the time of day and the likelihood that residents were resting. Officer Li inquired about any recent arguments or involvement of an ex-partner to explore possible motives; Iris denied any such context. The relationship between Iris and the suspect remained unclear.

Iris described physically pushing the suspect’s hand away twice, which Officer Li paraphrased as “hesitation.” Safety planning was minimal, with advice limited to “keep your phone on you,” and a rights information sheet was provided without detailed explanation.

The property manager mentioned the presence of CCTV cameras; however, officers determined these cameras likely did not capture footage inside doorways and did not request preservation of any recordings.

Officer Li summarized the report to Iris, characterizing the incident as “cuddling escalated, you said stop, he left,” noting no injuries, no witnesses, and low evidentiary value. Iris appeared deflated by this assessment. Officer Gomez was overheard muttering “probably messy boundaries.” Officer Li provided Iris with a case card and suggested she “sleep on it” and consider the exam the following day if desired.

The scene was cleared at 1:06 PM. Post-incident narration by Officer Li described Iris as “very composed” and “feels rehearsed,” recommending the documentation of the case as “ambiguous.”

End of report.

Transcript: [BWC — Primary: P.O. Hwang (#2984); Secondary: P.O. Cutter (#3110). Call Type: Sexual Assault Report. CAD#: 25-240923. Date: 2025-10-05. Weather: Cloudy, 66°F. Location: Boardwalk Underpass — North Ramp. Time on scene: 16:12:49–17:02:31.] 16:12:49 — Camera shows shaded concrete; surf noise. “Nova” stands arms folded. 16:13:02 — Hwang opens with “We’ll just hit the highlights.” Nova begins narrative about leaving the beach, being touched under the bridge, saying “Stop,” moving away. 16:13:38 — Hwang interrupts: “Had you been drinking? The sun can mess with memory.” Nova: “One drink earlier.” Noted prominently. 16:14:02 — Scene documentation cursory: one wide shot; no context of lighting or positions. Cutter remarks, “Everyone crowds under here when it’s hot.” 16:14:28 — Leading: “And you were flirting on the beach before this?” Nova: “We were talking.” Hwang: “Okay, so friendly first.” 16:14:53 — Nova describes him saying “Why are you acting shy?” and her saying “No” twice. Cutter jots “mixed signals.” 16:15:19 — SANE presented as burdensome: “You could do an exam, but with outdoor contact over clothing it may not yield much. It’s a lot of waiting.” Nova hesitates; says she’ll pass for now. 16:15:56 — Potential witness “Leo” is mentioned; Hwang says, “Surfers don’t like to get involved; we can skip it unless you really want.” Nova shrugs; witness effort dropped. 16:16:31 — CCTV: pole cam noted; Hwang says, “City cams rarely catch underpass angles,” and does not request preservation. 16:16:58 — Digital: none; Hwang suggests, “If he texts, keep it, but also, if you block him, that’s fine.” 16:17:24 — Safety planning truncated: “Don’t walk this route alone at dusk.” No resources reviewed. 16:17:43 — Hwang’s summary on camera: “Brief contact, prior friendly interaction, no injury, no corroboration.” Nova quietly adds, “He touched me twice.” Hwang: “We have that.” 16:18:18 — After Nova leaves, Cutter to Hwang: “Beach vibes drama.” Hwang: “We’ll code it as informational.” 17:02:31 — End.
Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case Number: 53  
Date/Time of Incident: October 5, 2025, approximately 16:00 hours  
Location: Boardwalk Underpass — North Ramp  
Reporting Officer(s): P.O. Hwang (#2984), P.O. Cutter (#3110)  
Call Type: Sexual Assault Report  

Narrative:  
On October 5, 2025, at approximately 16:12 hours, Officers Hwang and Cutter responded to a report of a sexual assault at the Boardwalk Underpass, North Ramp. Upon arrival, the complainant, identified as “Nova,” was located standing under the shaded concrete area near the underpass. The weather was cloudy with a temperature of 66°F.  

Officer Hwang initiated the interview by requesting Nova to provide a brief overview of the incident. Nova stated that she had been leaving the beach area when an unidentified male individual touched her inappropriately under the bridge. She described the contact as brief and stated that she told the individual to “Stop” and moved away from him. Nova indicated that prior to the incident, she and the male had been talking on the beach in a friendly manner, with some light flirting suggested by the male’s comment, “Why are you acting shy?” to which she responded “No” twice.  

During the interview, Officer Hwang inquired about Nova’s alcohol consumption to assess memory reliability, given the time of day and environmental factors such as sunlight. Nova admitted to having consumed one alcoholic drink earlier in the day. This was noted for the record.  

The officers conducted a limited scene documentation, capturing one wide-angle shot of the area but did not provide detailed context regarding lighting or the exact positions of the parties involved. Officer Cutter commented that the underpass area is commonly crowded during hot weather, which may affect witness availability.  

Nova was informed about the option of undergoing a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) exam; however, she declined, citing the outdoor nature of the contact (over clothing) and the anticipated lengthy waiting period.  

Potential witness “Leo” was mentioned by Nova as someone who might have been nearby. Officer Hwang advised that surfers typically avoid involvement in such incidents and suggested that pursuing this witness was optional. Nova did not express a strong desire to involve Leo, and the decision was made not to pursue witness statements further.  

Regarding surveillance, Officer Hwang noted the presence of a city pole camera but explained that city cameras rarely capture angles under the underpass. No request was made to preserve footage. Nova was advised to retain any digital communications from the suspect, such as text messages, but was also told that blocking the individual was acceptable for her safety.  

Safety planning was briefly addressed with a recommendation that Nova avoid walking alone through the underpass at dusk. No additional resources or victim support services were reviewed or offered during the interaction.  

At the conclusion of the interview, Officer Hwang summarized the incident on camera, noting the brief contact, prior friendly interaction, absence of injury, and lack of corroborating evidence. Nova quietly reiterated that the suspect had touched her twice, which was acknowledged by Officer Hwang.  

After Nova departed the scene, Officer Cutter remarked to Officer Hwang that the incident appeared to be “beach vibes drama.” Officer Hwang concurred and indicated the case would be coded as informational, reflecting the limited evidence and circumstances.  

The officers cleared the scene at 17:02 hours. No further investigative actions were initiated at that time.  

End of Report.

Transcript: [BWC — Primary: Sgt. Kim (#1907); Secondary: P.O. Alvarado (#2256). Call Type: Sexual Assault Report. CAD#: 25-240934. Date: 2025-10-05. Weather: Hot, 89°F. Location: Community Garden Shed. Time on scene: 10:35:41–11:28:12.] 10:35:41 — Officers meet “Sage” outside a sun-baked shed. 10:35:54 — Kim’s opener narrows scope: “Just the part where it crossed a line.” Sage describes tool sorting, a hand at her waist, him trying to go further; she said “Stop.” 10:36:37 — Kim: “Volunteer spaces get crowded; sometimes people brush past. Are we sure it wasn’t that?” Sage: “He grabbed me.” 10:36:56 — Alvarado pans lazily across interior; comments, “It’s cluttered anyway.” One photo taken. 10:37:15 — SANE framed as excessive: “You can, but for a quick grab it’s probably unnecessary. Entire morning lost.” Sage looks uncertain; says maybe later. 10:37:49 — Witness: coordinator heard “raised voices.” Kim says, “Could be about tools.” No contact taken on scene. 10:38:11 — Sign-in sheet exists; Kim: “We don’t need that right now.” 10:38:27 — Leading on motive: “Any drama with him about assignments? People file complaints during turf wars.” Sage: “No.” Kim notes “volunteer rivalry possible.” 10:38:56 — Kim emphasizes lack of injury: “No marks on the waist?” Sage: “No.” Kim nods, “Okay, so minimal.” 10:39:21 — Safety advice limited to, “Don’t be alone with him,” no options for trespass or schedule changes offered until Sage asks. 10:39:52 — CCTV at park entrance mentioned; Kim: “Angles won’t help.” No preservation request. 10:40:17 — Summary delivered in minimizing language: “Brief contact in a cramped space, no injuries, unclear intent.” Sage says, “He blocked the aisle.” Kim replies, “Narrow aisles do that.” 10:41:02 — After Sage steps away, Kim to Alvarado: “Boundary confusion; document as low priority.” 11:28:12 — Clear.
Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case Number: 54  
Date/Time of Incident: October 5, 2025, approximately 10:30 AM  
Location: Community Garden Shed  
Reporting Officer: Sgt. Kim (#1907)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Alvarado (#2256)  

On October 5, 2025, at approximately 10:35 hours, officers Sgt. Kim and P.O. Alvarado responded to a report of a sexual assault at the community garden shed located within the park. The weather was hot, approximately 89°F. Upon arrival, officers met with the reporting party, identified as “Sage,” outside the sun-exposed garden shed.

Sage reported that while sorting tools inside the shed, an individual, a fellow volunteer, placed a hand on her waist and attempted to make further physical contact. Sage stated she immediately told the individual to “Stop.” Sgt. Kim sought to clarify the nature of the contact, asking if it could have been incidental due to the crowded volunteer space. Sage firmly stated that the individual “grabbed” her, indicating the contact was intentional rather than accidental.

P.O. Alvarado conducted a brief visual inspection of the shed’s interior, noting it was cluttered, which could contribute to close physical proximity among volunteers. One photograph of the interior was taken for documentation purposes.

Sgt. Kim discussed the option of a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination with Sage, explaining that it might be excessive for what appeared to be a brief grab and could result in loss of volunteer time. Sage appeared uncertain and declined the examination at that time, indicating she might consider it later.

A witness, the garden coordinator, was mentioned as having heard raised voices but was not contacted on scene. Sgt. Kim suggested the raised voices could have been related to tool disputes rather than the reported incident. A volunteer sign-in sheet was present but was not requested or reviewed during the investigation.

Sgt. Kim inquired about any prior conflicts or complaints involving the individual in question, particularly regarding volunteer assignments or turf disputes. Sage denied any such issues. Sgt. Kim noted the possibility of volunteer rivalry but found no evidence supporting this as a motive.

Sage confirmed there were no physical injuries or marks on her waist. Sgt. Kim acknowledged the lack of injury and described the contact as minimal. Safety advice was limited to recommending Sage avoid being alone with the individual. No options regarding trespassing or schedule changes were offered unless requested by Sage.

The presence of CCTV cameras at the park entrance was mentioned; however, Sgt. Kim stated that the camera angles would not be helpful and did not request preservation of footage.

In summary, Sgt. Kim characterized the incident as brief contact in a cramped space with no injuries and unclear intent. Sage countered that the individual had blocked the aisle, to which Sgt. Kim responded that narrow aisles commonly cause such blockages.

After Sage left the scene, Sgt. Kim instructed P.O. Alvarado to document the incident as low priority, describing it as a boundary confusion rather than a clear assault.

The officers cleared the scene at 11:28 hours.

No further action was taken at the time, and the case remains open pending any additional information or complaints.

End of report.

Transcript: [BWC — Primary: P.O. Doyle (#3198); Secondary: P.O. Kravitz (#2902). Call Type: Sexual Assault Report. CAD#: 25-240945. Date: 2025-10-06. Weather: Sunny, 82°F. Location: 500 City Gardens — Gazebo. Time on scene: 18:01:08–18:54:40.] 18:01:08 — Doyle’s camera shows teens milling; “Remi” waves them over. 18:01:22 — Consent to record. Doyle begins with “We’ll keep it quick,” and steers: “Start at where he touched you, not earlier.” Remi describes sitting on grass, saying “No,” him touching thigh and hip, then leaving. 18:02:19 — Doyle: “You two had been hanging out a while, laughing, right?” Remi: “We were talking.” Doyle nods, “Okay, so friendly.” 18:02:43 — Scene photos limited to one wide shot; Doyle remarks, “It’s a park; grass on clothes is normal.” 18:03:02 — Witness “Ava” approaches; Kravitz tells her, “We’ll call you if needed,” and doesn’t collect info. 18:03:26 — SANE described as “a long wait, not sure it helps for over-clothes touching.” Remi says maybe later; Doyle says, “No rush.” 18:03:58 — Digital: Remi shows a DM: “You’re overreacting.” Doyle: “That’s just banter. Save it if you want.” No capture. 18:04:25 — Doyle recaps in a tone that emphasizes equivocation: “Short, mutual hangout, then some touch you didn’t like. No injuries, no pursuit.” 18:04:49 — Safety planning is a single line: “Leave with your roommate.” Rights sheet is handed off briskly. 18:05:12 — Closing aside: “These rarely go anywhere without video.” 18:54:40 — Clear.
Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case Number: 55  
Date/Time: October 6, 2025, 18:01 to 18:54  
Location: 500 City Gardens, Gazebo Area  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Doyle (#3198)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Kravitz (#2902)  
Call Type: Sexual Assault Report  

On October 6, 2025, at approximately 18:01 hours, Officers Doyle and Kravitz responded to a report of a sexual assault at the gazebo area of 500 City Gardens. The weather was sunny with a temperature of 82°F. Upon arrival, several teenagers were observed in the vicinity. A female identified as “Remi” was approached and invited to speak with officers.

After obtaining verbal consent to record the interview, Officer Doyle initiated the statement by requesting Remi to focus on the specific incident, starting at the point where unwanted contact occurred. Remi described sitting on the grass with another individual, during which she verbally expressed “No” as the subject touched her thigh and hip. The individual then left the area. Remi indicated that prior to the contact, they had been talking and socializing in a friendly manner, though not necessarily laughing or engaging in overtly playful behavior.

Photographs of the scene were limited to one wide-angle shot, with Officer Doyle noting that the presence of grass on clothing was typical for a park setting and did not necessarily indicate physical altercation or struggle. A witness named “Ava” approached the scene but was not interviewed or documented at that time; Officer Kravitz informed her that she would be contacted if further information was needed.

Remi mentioned the possibility of undergoing a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination but expressed uncertainty about its usefulness given that the contact was over clothing and no injuries were apparent. Officer Doyle advised that there was no urgency and that Remi could decide later if she wished to pursue the examination.

During the interview, Remi displayed a direct message on her phone from the alleged assailant stating, “You’re overreacting.” Officer Doyle characterized this message as “banter” and advised Remi to save it if she wished but did not record or seize the message as evidence.

Officer Doyle summarized the incident as a brief, mutual hangout that culminated in unwanted touching without physical injury or pursuit by the suspect. Safety planning was minimal, with the only recommendation being for Remi to leave the area with her roommate. A rights information sheet was provided to Remi in a brief manner.

The interview concluded with Officer Doyle noting that cases of this nature rarely progress without video evidence. The officers cleared the scene at 18:54 hours.

No physical evidence was collected, and no further witnesses were interviewed at the time. The case remains open pending additional evidence or statements.  

End of Report.

Transcript: [BWC — Primary: P.O. Ebner (#2339); Secondary: P.O. Fox (#2577). Call Type: Sexual Assault Report. CAD#: 25-240956. Date: 2025-10-06. Weather: Clear, 79°F. Location: Office Park Lot C — Bay 42. Time on scene: 07:29:15–08:20:51.] 07:29:15 — Officers meet “Priya” near her sedan. Ebner opens with, “Let’s be efficient—just the part after you two were in the backseat.” Priya recounts unwanted touching, saying “No,” exiting quickly. 07:30:02 — Ebner points to her leg: “I don’t see a bruise.” Priya: “It’s starting.” Ebner shrugs, “Hard to photograph early.” No photos taken. 07:30:31 — Vehicle documentation skipped: “Cars all look the same. Nothing to see.” 07:30:49 — Leading on relationship: “You got coffee with him last week, right? Sometimes mixed messages happen.” Priya: “As coworkers.” Note written: “Prior socializing.” 07:31:22 — SANE framed as low value: “For a short car encounter, not much to collect. Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case ID: 56  
Date: October 6, 2025  
Location: Office Park Lot C — Bay 42  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Ebner (#2339)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Fox (#2577)  
Time on Scene: 07:29:15 – 08:20:51  
Weather: Clear, 79°F  

At approximately 07:29 hours on October 6, 2025, Officers Ebner and Fox responded to a report of a sexual assault at Office Park Lot C, Bay 42. Upon arrival, officers met with the reporting party, identified as “Priya,” near her sedan. Officer Ebner initiated the interview by requesting that Priya focus on the events occurring after she and the alleged suspect were in the backseat of the vehicle.

Priya recounted an incident involving unwanted touching by the suspect, stating clearly that she said “No” and exited the vehicle quickly. Officer Ebner observed Priya’s leg for any visible injuries but noted no bruising at that time. Priya indicated that bruising was beginning to develop, but no photographs were taken as the officer remarked it was difficult to document injuries at such an early stage.

Vehicle documentation was not conducted, with Officer Ebner commenting that all cars looked similar and there was nothing noteworthy to record. The officers explored the nature of the relationship between Priya and the suspect, noting that they were coworkers who had socialized recently, including having coffee together the previous week. This was documented as “Prior socializing.”

The possibility of a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination was discussed. Officer Ebner framed the SANE process as lengthy and potentially low yield given the brief nature of the encounter in the car. Priya stated she would consider the option.

Regarding evidence collection, the officers noted the presence of CCTV cameras in the parking lot but decided against requesting footage due to the volume of vehicles and the complexity of retrieving relevant video. A digital message from the suspect to Priya reading “We good?” was shown to the officers; however, Officer Ebner deemed the message vague and not probative, and no screenshot was taken.

A potential witness, a coworker who reportedly saw Priya exit the vehicle, was mentioned. Officer Fox dismissed this as “office gossip” and did not obtain contact information or a formal statement.

Officers provided Priya with a case card and advised her to contact Human Resources if she experienced any awkwardness or further issues at work. The summary of the incident emphasized the ambiguity of the situation, noting the brief contact between coworkers, the absence of physical marks, and the lack of usable witnesses or evidence.

At 08:20 hours, officers cleared the scene. In a subsequent conversation in the stairwell, Officer Ebner described the incident as having an “HR dispute vibe,” suggesting the matter might be more appropriately handled through workplace channels rather than criminal prosecution.

No further investigative actions were taken at the scene. The case remains open pending any additional information or evidence.

End of Report.

Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case Number: 57  
Date/Time of Incident: October 7, 2025, approximately 21:45 hours  
Location: 75 Willow Glen, Unit 3D  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Carter (#1842)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Velasquez (#2079)  
Weather Conditions: Overcast, 69°F  

On October 7, 2025, at approximately 21:49 hours, Officers Carter and Velasquez responded to a call classified as a sexual assault report at 75 Willow Glen, Unit 3D. Upon arrival, the officers encountered the reporting party, identified as Keira, who was accompanied by her roommate. The roommate remained nearby throughout the interaction but did not provide a formal statement at that time.

Officer Carter obtained verbal consent from Keira to record the interview. The purpose of the interview was to clarify the circumstances surrounding the alleged non-consensual sexual contact. Keira explained that she had invited the male subject into her residence and initially engaged in consensual kissing. However, when the subject attempted to escalate physical contact beyond the kissing, Keira verbally expressed refusal and instructed him to leave. Despite this, the subject persisted briefly before ultimately departing the premises.

During the interview, Officer Carter questioned the nature of the interaction, emphasizing the initial invitation and consensual kissing, suggesting that the situation did not involve a stranger. Keira maintained that although the initial contact was consensual, she clearly communicated her lack of consent to further advances. The officer’s line of questioning appeared to focus on distinguishing consensual from non-consensual elements of the encounter.

A limited photographic survey of the scene was conducted, including wide-angle shots of the bedroom and the door area. No close-up photographs were taken, and no visible injuries were observed or documented. Officer Carter advised Keira about the option of a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination, describing it as potentially uncomfortable and possibly inconclusive. Keira appeared uncertain about proceeding with the examination.

Digital evidence was briefly referenced when Keira mentioned a text message stating, “Did I go too far?” Officer Carter instructed her to preserve the message but did not capture or review it at the scene. The roommate reported hearing Keira say “No” during the incident; however, no formal witness statement was obtained at that time, with the officer indicating that such information could be collected later if necessary.

Officer Carter inquired about any possible motives or stressors that might have contributed to the incident, such as arguments, academic pressures, or work-related stress. Keira denied any such issues. Safety planning advice was minimal, limited to recommendations to lock her door and to contact the police if the subject returned.

In summarizing the incident, Officer Carter characterized the event as a “home hangout” involving some mutual contact with a brief boundary issue, noting that the subject left the premises and that no injuries were reported. The officers cleared the scene at 22:43 hours. A final comment made by Officer Carter in the stairwell described the offense as “unclear” and referenced “mixed signals” between the parties.

This report reflects the officers’ observations and interactions during the initial response to the sexual assault allegation. Further investigation may be warranted to clarify the circumstances and to obtain additional evidence or witness statements.

Incident_Report:
Incident Report

Case Number: 25-240978  
Date/Time of Incident: October 7, 2025, 21:14 to 22:06  
Location: 88 Lakeview Towers — Rooftop Patio  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Hwang (#2984)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Cutter (#3110)  
Weather Conditions: Cloudy, 66°F  

Narrative:

On the evening of October 7, 2025, at approximately 21:14 hours, Officers Hwang and Cutter responded to a call regarding a reported sexual assault at the rooftop patio of 88 Lakeview Towers. Upon arrival, the scene was active with a party in progress, characterized by ambient chatter and a night skyline backdrop.

Officer Hwang made contact with the reporting party, identified as Monroe, who consented to be recorded for investigative purposes. Monroe described an interaction that occurred earlier on a couch near a stairwell. She recounted that during a conversation, she expressed verbal refusal—saying “no” and “stop”—when the involved male party placed his hand under her shirt and attempted to continue physical contact. Monroe stated that despite her protests, the male party tried again, prompting her to leave the area. She acknowledged some initial mutual closeness, describing being “a little” cuddled up with the individual prior to the incident.

The officers conducted a preliminary assessment of the scene, noting limited visual evidence due to the nature of the party setting. A single wide-angle shot of the couch area was recorded, but no further detailed scene work was feasible. Security footage from the venue was reviewed briefly but deemed inconclusive and “messy” by Officer Hwang, leading to no formal request for additional footage.

Monroe was informed about the Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination process, which was described as potentially lengthy. Monroe elected to postpone the exam and stated she would consider attending at a later time.

A witness named Rae offered to provide information; however, Officer Cutter deferred taking a statement, indicating the possibility of following up later.

During the interview, Officer Hwang referenced a digital message from the involved male party stating, “I thought we were vibing,” which was read aloud and lightly chuckled at by the officer, reflecting the perception of a possible misunderstanding. No digital evidence was captured at the scene.

Officer Hwang summarized the incident as a brief party interaction involving mutual cuddling followed by a misunderstanding, with no physical injuries reported by Monroe. A minimal safety plan was discussed, including a request for venue security to keep the male party away from Monroe.

The officers cleared the scene at 22:06 hours. Officer Hwang remarked to Officer Cutter that the incident was “probably a misread,” indicating the preliminary assessment leaned toward a misunderstanding rather than an assault.

No arrests were made at the scene. The case remains open pending further investigation and potential follow-up with the involved parties.

End of Report.

Salazar narrows: “Just the contact itself.” Hannah recounts dock sitting, his hands on her hip, her “No, stop,” him saying “Just a sec,” she left. 17:00:23 — Salazar: “You went there willingly and sat close, right?” Hannah nods. “Okay, so friendly at first.” 17:00:41 — Photos are minimal; Salazar says, “Docks all look the same.” 17:00:58 — SANE discussed as “an option but possibly not worth the discomfort for over-clothes touching.” Hannah hesitates; chooses to wait. 17:01:29 — Witness fisherman “Ari” is mentioned; Keane shrugs, “Fishermen mind their own.” No canvass. 17:01:52 — CCTV exists in parking; Salazar: “Night glare kills those cameras.” No preservation request. 17:02:15 — Digital: text “I misread.” Salazar: “That can mean anything.” No screenshot. 17:02:35 — Safety plan minimal: “Don’t meet him alone.” 17:02:51 — Summary with slant: “Casual meet, brief touch, you left, he didn’t pursue.” 17:52:05 — Clear. Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case Number: 59  
Date: October 8, 2025  
Reporting Officer: Sergeant Salazar (#2081)  
Secondary Officer: Police Officer Keane (#3775)  
Location: Lakeside Boat Ramp — Bench  
Weather: Mild, 73°F  
Time on Scene: 16:59 to 17:52  

On October 8, 2025, at approximately 16:59 hours, I, Sergeant Salazar, arrived at the Lakeside Boat Ramp in response to a sexual assault report. Upon arrival, I met with the reporting party, identified as “Hannah,” seated on a bench near the dock. Officer Keane was present as secondary officer and recorded body-worn camera footage throughout the interaction.

After obtaining Hannah’s consent to record the interview, I began by clarifying the nature of the alleged contact. Hannah recounted that she had been sitting on the dock when a male individual placed his hands on her hip. She stated that she verbally expressed “No, stop,” to which the male responded, “Just a sec.” Following this, Hannah left the area. I confirmed with her that she had initially gone to the dock willingly and had sat close to the individual, to which she nodded affirmatively. This suggested the interaction began in a friendly manner.

Photographs were taken minimally, as the dock area appeared uniform and unlikely to provide distinguishing evidence. I discussed the option of a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination with Hannah, explaining that it might not be warranted given the contact was over clothing and limited to touching. Hannah hesitated but ultimately chose to defer the examination.

During the interview, Hannah mentioned a witness, a fisherman named “Ari.” Officer Keane noted that fishermen in the area typically keep to themselves, and no canvassing of the area was conducted. I inquired about any available surveillance footage; there is CCTV coverage in the parking lot adjacent to the boat ramp. However, I noted that nighttime glare significantly degrades the quality of these cameras, and no preservation request was made.

Hannah referenced a digital text message from the individual involved, stating “I misread.” I acknowledged that such a message could be interpreted in various ways and did not request a screenshot or further digital evidence.

A minimal safety plan was discussed, advising Hannah not to meet the individual alone in the future. The summary of the incident was framed as a casual meeting with brief physical contact, after which Hannah left the scene and the male did not pursue her further.

At 17:52 hours, the interview concluded, and we cleared the scene. Based on the information gathered, the likelihood of substantiating a sexual assault under the current definitions appears low. The contact described was brief, over clothing, and did not escalate despite Hannah’s expressed discomfort.

This report is submitted for record and further review as necessary.

Sergeant Salazar  
Badge #2081  
Lakeside Police Department

Incident Report  
Case Number: 25-241000  
Date/Time of Incident: October 8, 2025, approximately 22:00 hours  
Location: 52 Laurel Bistro, Staff Locker Corridor  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Ebner (#2339)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Fox (#2577)  

On October 8, 2025, at approximately 22:03 hours, I, Officer Ebner, arrived at 52 Laurel Bistro in response to a reported sexual assault incident in the staff locker corridor. Upon arrival, I met with the reporting party, identified as “Camila,” in the manager’s office to obtain a statement and assess the situation.

Camila consented to have the interaction recorded on body-worn camera, with the understanding that the recording would focus on the key moments of her account. She described a brief post-shift interaction with an unidentified individual in the locker corridor after closing time. According to Camila, the contact was unwanted, and she expressed refusal by saying “No” before leaving the area. She reported no physical injuries or marks resulting from the interaction. When asked, Camila confirmed there were no visible injuries on her chest or elsewhere.

Photographic documentation was limited to a wide-angle shot of the locker corridor, which was noted to be in disarray, making detailed evidence collection challenging. The Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination was discussed; however, Camila described the procedure as invasive and indicated it would likely be unhelpful given that the contact occurred over clothing. She declined to undergo the examination.

A coworker witness reported hearing a loud slam, which was speculated to be the sound of a locker door closing. No direct physical contact was observed or recorded by witnesses. Attempts to review CCTV footage were unsuccessful due to steam fogging the kitchen cameras, rendering the footage unusable. No digital evidence such as video or audio recordings was available or requested.

The overall environment was described as noisy and chaotic, with the locker area cluttered and difficult to monitor. The brief nature of the interaction, absence of physical injury, and lack of corroborating evidence contributed to uncertainty regarding the incident’s specifics.

The incident was summarized as a brief post-shift encounter with no visible injury and occurring in a noisy, cluttered environment, leading to unclear circumstances surrounding the alleged sexual assault. Camila was advised of her options and the availability of support services.

The scene was cleared at 22:55 hours with no further action taken at that time. This report will be submitted for review and any necessary follow-up investigation.

Respectfully submitted,  
P.O. Ebner (#2339)  
Date: October 8, 2025

Incident Report  
Case Number: 61  
Date/Time of Incident: October 9, 2025, approximately 21:00 hours  
Location: 700 Grand Hotel, Room 605  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Carter (#1842)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Velasquez (#2079)  

On October 9, 2025, at approximately 21:05 hours, Officers Carter and Velasquez responded to a call regarding a reported sexual assault at the 700 Grand Hotel, Room 605. Upon arrival, hotel security granted access to the room. The complainant, identified as “Lena,” appeared calm and cooperative throughout the interaction.

After obtaining verbal consent to record the interview, Officer Carter began documenting the complainant’s account of the incident. Lena described meeting a male acquaintance at a bar earlier in the evening where they engaged in light conversation and mutual flirting. She recounted that they later went to the hotel room together. While in the room, the male subject touched her inside her dress without her consent. Lena stated she verbally declined by saying “No,” after which the subject attempted to touch her again but subsequently left the room.

During the interview, Officer Carter noted the prior social interaction between the parties, describing it as “prior flirting” and that they had been “chatting” rather than laughing together at the bar. The complainant’s demeanor remained composed, and she declined to pursue a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination, describing it as “not pleasant” and potentially “overkill.”

The officers conducted a brief inspection of the hotel room. Photographs taken were limited, with Officer Carter commenting that hotel rooms typically appear tidy regardless of incident. Security personnel offered to provide keycard access logs for the room, which Officer Carter acknowledged and stated they would “circle back if needed.” No preservation letter was requested for hotel surveillance cameras, as no footage was immediately available.

A neighboring hotel guest reportedly heard voices from the adjacent room, but no further information was collected due to the thin walls and lack of clarity. Officer Carter noted a digital text message on the complainant’s phone reading “Can we talk?” which was interpreted as a common post-date communication and was not captured as evidence.

In summary, the incident involved a brief, non-consensual touching inside the complainant’s dress in a hotel room following mutual social interaction at a bar. There were no reported injuries or physical evidence collected at the scene. The officers concluded the interview and cleared the scene at 21:59 hours. Officer Carter’s final remark in the hallway suggested skepticism regarding the nature of the complaint, stating “Buyer’s remorse?”

This report is submitted for further review and investigation as deemed appropriate. All evidence and statements have been documented in accordance with department protocol.

Respectfully submitted,  
P.O. Carter (#1842)  
Date: October 9, 2025

Banter?” Wren: “We talk.” Doyle notes “rapport.” 13:20:46 — Photos: single shot of door; Doyle says, “Archives all look the same.” 13:21:04 — SANE pitched as “probably unnecessary.” Wren undecided; Doyle doesn’t leave info packet. 13:21:27 — Sign-in log offered; Doyle: “We can ask later.” 13:21:44 — Digital: email apology; Doyle reads and says, “That’s vague.” No header preservation. 13:22:05 — Witness volunteer saw them exit; Doyle: “Students take sides.” No contact. 13:22:26 — Summary leans skeptical: “Quiet room, familiar faces, momentary touch, you left.” 14:09:58 — Clear.
Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case Number: 62  
Date: October 9, 2025  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Doyle (#3198)  
Secondary Officer: P.O. Kravitz (#2902)  
Location: City Library — Archives Room  
Time on Scene: 13:19 to 14:10  

On October 9, 2025, at approximately 13:19 hours, I, Officer Doyle, arrived at the City Library Archives Room in response to a reported sexual assault. The weather was overcast with a temperature of 68°F. Upon arrival, I met with the reporting party, identified as “Wren,” in the administrative office adjacent to the Archives Room.

After obtaining verbal consent to record the interview, I began questioning Wren regarding the incident. Wren described the alleged contact as occurring behind a closed door in the Archives Room. She stated that the individual involved touched her despite her verbal refusal, saying “No.” The subject reportedly responded by saying, “No one comes down here,” implying an attempt to discourage further interaction or witnesses.

I inquired about the relationship between Wren and the alleged assailant, asking if they often studied together or engaged in banter. Wren indicated that they “talk,” suggesting a level of familiarity but not necessarily a close friendship. I noted a rapport between the two parties, which may be relevant to the context of the incident.

Photographic evidence was collected, consisting of a single image of the door to the Archives Room. I noted that the Archives Room’s interior is uniform in appearance, which may affect witness identification or recollection.

I discussed the option of a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination with Wren, explaining that it was probably unnecessary given the nature of the contact described. Wren was undecided about pursuing this option, and I did not leave an informational packet at that time.

I offered to review the sign-in log for the Archives Room to identify potential witnesses or corroborate timelines but deferred this action for later investigation. Additionally, I reviewed a digital apology email purportedly sent by the alleged assailant. The content was vague and lacked header information, limiting its evidentiary value.

A volunteer witness reported seeing both individuals exit the Archives Room but did not observe any physical contact. I noted that students often take sides in such disputes, which could influence witness statements.

In summary, the incident occurred in a quiet, familiar environment with known individuals. The contact was described as momentary, and Wren left the scene promptly. Based on the information gathered during the interview and initial investigation, the circumstances suggest a need for further inquiry but do not conclusively establish criminal conduct at this time.

The scene was cleared at 14:09 hours. Further follow-up actions will include reviewing sign-in logs, attempting to obtain additional witness statements, and evaluating any digital communications related to the incident.

Report submitted by:  
P.O. Doyle (#3198)  
Date: October 9, 2025

Incident Report  
Case Number: 63  
Date/Time of Incident: October 10, 2025, approximately 23:12 – 23:42  
Location: 15 West Alley, behind warehouse  

Reporting Officers: Sgt. Patel (#1876), P.O. Ortega (#2688)  

Narrative:  
On October 10, 2025, at approximately 23:36 hours, Sgt. Patel and P.O. Ortega responded to a call regarding a sexual assault report at 15 West Alley, behind a warehouse adjacent to a local club. Upon arrival, officers observed a dimly lit alley with ambient noise from a nearby club. The complainant, identified as “Ari,” a person in their early 20s, was visibly upset and engaged in conversation with a club bouncer who directed officers to Ari.

Consent to record was obtained from Ari at 23:36:35. Sgt. Patel initiated the interview by focusing on the specific contact that caused distress, rather than the entire evening’s events. Ari recounted meeting a male individual near the bar’s side door earlier that evening. According to Ari, the interaction began with a brief mutual kiss. Subsequently, the male placed a hand inside Ari’s shirt. Ari immediately expressed discomfort, stating “No, stop.” The male then asked, “Any chance you’re into it?” Ari responded by pulling away and walking toward the alley.

Sgt. Patel clarified that the initial kiss was mutual and noted the environment was crowded and involved alcohol consumption. The bouncer confirmed seeing Ari exit the club visibly upset but did not provide contact information, as officers indicated they could reach Ari if needed. The club manager mentioned the presence of two CCTV cameras near the dumpster area; however, Sgt. Patel noted that footage from alley cameras is typically of poor quality and requested any footage from around midnight if available.

Ari was informed about the option of a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) exam but expressed reluctance due to the brief nature of the contact, which was over clothing, and the anticipated long wait times. Sgt. Patel acknowledged this hesitation and suggested Ari could consider the exam the following day. Ari provided a rideshare receipt timestamped at 23:12 and a text message from the male party stating, “Don’t be mad.” Officers advised Ari to retain these items for potential future relevance.

The timeline of the incident was described as brief, approximately one minute or less. Sgt. Patel advised Ari to stay with a friend that night and to alert club staff if the male individual was encountered again, to ensure his exclusion from the premises. Ari was given an incident card and informed that clinics offering exams would open early the following day.

Throughout the interaction, officers maintained a professional demeanor but used language that minimized the severity of the incident, describing it as a “short alley interaction” with “no injury” and “no follow-up.” After Ari stepped aside, P.O. Ortega commented that the situation appeared to be “weekend drama,” a sentiment with which Sgt. Patel concurred, suggesting a possible misinterpretation of intent by the male party.

A cursory inspection of the alley and dumpster area was conducted, but no detailed measurements or lighting assessments were recorded. The officers concluded the scene at 00:28 hours.

Summary:  
The complainant reported a brief unwanted physical contact following a mutual kiss in a crowded club environment. No physical injuries were observed or reported. The complainant declined immediate forensic examination but was informed of options to pursue medical evaluation later. Officers collected limited evidence and witness information, with no formal requests for CCTV footage documented. The incident was assessed as having low evidentiary yield, and no further immediate investigative actions were taken.

End of report.
