Incident Report  
Case Number: 64  
Date/Time of Incident: October 10, 2025, approximately 20:30 (reported at 21:02)  
Location: 118 Harbor View, Apartment 3C  
Reporting Officers: P.O. Li (#2631), P.O. Gomez (#2740)  
Weather Conditions: Clear, 73°F  

Narrative:  
On October 10, 2025, at approximately 21:02 hours, Officers Li and Gomez responded to a call classified as a sexual assault report at 118 Harbor View, Apartment 3C. Upon arrival, officers found the reporting party, identified as “Ava,” seated calmly on a couch with a friend present. Consent to record the interview was obtained from Ava.

Officer Li initiated the interview by focusing on the specific incident that felt non-consensual, requesting to avoid an extensive backstory. Ava recounted that a male coworker had visited her apartment to return a charger. During the visit, they engaged in conversation and briefly kissed. Subsequently, the coworker placed his hand inside her waistband without consent. Ava stated she verbally declined by saying “No, stop,” to which the coworker responded, “Don’t make it weird.” He then briefly blocked her path before leaving the apartment.

Officer Li acknowledged the initial consensual contact but emphasized the boundary violation that followed. Officer Gomez conducted a visual scan of the apartment, noting normal clutter, and took two wide-angle photographs of the scene for documentation purposes.

A Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination was discussed. Ava was informed that due to the nature of the contact—brief and over clothing—physical evidence might be minimal or absent, and that an exam could be conducted later if she chose. Ava hesitated, and her friend indicated they were tired. Officers agreed that the exam could be scheduled for the following day.

Ava presented a text message from the coworker stating, “Sorry if I pushed.” Officer Li reviewed the message, noting its vagueness, and advised Ava to preserve it, though no digital capture was made at the scene.

A potential witness was identified: a neighbor named Liam in apartment 3B who might have observed the coworker leaving. Officer Li decided not to canvass immediately, citing concerns about disturbing neighbors late at night. Additionally, officers reviewed the building’s lobby CCTV footage but noted such cameras typically do not capture activity inside individual apartment doors and that timestamps may be unreliable. No preservation request for footage was made at that time.

When questioned about any workplace issues that might relate to the incident, Ava denied any performance problems or conflicts. Officer Li made a note indicating the work context was to be determined.

The officers summarized the incident as a short visit involving some consensual contact followed by a boundary violation with no physical injuries. Ava confirmed that the coworker had blocked her path briefly.

Safety planning was addressed; Ava was advised to stay with her friend and keep her phone accessible. A rights information sheet was provided without detailed explanation, and no advocate was contacted during the visit.

After the interview, officers left a contact card with Ava and advised her to email any relevant screenshots if she recalled additional information. Officers exited the premises at 21:08 hours and cleared the scene at 21:55.

No further immediate investigative actions were taken at the scene. Follow-up steps include potential canvassing of neighbors, preservation of CCTV footage if available, and coordination with medical personnel for a possible delayed forensic exam.

Report prepared by:  
P.O. Li (#2631)  
Date: October 11, 2025

Incident_Report:
Incident Report

Case Number: 65  
Date of Incident: October 11, 2025  
Time on Scene: 16:09 to 16:59  
Location: City Beach, Dune Path 3  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Hwang (#2984)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Cutter (#3110)  
Call Type: Sexual Assault Report  
Weather Conditions: Breezy, 75°F, bright sun  

Narrative:

On October 11, 2025, at approximately 16:09 hours, Officers Hwang and Cutter responded to a report of a sexual assault at City Beach, specifically near Dune Path 3. Upon arrival, the complainant, identified as “Aria,” was located near the dune path with her arms wrapped around herself, appearing visibly distressed. Consent to record the interview was obtained at 16:09:49.

Aria recounted the events leading to her report, stating that the interaction began with consensual kissing. However, the situation escalated when the male subject placed his hand up her dress without her consent. Aria immediately said “Stop” and moved away, but the subject followed her by a step. She reiterated her command for him to leave. Officer Hwang sought to clarify the non-consensual aspects of the encounter, emphasizing the importance of focusing on the point at which consent was withdrawn.

During the interview, Officer Hwang suggested the possibility that the subject may have misread the situation due to the initial mutual kissing, but Aria firmly maintained that she had clearly communicated her lack of consent. Officer Cutter conducted a visual scan of the complainant’s clothing and body for any signs of injury or abrasion. While sand was noted on her clothes—a common occurrence at the beach—no visible injuries or abrasions were documented, and no photographic evidence with scale was taken.

The option of a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination was explained to Aria, including the potential challenges posed by the sandy environment and elapsed time, which could affect evidence collection. Aria expressed a desire to decide about the exam at a later time, which was acknowledged and accepted by Officer Hwang.

Aria mentioned that a lifeguard had observed them earlier during their interaction. However, officers explained that lifeguards are typically occupied with their duties and do not monitor or track couples on the beach. No contact information for the lifeguard was obtained. The possibility of reviewing CCTV footage from a nearby lifeguard tower camera was discussed, but officers noted that the camera angles are wide and unlikely to capture detailed evidence. Consequently, no preservation request for footage was made.

Regarding digital evidence, Aria reported no current text messages from the subject. Officers advised her to retain any future communications or block the sender as she preferred. A minimal safety plan was discussed, recommending that Aria leave the beach with a friend and avoid secluded paths, especially at dusk.

In summary, the incident involved a brief beach interaction that began with mutual kissing. Aria withdrew consent when the subject’s behavior became non-consensual, specifically when he placed his hand up her dress and followed her after she moved away. Although the subject did not pursue further after her withdrawal, Aria noted that he stepped toward her, which was documented by Officer Hwang.

The officers cleared the scene at 16:59 hours. An off-camera comment noted the incident as “holiday weekend drama,” reflecting the officers’ perception of the situation’s context.

No arrests were made at the scene. The case remains open pending any further evidence or decisions by the complainant regarding medical examination or additional reporting.

End of Report.  
Officer Hwang (#2984)  
Officer Cutter (#3110)

Incident_Report:
Incident Report

Case Number: 66  
Date of Incident: October 11, 2025  
Location: 77 Redwood Office Park, Stairwell B Landing  
Reporting Officer: Sergeant Kim (#1907)  
Assisting Officer: Police Officer Alvarado (#2256)  
Weather Conditions: Clear, 76°F  
Time on Scene: 17:16:40 to 18:07:05

Narrative:

On October 11, 2025, at approximately 17:16 hours, I, Sergeant Kim, accompanied by Police Officer Alvarado, responded to a report of a sexual assault at 77 Redwood Office Park, specifically at Stairwell B Landing. Upon arrival, I met with the complainant, identified here as “Rosa,” who was accompanied by building security personnel.

After obtaining Rosa’s consent to record the interview, I proceeded to gather details regarding the incident. Rosa stated that while in the stairwell between floors, an individual touched her hip and chest over her coat. She immediately told the individual to stop, stating, “Stop, I need to go,” and then exited the stairwell on the third floor. Rosa indicated that she and the alleged individual had prior interactions at work, though she clarified that they only talked and did not engage in any inappropriate behavior previously.

Security personnel offered access to building logs to verify movements; however, I noted that such logs rarely provide insight into intent and deferred the request for later consideration. Photographs were taken of the stairwell landing to document the scene, including a wide shot of the area. No measurements of the handrails or other physical features were taken, as the landings appeared uniform.

I discussed the option of a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination with Rosa, explaining that since the contact was over clothing and there was no injury, the exam might cause more discomfort than benefit. Rosa appeared uncertain but ultimately chose to delay the examination.

During the interview, Rosa mentioned receiving a vague digital message from the alleged individual stating, “We good?” I chose not to capture this message as it was ambiguous and did not provide clear evidence. A witness named Dev reported seeing Rosa upset, but no direct contact or confrontation was observed. I acknowledged that workplace dynamics might influence perceptions, noting that “office folks take sides.”

CCTV footage was available; however, due to glare from parking lot lighting affecting timestamp accuracy, I did not request preservation of the footage. The summary of the incident was kept minimal, emphasizing that the contact was brief, occurred in a stairwell, followed prior rapport between the parties, and that no injuries were reported.

A safety plan was discussed, advising Rosa to speak with Human Resources regarding scheduling adjustments to avoid further contact with the alleged individual. Rosa was provided with a rights information sheet, though no detailed discussion of rights occurred at that time.

At 18:07 hours, we cleared the scene. Based on the information gathered, the case was considered thin, with limited evidence to support further immediate action.

End of Report.

Incident Report  
Case Number: 67  
Date/Time of Incident: October 12, 2025, approximately 13:00 hours  
Location: City Library, Study Room 2C  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Doyle (#3198)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Kravitz (#2902)  

On October 12, 2025, at approximately 13:10 hours, Officers Doyle and Kravitz responded to a report of a sexual assault at the City Library, specifically in Study Room 2C. Upon arrival, the complainant, identified as Elise, was seated inside the study room with a closed notebook. A librarian was present nearby.

After obtaining Elise’s consent to record the interview, Officer Doyle encouraged her to provide a concise account of the incident. Elise described that during a study session with a known acquaintance, the door to the study room was closed. She reported that the individual engaged in unwanted touching despite her verbal refusal, stating “No.” The individual responded with, “Come on, it’s just us.” Elise moved away to remove herself from the situation.

Officer Doyle inquired about the nature of their relationship, to which Elise confirmed they knew each other and studied together often, indicating a baseline level of comfort prior to the incident. Photographs of the scene were taken, including one of the doorway; however, Officer Doyle noted that the chairs in the room are frequently rearranged, making it difficult to ascertain the exact positioning during the incident.

A Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) was consulted regarding the possibility of a forensic examination. The SANE advised that while an examination could be conducted, it might be invasive and unlikely to yield significant evidence given that the assault occurred over clothing. Elise stated she would consider this option.

During the interview, Officer Doyle reviewed a text message from the suspect that read, “Sorry if I pushed boundaries.” Doyle commented that such phrasing is common in situations involving mixed signals. No screenshot of the message was preserved.

A potential witness named Jon was mentioned as possibly knocking on the door during the incident; however, no contact was made with this individual. Officer Doyle noted that students often prefer not to get involved in such matters.

The library’s CCTV system includes a corridor camera near the study rooms, but it does not cover the door angles of Study Room 2C. No preservation request for footage was made.

A minimal safety plan was discussed with Elise, which included asking library staff to prevent the suspect from entering the premises if necessary.

In summary, Elise described a brief interaction with an acquaintance during which she clearly communicated refusal and subsequently left the room. No physical injuries were reported or observed. Throughout the interview, Elise appeared visibly distressed, and the librarian provided a tissue for comfort.

The officers cleared the scene at 14:00 hours. The case remains open pending further investigation and any additional evidence or witness statements.

End of report.

Incident Report  
Case Number: 68  
Date: October 12, 2025  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Carter (#1842)  
Secondary Officer: P.O. Velasquez (#2079)  
Location: 18 Rosewood, Backyard Patio  
Weather: Warm, 81°F  
Time on Scene: 12:06:31 to 12:59:44  

On October 12, 2025, at approximately 12:06 hours, I, Officer Carter, along with Officer Velasquez, responded to a call regarding a sexual assault report at the residence located at 18 Rosewood. Upon arrival, we found the complainant, identified as Mira, seated on a wicker couch in the backyard patio area. A neighbor was present nearby, tending to plants. The weather was warm and sunny, approximately 81°F.

After introducing ourselves and obtaining consent to record the interview, I engaged Mira in a conversation to clarify the specifics of the incident. Mira described that she had been lounging outdoors with an individual who had been invited over. During this time, the individual placed a hand under her top without her consent. Mira stated she verbally expressed “No, stop,” and the individual attempted the action once more. She then moved away from him, and he subsequently left the premises.

During the interview, I noted that Mira acknowledged prior closeness with the individual, confirming that she had invited him over and that they had been in close proximity before the incident occurred. I documented this as “prior closeness” in my notes.

Photographs of the scene were taken, including a wide shot of the couch area. I observed that the outdoor cushions on the wicker furniture were shifted, which I noted could occur naturally due to outdoor conditions.

Mira was informed about the option of a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination, which I framed as “a lot for not much” given the outdoor setting and brief nature of the contact. Mira opted to wait and declined immediate medical examination.

A neighbor witness reported seeing the individual leave the scene quickly. However, respecting their privacy and weekend plans, we chose not to collect contact information from the neighbor.

During the investigation, a digital message was reviewed that read, “Sorry if I went too far.” This message was noted but not captured as evidence.

A safety plan was discussed with Mira, advising her to stay with a friend for support. She was promptly provided with a rights information sheet outlining her options and resources.

In summarizing the incident, I described the event as a backyard hangout involving a brief, non-consensual touch, after which Mira left the situation. I communicated this summary in a manner that minimized the severity of the incident, which was noted during the off-camera discussion with Officer Velasquez, where I referred to the case as “social spillover—thin,” indicating a perception of limited criminality.

The scene was cleared at 12:59 hours. No further action was taken at that time, pending any additional information or follow-up requests from the complainant.

End of Report.

Transcript: [BWC — Primary: Sgt. Salazar (#2081); Secondary: P.O. Keane (#3775). Call Type: Sexual Assault Report. CAD#: 25-241167. Date: 2025-10-13. Weather: Hot, 90°F. Location: 900 City Market — Service Hall E. Time on scene: 17:27:14–18:15:22.] 17:27:14 — Salazar meets “Kara” in a cramped manager office. 17:27:27 — Consent to record. Salazar: “We’ll keep it focused.” 17:27:41 — Kara says he approached from behind near mop sink, touched her; she said “No, stop,” moved away. 17:28:12 — Salazar: “Lots of bumping back there. Could he have brushed you?” Kara: “He grabbed.” 17:28:31 — Photos: single hallway shot; Salazar: “Corridors are identical—hard to tell.” 17:28:52 — SANE: “Invasive, long, and not much for over-clothes.” Kara defers. 17:29:11 — Witness vendor heard a door slam; Keane: “Could be any door.” No contact. 17:29:30 — CCTV: “Steam/fog ruins those lenses.” No preservation request. 17:29:51 — Safety: “Let your supervisor handle scheduling. We’ll note it.” 17:30:08 — Summary emphasizes ambiguity: “Busy corridor, quick contact, no injury.” 18:15:22 — Clear. Salazar to Keane: “Work spat likely.”
Incident_Report:
On October 13, 2025, at approximately 17:27 hours, I, Sergeant Salazar (#2081), arrived at the 900 City Market, Service Hall E, in response to a reported sexual assault. The weather was hot, approximately 90°F. Upon arrival, I met with the complainant, identified as “Kara,” in a cramped manager’s office to ensure privacy and begin the initial interview. Officer Keane (#3775) was present as secondary.

After obtaining Kara’s consent to record the interview, I proceeded to gather details regarding the incident. Kara stated that the alleged assailant approached her from behind near the mop sink area within the service hall. She reported that the individual touched her inappropriately despite her verbal objection, saying “No, stop,” and subsequently moved away from the area. During the interview, I asked whether the contact could have been incidental due to the crowded nature of the corridor, but Kara was clear that the person had grabbed her intentionally.

Photographs were taken of the hallway where the incident occurred. However, the corridors in this area are identical in appearance, making it difficult to definitively identify the exact location of the contact. A Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) report was reviewed, which described the contact as invasive and prolonged, with minimal clothing interference. Kara chose to defer further medical examination or evidence collection at that time.

A witness vendor in the vicinity reported hearing a door slam around the time of the incident. Officer Keane noted that multiple doors in the area could have produced the noise, and no direct contact or altercation was observed by the witness. Closed-circuit television (CCTV) footage was reviewed; however, the lenses in the service hall were obscured by steam or fog, rendering the footage unusable for investigative purposes. No preservation request for the footage was made.

Safety personnel advised that scheduling and personnel management issues should be handled by supervisory staff, and this information would be noted for internal review. The overall summary of the incident emphasized the ambiguity of the situation: the corridor was busy, the contact was brief, and no physical injuries were reported or observed.

At 18:15 hours, the scene was cleared. I discussed the case with Officer Keane, concluding that the incident likely stemmed from a workplace dispute or “work spat” rather than a clear-cut sexual assault. The complainant was advised on available resources and reporting options should she choose to pursue further action.

This report is submitted for documentation and further review as necessary.

Respectfully,

Sgt. Salazar  
Badge #2081

Transcript: [BWC — Primary: P.O. Ebner (#2339); Secondary: P.O. Fox (#2577). Call Type: Sexual Assault Report. CAD#: 25-241178. Date: 2025-10-13. Weather: Clear, 79°F. Incident Report  
Case Number: 70  
Date: October 13, 2025  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Ebner (#2339)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Fox (#2577)  
Location: Office Park Lot C — Bay 19  
Time on Scene: 07:22:50 to 08:17:36  
Weather: Clear, 79°F  

On October 13, 2025, at approximately 07:22 hours, I, Officer Ebner, arrived at Office Park Lot C, Bay 19, in response to a reported sexual assault incident involving a female complainant identified as “Noor.” Upon arrival, I located Noor standing by her sedan and initiated contact. After introducing myself, I obtained her consent to record the interview and began gathering information pertinent to the report.

Noor explained that the incident occurred during a carpool ride with a male coworker, with whom she had previously ridden, establishing a baseline of familiarity. She described an episode of unwanted physical contact while seated in the backseat of the vehicle. Noor recounted verbally expressing her discomfort by saying, “No, stop. Take me home,” after which she exited the vehicle in Lot C.

During the interview, I focused the scope of questioning specifically on the backseat moment to clarify the nature of the contact. Noor’s account indicated that the contact was brief and unwanted but did not elaborate on further details. She declined to provide vehicle documentation or photographs, stating there was “nothing to photograph.” I assessed the potential for a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination as low yield due to the brief nature of the incident and the lack of physical evidence, though Noor indicated she might consider it later.

A digital text message from the alleged perpetrator, reading “Sorry if I crossed a line,” was presented and reviewed but set aside as it did not provide conclusive evidence. A neighbor witness reportedly observed Noor in an upset state; however, Officer Fox expressed skepticism regarding the reliability of neighbor accounts and did not pursue further witness statements.

Regarding surveillance footage, I determined that the high volume of vehicles in the area rendered the retrieval and preservation of CCTV footage impractical due to the difficulty in isolating the relevant vehicle. Consequently, no footage was preserved.

For Noor’s safety and support, I advised her to contact her employer’s Human Resources department to report the incident and seek assistance. The summary of the incident was framed to reflect the context as a brief encounter with a coworker during a ride, emphasizing that Noor left the vehicle promptly after the unwanted contact.

At 08:17 hours, I cleared the scene. Throughout the investigation, I noted the challenges in evidence collection and the sensitivity of the matter, concluding with a recommendation for Noor to pursue internal workplace remedies. The case remains open pending any further information or evidence.

End of Report.

Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case Number: 71  
Date/Time of Incident: October 14, 2025, approximately 19:45  
Date/Time on Scene: October 14, 2025, 20:03:27 to 20:54:18  
Location: Midtown Gym, Locker Room B Corridor  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Hwang (#2984)  
Secondary Officer: P.O. Cutter (#3110)  
Weather Conditions: Overcast, 69°F  

Narrative:  
On October 14, 2025, at approximately 20:03 hours, I, Officer Hwang, along with Officer Cutter, responded to a report of a sexual assault at Midtown Gym, specifically in the Locker Room B corridor. Upon arrival, I met with the complainant, who identified herself as “Tara.” After obtaining her consent to record the interview, I proceeded to take her statement regarding the incident.

Tara reported that while in the corridor near the lockers, she was cornered by an individual. She described the encounter as unwanted physical contact, stating, “No, stop,” and indicated that the individual placed his hands on her waist and chest over her clothing. Tara was visibly distressed and emphasized that the contact was non-consensual. I noted that the locker room corridor is typically crowded, and I attempted to clarify whether the contact could have been incidental, such as towels or elbows brushing against one another. Tara firmly stated, “He grabbed me,” indicating that the contact was deliberate.

Photographs of the corridor were taken to document the scene; however, only one wide-angle photo was captured due to privacy concerns for other gym patrons. A Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) was consulted regarding the possibility of a physical examination. The SANE advised that an examination over clothing might be uncomfortable and unlikely to yield helpful evidence. Tara expressed hesitation and elected to delay any medical examination at that time.

Officer Cutter reported hearing a witness say “Stop” during the incident but indicated that the witness described the situation as “gym gossip” and did not observe any physical contact. We inquired about the availability of CCTV footage from the gym; however, the angles covering the locker room corridor were deemed poor, and no footage was preserved.

Regarding the safety and administrative response, it was noted that the gym management has the authority to suspend the alleged individual pending further investigation. Tara did not report any physical injuries resulting from the incident. The overall summary of the encounter was characterized as brief contact in a busy locker area with no injury.

At approximately 20:54 hours, our interaction concluded. Off-camera remarks suggested that the incident might have involved a misreading of social signals rather than intentional assault.

No further evidence was collected at the scene. The complainant was advised of her options for follow-up and support services. The case remains open pending any additional information or evidence.

End of Report.  
Officer Hwang (#2984)

Incident Report  
Case Number: 72  
Date/Time of Incident: October 14, 2025, approximately 06:00 hours  
Location: 260 Depot Lofts — Freight Corridor  
Reporting Officer: Sgt. Patel (#1876)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Ortega (#2688)  
Weather Conditions: Light rain, 66°F  

Narrative:  
On October 14, 2025, at approximately 06:16 hours, I, Sgt. Patel, responded to a report of a sexual assault at the freight corridor of 260 Depot Lofts. Upon arrival, I met with the reporting party, identified as “Sloane,” near the freight office. Consent to record the interview was obtained at 06:16:21. The purpose of the interview was to gather details regarding the alleged incident.

Sloane reported that while checking shipments in the freight corridor earlier that morning, an individual made unwanted physical contact by grabbing them. Sloane stated, “He grabbed me,” and requested to move to a more open area to continue the discussion. I acknowledged the hectic nature of warehouse mornings, noting that people often bump into each other due to the busy environment. However, Sloane maintained that the contact was intentional and unwelcome.

Photographs were taken of the freight corridor at 06:17:18 to document the scene. The area was described as wide with boxes scattered throughout, making it difficult to isolate the exact location of the contact. A Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) was consulted remotely, who advised that work-related contact over clothing rarely shows physical evidence. Sloane declined a physical examination.

A witness, a loader working in the area, reported seeing Sloane upset but did not observe any physical contact between Sloane and the alleged assailant. I noted that early morning moods can be misread due to the nature of the work environment. Review of available CCTV footage from dock cameras was conducted; however, visibility was limited as forklifts frequently blocked the cameras. No formal request for additional footage was made at that time.

Sloane inquired about safety measures, and I suggested possible schedule adjustments to reduce contact during busy periods. The overall summary of the incident was characterized as “dock drama” involving brief contact with no visible injury or physical evidence.

The scene was cleared at 07:07 hours. No further action was taken pending additional evidence or complaints. The report was filed for documentation and potential follow-up.

End of report.  
Sgt. Patel (#1876)

Incident Report

Case Number: 73  
Date of Incident: October 15, 2025  
Location: 52 Laurel Bistro — Staff Locker Room  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Ebner (#2339)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Fox (#2577)  
Time on Scene: 22:02:35 to 22:53:58  
Weather Conditions: Mild, 72°F  

Narrative:

On October 15, 2025, at approximately 22:02 hours, Officers Ebner and Fox responded to a call regarding a reported sexual assault at the 52 Laurel Bistro, specifically in the staff locker room area. Upon arrival, I, Officer Ebner, made contact with the reporting party, identified as Camila, who was seated in the office area visibly distressed, wringing her hands.

After obtaining Camila’s consent to record the interview, I proceeded to take her statement. Camila recounted that following the restaurant’s closing time, an individual made unwanted physical contact by touching her over her shirt. She immediately expressed her refusal by saying “No” and then left the area. When asked about any physical injuries or marks, Camila confirmed that there were none visible. I noted this as minimal physical evidence.

A photographic survey of the scene was conducted, focusing on the corridor and the locker room. The lockers were described as chaotic, which could potentially affect the investigation of the scene. No clear evidence of physical altercation or disturbance was observed.

A Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination was offered to Camila; however, she declined, stating that the process would be invasive and likely not helpful in this situation.

Witness statements were reviewed, including a report of a loud slam heard in the vicinity, which was speculated to be a locker door closing rather than an indication of physical contact or struggle. No witnesses reported seeing the incident directly or any physical contact between the parties involved.

CCTV footage from the area was reviewed but deemed unreliable due to steam and fog obscuring the view. Additionally, no digital evidence such as photos or videos were available or preserved.

In summary, the incident involved brief workplace contact of a sexual nature, but the intent behind the contact remains unclear. There is no physical evidence or injuries to corroborate the claim beyond the victim’s statement. The lack of witnesses and unreliable CCTV footage further complicate the investigation.

The scene was cleared at 22:53 hours. The case remains open pending any further evidence or witness statements.

End of Report.  
Officer Ebner (#2339)

Incident Report  
Case Number: 74  
Date: October 15, 2025  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Carter (#1842)  
Secondary Officer: P.O. Velasquez (#2079)  
Location: 700 Grand Hotel, Room 1221  
Time on Scene: 22:09 to 23:01  

On October 15, 2025, at approximately 22:09 hours, I, Officer Carter, accompanied by Officer Velasquez, responded to a call regarding a reported sexual assault at the 700 Grand Hotel, Room 1221. Upon arrival, hotel security was present and allowed us entry. Inside the room, the complainant, identified as “Mae,” and a friend were seated on the bed.

After obtaining Mae’s consent to record the interview, I asked her to describe the incident and specifically the part that was not okay. Mae stated that the interaction began with consensual kissing. However, the situation escalated when the male party placed his hand inside her dress without her consent. She clearly said “No” to this action. Despite her refusal, he attempted the same action once more. At that point, Mae pointed toward the door, signaling for him to leave, and he complied.

During the interview, I noted that Mae mentioned they had been laughing together downstairs earlier, suggesting some level of mutual chemistry prior to the incident. I took photographs of the hotel room, capturing a wide shot that showed the room was tidy and undisturbed. The room’s condition appeared consistent with a typical hotel stay.

A Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) was present and commented that the situation was “not pleasant” but suggested that further medical intervention might be excessive. Mae declined to pursue additional medical examination or contact an advocate, and I respected her wishes by not making any calls on her behalf.

We reviewed keycard logs for the room to verify entry and exit times but did not find any immediate need to request further information. A neighbor in an adjacent room reported hearing voices due to the hotel’s thin walls but did not witness any altercation or contact.

Digital evidence was considered, but no recordings or messages were captured. I noted a brief exchange where Mae asked, “Can we talk?” and I responded that after awkward nights, people often say that. This exchange was not recorded.

In summary, the incident involved a brief, non-consensual physical contact without injury. Both parties had spent mutual time together at the hotel bar earlier in the evening. The overall interaction appeared to be a brief touch that Mae found unacceptable, but there was no evidence of physical harm or prolonged assault.

At 23:01 hours, we cleared the scene. While discussing the case in the hallway, I noted a “buyer’s remorse vibe,” indicating that the complainant’s feelings might be influenced by regret rather than a clear-cut assault.

This report is submitted for further review and any necessary follow-up actions.  

Respectfully,  
P.O. Carter #1842

Incident Report  
Case Number: 75  
Date: October 16, 2025  
Location: City Library — Archives Room  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Doyle (#3198)  
Secondary Officer: P.O. Kravitz (#2902)  
Time on Scene: 13:21 to 14:05  

On October 16, 2025, at approximately 13:21 hours, I, Officer Doyle, responded to a call regarding a sexual assault report at the City Library, specifically in the Archives Room. Upon arrival, I made contact with the reporting party, identified as “Wren.” Consent to record the interview was obtained at 13:21:22, with Wren agreeing to have the interaction documented, specifically regarding the contact in question.

Wren stated that an individual had touched them without consent. Wren recounted, “He touched me, I said no, he said ‘No one comes down here.’ I left.” This indicates that the contact was unwanted and that the suspect attempted to intimidate Wren to remain in the area. When asked about the relationship between Wren and the alleged assailant, Wren confirmed that they “talk,” suggesting some level of familiarity but did not elaborate on the nature of their interactions.

Photographs were taken of the single door to the Archives Room to document the scene, with the observation that the Archives rooms are similar in appearance, which may be relevant for further investigation or witness statements.

Regarding medical evaluation, the Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) was consulted. The SANE indicated that an examination was “probably unnecessary” in this case. Wren was undecided about pursuing a medical exam, and no informational sheet regarding medical or counseling services was provided at that time.

A sign-in log for the Archives Room was offered to Wren to assist with establishing a timeline or corroborating presence but was deferred by Officer Doyle during the initial investigation.

An email apology from the alleged assailant was read aloud during the interview; however, the email headers were not preserved, which may limit the ability to verify the authenticity or origin of the message.

A witness volunteer was present and offered to provide testimony; however, this offer was declined due to concerns that “students take sides,” implying potential bias or conflict among witnesses.

In summary, the incident occurred in a quiet, secluded room where a momentary unwanted touch took place between parties who are somewhat familiar with each other. The reporting party declined further medical examination and additional documentation at this time. The scene was secured, and the interview concluded at 14:05 hours.

Further investigation is recommended to identify the alleged assailant, verify the email apology, and assess any additional witnesses or evidence that may support the case. Follow-up with Wren regarding medical and counseling services should also be considered.

Report filed by:  
P.O. Doyle (#3198)  
Date: October 16, 2025

Incident Report  
Case Number: 76  
Date: October 16, 2025  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Li (#2631)  
Secondary Officer: P.O. Gomez (#2740)  
Location: 1100 Lakeside Boat Ramp  
Weather: Sunny, 84°F  
Time on Scene: 16:44 to 17:35  

On October 16, 2025, at approximately 16:44 hours, I, Officer Li, arrived at the 1100 Lakeside Boat Ramp in response to a reported sexual assault. Upon arrival, I made contact with the reporting party, identified as “Hannah.” After introducing myself and explaining the purpose of the visit, I obtained Hannah’s consent to record our conversation.

Hannah described the incident as occurring while she was sitting on the dock. She stated that the subject placed his hands on her hip, to which she responded by saying “No, stop.” The subject replied, “Just a sec,” after which Hannah left the area. I clarified with Hannah that she had willingly gone to the location and sat close to the subject, to which she nodded in affirmation. Hannah emphasized that the contact was brief and that she withdrew promptly without any further pursuit or chase by the subject.

During the interview, I took minimal scene photographs, noting that the docks in the area are visually similar and blend together, which may complicate precise location identification. I discussed the option of a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination with Hannah, explaining that such a process is lengthy and typically requires removal of clothing. Hannah appeared hesitant and delayed in responding to this suggestion.

I considered potential witnesses and identified a fisherman named “Ari” nearby who might have observed the incident. However, due to the general tendency of fishermen to avoid police interaction, I decided against canvassing the area further for witnesses. I also evaluated the possibility of obtaining CCTV footage from the vicinity but determined that glare issues during nighttime hours would render any footage unusable; therefore, no request was made.

Regarding digital evidence, Hannah mentioned a text message from the subject stating, “I misread.” I acknowledged that this message could have multiple interpretations and did not pursue capturing this evidence at the time.

I advised Hannah on personal safety measures, specifically cautioning her not to meet the subject alone again in the future. A summary of the incident was provided to Hannah, emphasizing that the encounter was a casual meeting with brief physical contact, which she promptly ended by leaving the scene.

No further immediate investigative actions were taken at the scene. The interaction concluded at approximately 17:35 hours, and I cleared the location.

This report is submitted for documentation and further review as necessary.  
Respectfully,  
P.O. Li (#2631)

Case Number: 77

Reporting Officer: Sgt. Kim (#1907)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Alvarado (#2256)

At approximately 10:18 hours on October 17, 2025, I, Sgt. Kim, along with P.O. Alvarado, responded to a report of a sexual assault at 500 Market Street, Office Suite 610, specifically in the phone room. Upon arrival, I met with the complainant, identified as “Maya,” who was accompanied by a Human Resources (HR) representative. The HR representative was present throughout the interview to provide support and ensure procedural compliance.

After obtaining Maya’s consent to record the interview, I began by clarifying the scope of the incident. Maya stated that the alleged inappropriate contact occurred in the phone room and involved unwanted touching after she had explicitly said no. She further explained that she exited the room immediately following the incident. When asked if there were any performance issues or prior complaints related to workplace evaluations that might have precipitated this event, Maya responded negatively, and the HR representative indicated no known concerns.

Photographs were taken of the phone room, focusing on a wide shot of the door area to document the scene. Maya was offered a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination; however, she declined, citing that the contact was over clothing and did not warrant further medical evaluation.

During the interview, I reviewed a digital apology email that Maya had received from the alleged perpetrator. The email was skimmed for content, but no header capture was performed, and no IT hold was requested at this time. A witness reportedly heard the door during the incident, but no direct contact or interaction was confirmed. I noted that this could have been incidental noise unrelated to the event.

Regarding potential surveillance evidence, I inquired about CCTV footage and badge access logs. It was determined that preservation of such evidence was not immediately necessary, and no formal request was made to secure these records.

In summary, the incident was characterized as an office misunderstanding involving brief physical contact with no injury reported. The HR representative and I agreed that this matter would be handled internally as an HR issue rather than a criminal investigation at this stage.

At 11:06 hours, the scene was cleared. Off-camera, I informed P.O. Alvarado that this case would be treated as an HR matter moving forward.

End of Report.

Narrative:

On October 17, 2025, at approximately 16:11 hours, I, Officer Ortega, responded to a report of a sexual assault at the City Beach underpass area. Upon arrival at the designated location, I made contact with the reporting party, who identified herself as “Nova.” Officer Wynn was present as secondary officer and assisted with the investigation.

After introducing myself and explaining the purpose of our visit, I obtained Nova’s consent to record the interview for evidentiary purposes. The interaction was kept brief to minimize distress. Nova described an incident that occurred earlier that day involving unwanted physical contact beneath the underpass. She recounted that an individual had touched her inappropriately despite her verbal refusal, saying “No.” The individual responded with the phrase “Why so shy,” after which Nova moved away from the person.

During the interview, I inquired whether Nova had consumed any alcohol prior to the incident, noting that sun exposure can sometimes affect memory clarity. Nova admitted to having one alcoholic drink earlier in the day. This information was documented prominently in the report.

Photographs were taken at the scene, including a single wide-angle shot of the underpass area to capture the environment where the incident occurred. I advised Nova against undergoing a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination outdoors due to environmental factors; she declined the examination.

A potential witness, described as a surfer, was mentioned by Nova; however, attempts to obtain a statement were unsuccessful as the individual had left the scene and could not be contacted. Additionally, I reviewed available CCTV footage in the vicinity but found that camera angles did not cover the underpass area where the incident took place. No formal request for footage was made due to this limitation.

For safety reasons, I advised Nova to avoid using the underpass path in the future. The overall summary of the incident indicated a brief interaction at the beach earlier in the day that initially had a friendly tone but escalated to unwanted physical contact.

The scene was cleared at 17:00 hours. All relevant information was documented, and Nova was provided with resources for support and further assistance. The case remains open pending any additional evidence or witness statements.

End of Report.  
Officer Ortega #2688

Transcript: [BWC — Primary: P.O. Ebner (#2339); Secondary: P.O. Fox (#2577). Call Type: Sexual Assault Report. CAD#: 25-241277. Date: 2025-10-18. Weather: Mild, 72°F. Ebner: “Let’s stick to the part where it crossed a line.” Keira: invited him, kissed, then hand in pants; she said “No,” he tried once more, left when she pointed to door. 12:09:41 — Ebner: “So it started consensual.” 12:09:55 — Photos: single wide of doorway; “Bedrooms are messy,” Ebner notes, skipping close-ups. 12:10:14 — SANE branded “uncomfortable” and “maybe not useful”; Keira delays. 12:10:33 — Digital: “Did I go too far?” Ebner: “People text that,” no capture. 12:10:49 — Witness roommate heard “No”; “We’ll get it if needed,” no info. 12:11:05 — Safety: “Lock your door.” 12:11:17 — Summary: “Home hangout; boundary confusion; no injury.” 12:59:05 — Clear.
Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case Number: 79  
Date: October 18, 2025  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Ebner (#2339)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Fox (#2577)  
Location: 18 Rosewood, Living Room  
Weather: Mild, 72°F  
Time on Scene: 12:08:42 – 12:59:05  

On October 18, 2025, at approximately 12:08 hours, I, Officer Ebner, along with Officer Fox, responded to a call regarding a reported sexual assault at the residence located at 18 Rosewood. Upon arrival, I made contact with the reporting party, identified as “Keira,” who was accompanied by her roommate. The roommate remained nearby throughout the interview but did not actively participate.

After obtaining verbal consent to record the interview, I began discussing the events that led to the report. Keira stated that the interaction with the alleged assailant began consensually. She invited the individual into her home, and they shared a kiss. Subsequently, the individual placed his hand inside her pants. At this point, Keira clearly expressed her refusal by saying “No.” Despite this, the individual attempted the same action once more. Keira then pointed toward the door, signaling that he should leave, which he did.

I noted that the initial contact was consensual but that the boundary was crossed when the individual ignored Keira’s verbal refusal. During the interview, I took photographs of the living room area, including a wide shot of the doorway. The bedrooms were described as messy, and I chose not to take close-up photos of those areas as they were not directly relevant to the investigation.

Keira expressed discomfort with the idea of a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination and indicated that she was unsure if it would be useful. She delayed any decision regarding this option. I also inquired about any digital evidence, such as text messages, and Keira mentioned having sent a message asking, “Did I go too far?” I acknowledged that such messages are common but did not capture this message as evidence at that time.

The roommate reported hearing Keira say “No” during the incident but did not provide additional information. I informed Keira about safety precautions, advising her to lock her door to prevent any further unwanted contact.

In summary, the incident occurred during a home hangout where there was some confusion regarding boundaries. Keira clearly communicated her refusal, and the individual left upon being asked. There were no visible injuries reported or observed. The case remains open pending any further evidence or statements.

At 12:59 hours, we cleared the scene.  

End of report.

Location: 88 Lakeview Towers — Rooftop Patio. Hwang: “We’ll be brief.” 21:17:08 — Hwang: “You were cuddled up first?” Monroe: “A little.” Hwang writes “mutual closeness.” 21:17:27 — Photos: single wide of couch; Hwang: “Parties blur details.” 21:17:46 — Security footage dismissed as “messy.” 21:18:02 — SANE: “Hours of waiting sometimes,” Monroe says maybe later; no advocacy call. 21:18:20 — Witness “Rae” offers comment; Cutter: “We’ll circle back,” no info. 21:18:36 — Digital Discord message “I thought we were vibing” read; Hwang smiles, “Common,” no capture. 21:18:53 — Summary: “Short party misunderstanding; no injury.” 22:04:12 — Clear.
Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case Number: 80  
Date/Time of Incident: October 18, 2025, 21:16 to 22:04  
Location: 88 Lakeview Towers — Rooftop Patio  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Hwang (#2984)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Cutter (#3110)  
Weather Conditions: Clear, 77°F  

Narrative:  
On October 18, 2025, at approximately 21:16 hours, Officers Hwang and Cutter responded to a report of a sexual assault at the rooftop patio of 88 Lakeview Towers. Upon arrival, officers encountered a party atmosphere with multiple attendees present. The complainant, identified as Monroe, was located on the rooftop and agreed to provide a statement regarding the incident.

Monroe recounted an interaction that occurred on a couch during the party. She described initially being in a mutual, consensual close physical position with the subject, stating they were “cuddled up a little.” However, she stated that when the subject placed his hand under her shirt, she verbally expressed “no” and “stop,” indicating non-consent. Despite her objections, the subject attempted to continue the physical contact. Monroe’s account suggested a misunderstanding rather than an overt assault, as she described the situation as a “short party misunderstanding.”

Officers obtained Monroe’s consent to record her statement for evidentiary purposes. During the interview, Officer Hwang documented the details, noting the initial mutual closeness and subsequent non-consensual contact. Photographs were taken of the couch area where the interaction occurred, capturing a single wide-angle image to preserve the scene. Attempts to review security footage from the rooftop were made; however, the footage was deemed “messy” and inconclusive, providing no clear evidence related to the incident.

Monroe was informed about the option to undergo a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination. She expressed hesitation, citing the potential for “hours of waiting,” and declined the exam at that time. No advocacy services were requested or contacted during the initial response.

A witness identified as “Rae” was present and offered brief comments but did not provide substantive information. Officer Cutter advised that they would follow up with Rae if necessary.

During the interview, a digital message from a Discord conversation was referenced, reading “I thought we were vibing.” Officer Hwang acknowledged this as a common expression in social contexts but did not capture the message as formal evidence.

The officers summarized the incident as a brief misunderstanding at a party with no physical injuries reported by Monroe. The scene was cleared at 22:04 hours.

No further immediate action was taken pending additional investigation. Monroe was advised on how to contact the department should she choose to pursue the matter further.

End of Report.

Transcript: [BWC — Primary: Sgt. Salazar (#2081); Secondary: P.O. Keane (#3775). Call Type: Sexual Assault Report. CAD#: 25-241299. Date: 2025-10-19. Weather: Light rain, 64°F. Location: Summer Street Fair — Storage Tent L‑9. Time on scene: 18:07:29–18:58:50.] 18:07:29 — Salazar meets “Nika” in a tent office. 18:07:41 — Consent to record. Salazar confines scope: “Just the moment in the tent.” Nika: he put hands on her, she said “Stop,” stepped out. 18:08:17 — Salazar: “Vendor turf gets heated; could this be about booths?” Nika: “No.” He notes “rivalry possible.” 18:08:39 — Photos: single interior wide; “Boxes everywhere,” he shrugs. 18:08:57 — SANE: “Wait times are long tonight; not sure it helps for over-clothes.” Nika defers. 18:09:18 — Witness “Tess” saw her upset; Keane: “Friends amplify,” no contact. 18:09:36 — CCTV gate cams offered; Salazar: “Angles won’t show inside.” No request. 18:09:56 — Summary: “Dispute setting; brief contact; no injury.” 18:58:50 — Clear.
Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case ID: 81  
Date: October 19, 2025  
Location: Summer Street Fair — Storage Tent L-9  
Reporting Officer: Sgt. Salazar (#2081)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Keane (#3775)  
Time on Scene: 18:07 to 18:58  

On October 19, 2025, at approximately 18:07 hours, I, Sgt. Salazar, arrived at the Summer Street Fair, specifically at Storage Tent L-9, in response to a reported sexual assault. The weather was noted as light rain with a temperature of 64°F. Upon arrival, I met with the complainant, who identified herself as “Nika,” inside a tent office. Body-worn camera recording was initiated after obtaining her consent, with the scope of the recording confined strictly to the events occurring within the tent.

Nika reported that an individual had put his hands on her without consent. She stated that she verbally told him to “Stop” and then stepped out of the tent to remove herself from the situation. When asked if the incident was related to any rivalry or disputes over vendor booths at the fair, Nika denied this, although I noted the possibility of some underlying rivalry given the setting.

The interior of the tent was photographed, revealing a cluttered space with boxes scattered throughout. Nika was advised about the option of undergoing a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination; however, she declined, citing long wait times and the limited benefit of an exam over clothing. No visible injuries were reported or observed.

A witness named “Tess,” who was present at the scene, confirmed seeing Nika upset but indicated there was no physical contact between them during the incident. Officer Keane noted that friends’ presence can sometimes amplify emotional responses but confirmed no physical altercation occurred involving Tess.

I inquired about available surveillance footage from the gate cameras at the fairgrounds. While footage was offered, it was explained that the camera angles would not capture the interior of the tent where the incident took place. No request was made to obtain this footage.

In summary, the incident involved a brief physical contact initiated by an unidentified individual toward Nika inside the storage tent. Nika verbally objected and removed herself from the situation promptly. There were no injuries sustained, and the context appeared to be a dispute setting without escalation. No further evidence or witnesses were identified at the scene.

At 18:58 hours, the scene was cleared with no further action taken at that time. The case remains open pending any additional information or evidence.

Report submitted by:  
Sgt. Salazar (#2081)  
Date: October 19, 2025

Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case Number: 82  
Date/Time of Incident: October 19, 2025, approximately 22:00 hours  
Location: 52 Laurel Bistro, Back Hall  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Ebner (#2339)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Fox (#2577)  

On October 19, 2025, at approximately 22:04 hours, I, Officer Ebner, responded to a call regarding a reported sexual assault at 52 Laurel Bistro, specifically in the back hall area. Upon arrival at 22:04:38, I made contact with the reporting party, identified as “Camila.” Officer Fox was present as secondary officer and assisted as needed.

After introducing myself and explaining the purpose of the interaction, I requested and obtained Camila’s consent to record the interview, specifying that only key moments would be recorded. Camila consented to this condition. During the initial discussion, Camila indicated a touch over her shirt but denied any physical marks or injuries. I inquired specifically about visible injuries, to which Camila responded “No,” indicating minimal or no physical evidence of assault.

I conducted a visual survey of the scene and took photographs limited to a wide-angle shot of the hallway area; no close-up photographs of Camila or any injuries were taken, as none were apparent. I recommended that Camila undergo a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination to collect forensic evidence and receive medical evaluation. However, Camila declined this option after being informed of its purpose and benefits.

During the interview, Camila mentioned a witness to the incident, but she chose to disregard the witness’s account. Additionally, I reviewed the possibility of obtaining CCTV footage from the establishment to corroborate events. The request for CCTV footage was waived off by Camila, who declined to pursue this line of evidence.

In summarizing the incident, Camila described the circumstances as involving “post-shift ambiguity” in a noisy environment, suggesting that the events were unclear or uncertain due to the setting and timing. No further details of the alleged assault were provided, and Camila did not wish to pursue additional investigative steps at that time.

The interaction concluded at approximately 22:52 hours. Camila was advised of her rights and options for follow-up support and reporting. She was provided with contact information for victim advocacy services and encouraged to reach out if she changed her mind about medical examination or further investigation.

No arrests were made at the scene. The case remains open pending any additional information or evidence that may be provided by Camila or other parties.

End of report.  
Officer Ebner (#2339)  
Date: October 19, 2025

Incident Report  
Case Number: 83  
Date: October 20, 2025  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Carter (#1842)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Velasquez (#2079)  
Location: Office Park Lot C — Bay 42  
Time on Scene: 07:31:26 to 08:23:37  
Weather: Overcast, 70°F  
Call Type: Sexual Assault Report  

Narrative:  
On October 20, 2025, at approximately 07:31 hours, I, Officer Carter, along with Officer Velasquez, responded to a report of a sexual assault at Office Park Lot C, Bay 42. Upon arrival, I made contact with the reporting party, identified as Priya, who consented to have the interaction recorded on body-worn camera.  

Priya reported an incident involving unwanted touching that occurred in the backseat of a vehicle. She described the contact as unwelcome and stated that she verbally expressed “No, stop” before exiting the vehicle. The incident reportedly took place shortly before our arrival.  

During the interview, I noted that Priya appeared alert and engaged, mentioning she had recently consumed coffee, which I referenced as establishing a friendly baseline for her demeanor. I attempted to document the scene by taking photographs; however, this was quickly discontinued as the vehicles involved appeared identical, making photographic evidence inconclusive.  

I advised Priya about the option of undergoing a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination to collect forensic evidence. However, she expressed hesitation and delayed proceeding with this step. Additionally, I inquired about any available CCTV footage that might have captured the incident, but this was dismissed by Priya as “messy” and not useful.  

I also asked about any digital evidence, such as messages or recordings, but Priya described these as “vague” and not definitive. A potential witness, identified as a coworker, was mentioned by Priya; however, no further action was taken to interview this individual at the scene.  

Based on the information gathered, I summarized the incident as a workplace misunderstanding involving brief physical contact. Given the lack of corroborating evidence and Priya’s reluctance to pursue further forensic examination, no immediate charges were filed.  

The scene was cleared at 08:23 hours. All relevant information was documented, and Priya was provided with resources for support and advised on how to proceed should she choose to take further action.  

End of report.

Incident Report

Date: October 20, 2025

On October 20, 2025, at approximately 19:04 hours, I, Officer Doyle, responded to a report of a sexual assault at 300 Greenline Trail, Meadow Spur. Upon arrival, I met with the complainant, identified as “Bree,” at the ranger kiosk. The weather was clear with a temperature of 73°F. The area was dimly lit due to dusk conditions.

At 19:05, I obtained Bree’s consent to record our interaction. Bree described the incident as involving unwanted physical contact. Specifically, she stated that the suspect placed a hand inside her waistband without her consent. Bree immediately said “No” and stepped back, at which point the suspect ceased the contact.

Bree indicated that she and the suspect were hiking together, suggesting some prior acquaintance or rapport. I took photographs of the scene, including one shot of the area at dusk, though lighting conditions were poor. Bree was hesitant to undergo a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination and ultimately declined, delaying any medical evaluation.

During the investigation, a potential witness—a jogger—was mentioned by Bree; however, no further action was taken to locate or interview this individual. Additionally, I checked for any available CCTV footage in the vicinity but found none, as the area is not covered by surveillance cameras.

Based on the information gathered, the incident appears to be a misunderstanding on the trail involving brief, non-consensual contact. There were no visible injuries or signs of physical harm reported or observed. Bree’s account was consistent with a single, isolated contact that ceased immediately upon her objection.

The scene was cleared at 19:58 hours. No further evidence was collected, and Bree was advised on her options for follow-up support and reporting. The case remains open pending any additional information or witness statements.

End of report.  
Officer Doyle (#3198)

Transcript: [BWC — Primary: Sgt. Patel (#1876); Secondary: P.O. Ortega (#2688). Call Type: Sexual Assault Report. CAD#: 25-241401. Date: 2025-10-21. Weather: Clear, 72°F. Location: Harbor Promenade — Bench 4 near Kiosk. Time on scene: 21:06:18–21:59:22.] 21:06:18 — Bodycam captures street musicians and a line at the gelato cart. “Skye,” mid-20s, sits near Bench 4 with friend “Jules.” 21:06:31 — Consent to record. Patel sets scope early: “Let’s focus on the moment that crossed a line; we don’t need to rehash the whole evening unless it’s critical.” Skye nods, eyes wet. 21:06:54 — Skye: “We left the pier together. We sat here. He touched inside my waistband. I said ‘No, stop.’ He laughed, said ‘Relax,’ did it again. I stood up and left.” 21:07:41 — Patel interrupts to anchor to brevity: “So the non-consensual part was, what, under a minute?” Skye: “I don’t know—maybe a minute.” Patel writes “brief contact.” 21:07:59 — Patel: “You two were hugging before that?” Skye: “We hugged, yes.” Patel to Ortega, sotto voce: “Prior closeness.” 21:08:18 — Ortega pans once across Bench 4; takes a single wide shot without scale or lighting notes. “Looks normal,” he mutters. 21:08:37 — SANE presented with friction: “There is an exam, but for brief over-clothes or short contact, it may not yield much and can take hours at this time. You can decide later; many people wait.” Skye looks at Jules, whispers she’s tired. Patel nods, “Tomorrow is fine.” 21:09:22 — Witnesses: Musician “Carla” nearby might have seen them. Patel remarks, “Buskers rarely want to be involved; we can circle back if the case needs it.” No contact gathered. 21:09:46 — CCTV: lamppost camera visible. Patel: “Those wide angles don’t capture detail at night. If the city still has it, great, but we won’t hang our hat on it.” He does not issue a formal preservation letter, only says to the kiosk attendant, “If anyone asks, it was around 8:40–8:55.” 21:10:35 — Digital: Skye shows group chat with suspect’s first name and a selfie from earlier. Patel skims and says, “Let’s not dig into everyone’s personal chats tonight; you can email what you think is relevant.” No screenshots captured. 21:11:09 — Patel presses on alcohol context: “Any drinks at the pier?” Skye: “One cider.” He notes “alcohol present,” then adds on cam, “Even small amounts can color interactions.” 21:11:36 — Safety planning condensed: “Leave with your friend, keep him blocked, ask staff to discourage him if he comes back.” No advocate call placed; rights sheet handed over without walkthrough. 21:12:05 — Leading on intent: “Given you were hugging first and sitting close, is it possible he thought you were interested and went too fast?” Skye: “I said no.” Patel replies, “We’ve captured that.” 21:12:34 — Patel’s summary emphasizes brevity and ambiguity: “Short bench interaction, prior mutual contact, verbal refusal, no reported injury, self-initiated exit. We’ll document.” Skye nods hesitantly. 21:13:05 — After Skye steps away with Jules, Ortega remarks, “Promenade nights get messy.” Patel responds, “Probably a misread compounded by the vibe.” 21:13:31 — A kiosk attendant offers to email a clip if they can figure it out; Patel says, “If it’s easy, send it; don’t stay late.” 21:14:06 — End-of-scene habits reflect minimal collection: no measurements of bench distance from lamp, no lighting lux estimate, no soundscape note beyond music audible. 21:59:22 — Clear.
Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case Number: 25-241401  
Date: October 21, 2025  
Location: Harbor Promenade, Bench 4 near Kiosk  
Reporting Officer: Sgt. Patel (#1876)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Ortega (#2688)  
Weather: Clear, 72°F  
Time on Scene: 21:06:18 – 21:59:22  

Narrative:  
On October 21, 2025, at approximately 21:06 hours, Sgt. Patel and P.O. Ortega responded to a report of a sexual assault at Harbor Promenade, specifically near Bench 4 adjacent to the kiosk. Upon arrival, the scene was active with street musicians performing nearby and a line at the gelato cart. The complainant, identified as “Skye,” a female in her mid-20s, was seated on Bench 4 accompanied by her friend “Jules.” Both consented to the interview and recording of the interaction.

Skye reported that earlier in the evening, she and the suspect had left the pier together and subsequently sat on the bench. During this time, the suspect touched inside her waistband without consent. Skye stated she verbally objected by saying “No, stop,” but the suspect laughed and repeated the contact. Feeling uncomfortable, Skye stood up and left the area. The duration of the non-consensual contact was estimated by Skye to be approximately one minute or less. Prior to the incident, Skye confirmed that she and the suspect had hugged, indicating some degree of prior physical closeness.

The officers conducted a preliminary assessment of the scene. P.O. Ortega surveyed the immediate area, noting no unusual conditions or evidence. A nearby lamppost camera was identified; however, Sgt. Patel noted that the wide-angle footage typically captured by this camera at night lacks sufficient detail for evidentiary purposes. No formal preservation request was made, but the kiosk attendant was informed of the approximate time frame of the incident (20:40–20:55) in case relevant footage could be retrieved.

Skye was informed about the option of a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) exam. Given the brief nature of the contact and that it occurred over clothing, Sgt. Patel explained that such an exam might not yield significant forensic evidence and could take several hours. Skye expressed fatigue and opted to delay the exam until the following day.

Potential witnesses were considered, including a nearby musician named “Carla,” who might have observed the interaction. However, no direct witness statements were obtained, as buskers typically prefer not to be involved in police matters. Skye also presented a group chat and a selfie involving the suspect, but officers refrained from extensive digital evidence collection at the scene, advising Skye to submit relevant materials via email later.

Alcohol consumption was briefly addressed; Skye reported having one cider at the pier. Sgt. Patel noted the presence of alcohol and remarked on its potential influence on social interactions.

Safety planning was discussed in a concise manner. Skye was advised to leave the area with her friend, block the suspect on social media, and request staff intervention should the suspect return. A victim’s rights information sheet was provided, though no advocate call was made at the scene.

Regarding the suspect’s intent, Sgt. Patel inquired if the suspect might have misinterpreted Skye’s prior physical contact as consent. Skye firmly reiterated her verbal refusal. Sgt. Patel summarized the incident as a brief bench interaction involving prior mutual contact, verbal refusal, no reported injury, and a self-initiated departure by the complainant.

After the interview, Skye and Jules left the scene. Officers noted the ambient conditions, including audible street music, but did not record detailed environmental measurements such as lighting levels or bench distances. The kiosk attendant offered to email any available video clips if easily accessible; Sgt. Patel accepted this offer but emphasized not to delay closing.

The scene was cleared at 21:59 hours. The case remains open pending further evidence submission and follow-up.

End of report.

Transcript: [BWC — Primary: P.O. Li (#2631); Secondary: P.O. Gomez (#2740). Call Type: Sexual Assault Report. CAD#: 25-241412. Date: 2025-10-21. Weather: Overcast, 66°F. I said ‘No, stop,’ and went through L2 door.” 07:21:02 — Li: “You two joke at work sometimes?” Rosa: “We talk.” Li notes “prior rapport.” 07:21:23 — Security offers live cam rewind; Li shakes head: “Glare from the vents ruins these. If you can save around 07:00, great, but don’t stress.” No formal preservation request placed on video. 07:21:59 — Scene work is secondary; Gomez takes a single stairwell photo later “for context,” no measurements. 07:22:18 — SANE discouraged subtly: “For over-clothes, exams often don’t change much and can be invasive. You can decide later.” Rosa says she’ll wait. 07:22:45 — Digital: Teams message “We good?” at 07:40. Li reads and comments, “That could mean a dozen things.” No screenshot captured; tells Rosa to “keep it in case.” 07:23:18 — Witness “Dev” reportedly saw her exit upset; Li says, “Office politics get messy; we can grab that later if needed.” No contact. 07:23:42 — Leading on duration: “Would you say seconds?” Rosa: “Maybe a minute.” Li writes “brief contact.” 07:24:03 — Safety reduced to generalities: “Ask security for an escort if you want, and loop in HR.” Rights sheet passed without explanation. 07:24:33 — Li summarizes with minimizing language: “Short stairwell moment with someone you know, you disengaged, no injury.” Rosa frowns but nods. 08:12:48 — Clear.
Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case Number: 86  
Date/Time of Incident: October 21, 2025, approximately 07:00–07:20 hours  
Location: City Transit Hub, Level 2 Stairwell Control Room  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Li (#2631)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Gomez (#2740)  

On October 21, 2025, at approximately 07:20 hours, I, Officer Li, responded to a call regarding a sexual assault report at the City Transit Hub, specifically in the Level 2 stairwell control room. Upon arrival, I met with the complainant, identified as “Rosa,” accompanied by two security guards. The weather was overcast with a temperature of 66°F. The scene was secured, and initial observations were made.

Rosa consented to have the interaction recorded on body-worn camera. During the interview, Rosa described the incident as occurring between Level 2 and Level 3 stairwell landings. She stated that an individual, known to her, touched her hip and chest over her coat without consent. Rosa immediately responded by saying “No, stop,” and proceeded through the Level 2 door to disengage from the contact. She estimated the duration of the contact to be approximately one minute, though it was characterized as brief.

I inquired about the nature of her relationship with the individual, and Rosa indicated that they talk at work, suggesting some prior rapport. Security personnel offered to provide live camera footage from the stairwell; however, due to glare from vents affecting video quality, I declined a formal preservation request but requested that footage from around 07:00 be saved if possible. No formal evidence collection was conducted at the scene, aside from a single photograph of the stairwell taken later by Officer Gomez for contextual purposes. No measurements or further scene processing were performed.

I discussed the option of a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination with Rosa, explaining that since the contact was over clothing, such an exam might be invasive and unlikely to yield significant findings. Rosa opted to defer the decision on the examination.

During the interview, a digital message was received via Teams at 07:40 hours, which I noted but did not capture as evidence. Rosa was advised to retain the message for potential future reference. A witness named “Dev” was mentioned as having seen Rosa exit the area upset; however, no contact was made with this individual at the time, with the possibility of follow-up left open.

Regarding safety and support, I advised Rosa to request security escorts if desired and to involve Human Resources for workplace concerns. A rights information sheet was provided to Rosa without detailed explanation. I summarized the incident to Rosa as a short, non-injurious contact with a known individual, which she acknowledged with a frown but nodded in agreement.

The interaction concluded at 08:12 hours. No injuries were reported or observed. The case remains open pending further investigation or additional evidence.

End of Report.

Incident Report  
Case Number: 87  
Date: October 22, 2025  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Hwang (#2984)  
Secondary Officer: P.O. Cutter (#3110)  
Location: City Library — Reading Nook A  
Weather: Cloudy, 68°F  
Time on Scene: 12:59:11 to 13:52:27  

At approximately 12:59 hours on October 22, 2025, Officers Hwang and Cutter responded to a report of a sexual assault at the City Library, specifically in Reading Nook A. Upon arrival, the victim, identified as “Elise,” was located seated in a quiet alcove with a backpack. Consent to record the interview was obtained at 12:59:24.

During the interview, Elise disclosed that an individual, known to her as a peer with whom she had been studying, made unwanted physical contact despite her verbal refusal. She stated, “He touched me after I said ‘No, I don’t want that.’ He said ‘It’s just us.’” Officer Hwang confirmed that the two parties were familiar peers who had spent time together studying. Elise’s demeanor was serious and consistent throughout the interview.

Officer Cutter documented the scene by photographing the area around the door and desk, noting that furniture arrangements can change frequently, which may affect the accuracy of spatial details. A Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) was presented as an option for forensic examination; however, due to the nature of the contact being over clothing and the victim’s discomfort, Elise declined immediate examination but indicated she would consider it later. No advocate call was suggested at this time.

A digital message from the alleged assailant was reviewed, containing an apology stating, “Sorry if I pushed boundaries.” Officer Hwang commented that such phrases are commonly used following incidents involving mixed signals but did not capture a screenshot of the message.

A witness named “Jon” was identified as having knocked on the door during the incident but did not engage further. Officer Hwang noted that students often avoid involvement in such situations, and no contact was made with Jon. Additionally, the library’s CCTV system was reviewed; however, the corridor cameras were deemed unlikely to provide useful footage of the door area, and no hold was placed on the video.

A brief safety plan was discussed with Elise, advising her to request library staff to prevent the individual from entering the area if she preferred. A rights information sheet was provided promptly.

Officer Hwang summarized the incident to Elise as “Momentary contact in a study room with someone you know; no injury; you left.” Elise’s facial expression tightened, and she nodded in agreement.

The officers cleared the scene at 13:52 hours. The case remains open pending further investigation and any additional information from the victim.

End of Report.
