Kim: “We’ll zero in on the specific contact.” 17:05:48 — Tara: “He followed me in and touched my chest over my suit. I said ‘Stop, not okay,’ stepped back.” 17:06:12 — Kim: “Locker rooms get crowded; hands brush.” Tara: “He grabbed.” Kim notes “crowded environment.” 17:06:34 — Photos: single corridor wide; privacy cited to avoid more. 17:06:49 — SANE: “For over-clothes, might be a lot of discomfort without much result; your choice.” Tara says she’ll delay. 17:07:10 — Witness “Neil” may have heard “Stop”; Kim: “Coworkers pick sides,” no contact. 17:07:27 — Badge logs offered; Kim: “We can pull later if needed.” No preservation request recorded. 17:07:44 — CCTV hallway exists; Kim says, “Angles are poor,” no hold. 17:07:58 — Safety: “Manager can separate schedules; talk to HR.” Rights sheet passed quickly. 17:08:17 — Summary minimizing: “Brief post-shift contact, busy area, no injury.” Tara looks down but agrees it was “brief.” 17:58:09 — Clear.
Incident_Report:
On October 22, 2025, at approximately 17:05 hours, officers responded to a reported sexual assault at the community pool, specifically in the staff locker A corridor. The weather was hot, with a temperature of 89°F. Upon arrival, Sergeant Kim (#1907) and Police Officer Alvarado (#2256) made contact with the reporting party, identified as “Tara,” near the locked staff area.

After obtaining consent to record the interview, Sgt. Kim initiated the statement by focusing on the specific nature of the contact. Tara reported that a male coworker had followed her into the staff locker corridor and touched her chest over her swimsuit. She stated, “He followed me in and touched my chest over my suit. I said ‘Stop, not okay,’ stepped back.” Sgt. Kim acknowledged that locker rooms can be crowded and that incidental contact can occur, but Tara insisted that the contact was deliberate, stating, “He grabbed.” The environment was noted as crowded, which may have contributed to the complexity of the situation.

Photographs were taken of the corridor, which is a single wide corridor. Due to privacy concerns, no further photos were taken inside the locker room area. A Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) was consulted regarding the possibility of a medical examination. The SANE advised that since the contact was over clothing, there might be discomfort with little evidentiary benefit. Tara elected to delay any medical examination at that time.

A witness named Neil was identified, who may have overheard Tara say “Stop” during the incident. Sgt. Kim noted that coworkers often take sides in such disputes and that Neil did not observe any physical contact himself. Badge logs were offered to Tara, with Sgt. Kim explaining that they could be reviewed later if necessary. No request was made to preserve any evidence at this time.

CCTV footage was available for the hallway, but Sgt. Kim noted that the camera angles were poor and declined to place a hold on the footage. For safety and workplace considerations, Sgt. Kim advised that the manager could separate work schedules and suggested that Tara speak with Human Resources for further support. A rights sheet was provided to Tara promptly.

During the interview, Tara appeared to minimize the incident, describing it as a “brief post-shift contact” in a busy area with no physical injury. She looked down but agreed that the contact was brief. The officers cleared the scene at 17:58 hours.

In summary, the report documents a brief, non-injurious contact described by the victim as unwanted touching over clothing in a crowded staff locker corridor. No physical evidence was collected, and no immediate preservation of CCTV footage was requested. The victim was advised on workplace safety measures and her rights. The case remains open pending any further developments or requests for evidence review.

I said ‘No, stop, take me home.’ He parked here, I got out.” 07:24:15 — Doyle: “You’ve ridden with him before; so there’s comfort baseline.” 07:24:32 — Vehicle documentation skipped; “Backseats don’t show much,” Doyle says. 07:24:48 — SANE: “Short car incident; exams are long; probably not much to collect.” Noor says she’ll think about it. 07:25:07 — Digital: “Sorry if I crossed a line” read; Doyle says, “That could mean anything,” and doesn’t capture. 07:25:26 — Witness neighbor saw her upset; Kravitz: “Neighbors dramatize,” no contact. 07:25:42 — CCTV likely; Doyle: “Too many cars; pulling’s a headache,” no preservation. 07:25:56 — Safety: “HR can sort rides.” Rights sheet handed over without explanation. 07:26:13 — Summary: “Coworker ride, brief contact, you exited, no injury.” 08:16:33 — Clear.

Incident Report  
Case ID: 89  
Date: October 23, 2025  
Location: Midtown Garage — Bay 19  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Doyle (#3198)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Kravitz (#2902)  
Call Type: Sexual Assault Report  
CAD#: 25-241445  

On October 23, 2025, at approximately 07:23 hours, I, Officer Doyle, arrived at Midtown Garage, Bay 19, in response to a reported sexual assault involving a female victim identified as “Noor.” The weather was clear with a temperature of 77°F. Officer Kravitz (#2902) was present as secondary.

Upon arrival, I made contact with Noor beside her sedan. After introducing myself and explaining the purpose of the interaction, I obtained her consent to record the conversation, specifying that the recording would focus solely on the incident occurring inside the vehicle. Noor described the incident as occurring in the backseat of the vehicle, stating that the male coworker, who had previously given her rides and with whom she had an established comfort baseline, touched her thigh without consent. She recalled telling him, “No, stop, take me home.” The coworker then parked the vehicle in the Midtown Garage, Bay 19, where Noor exited the car.

During the interview, I noted that vehicle documentation was not completed, as the backseat area did not provide significant evidence. A Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) was consulted and indicated that, given the brief nature of the incident, the physical examination might be lengthy with limited forensic evidence to collect. Noor expressed that she would consider undergoing the examination.

A digital message from the coworker stating, “Sorry if I crossed a line,” was read aloud but not recorded, as the statement was ambiguous and could be interpreted in various ways. A neighbor witness reportedly saw Noor upset; however, Officer Kravitz noted that neighbors tend to dramatize situations, and no direct contact was made with this witness.

Regarding surveillance, I assessed that although CCTV coverage likely existed in the garage, the presence of numerous vehicles would complicate identifying the specific car involved. Consequently, no preservation request for CCTV footage was made.

Safety concerns were addressed by advising Noor that Human Resources could assist with arranging alternative rides in the future. A rights information sheet was provided to Noor, though no detailed explanation was given at that time.

In summary, the incident involved a brief, non-consensual touching by a coworker during a ride, after which Noor exited the vehicle without injury. The interaction concluded at approximately 08:16 hours with no further immediate action taken.

End of report.

Incident Report  
Case Number: 90  
Date: October 23, 2025  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Carter (#1842)  
Secondary Officer: P.O. Velasquez (#2079)  
Location: Campus Housing — Room 3B Lounge  
Weather: Overcast, 71°F  
Time on Scene: 18:10 to 19:01  

On October 23, 2025, at approximately 18:10 hours, I, Officer Carter, along with Officer Velasquez, responded to a report of a sexual assault at the campus housing complex, specifically in the lounge area of Room 3B. Upon arrival, I made contact with the reporting party, identified as “Piper,” who was present in the lounge.

After introducing myself and explaining the purpose of our visit, I obtained Piper’s consent to record the interview. Piper described the incident as occurring during a social visit in which she had invited the subject into the room to watch a movie. According to Piper, the subject touched her under her shirt after she had explicitly communicated that she did not want to engage in sexual activity. She stated that she said “No, stop,” and subsequently opened the door to end the interaction.

During the interview, I acknowledged the initial friendly context of the visit but focused on the moment Piper indicated she did not consent to physical contact. Piper appeared hesitant when discussing the possibility of a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination, noting that such an exam might be invasive and might not reveal much evidence. She delayed providing further details on this matter.

I took photographs of the lounge area, including a wide shot of the single doorway, noting that the layout of bedrooms in the housing complex can shift frequently, which may affect the investigation. A message labeled “Can we talk?” was read on Piper’s digital device but was not captured as evidence.

A roommate, who was a potential witness, reportedly heard Piper say “No” during the incident; however, no further information was obtained from this individual at the time. I informed Piper that if necessary, we would follow up with the roommate later.

Regarding safety measures, I advised Piper that campus authorities have the option to issue a no-trespass order against the subject if deemed appropriate. I provided Piper with a rights information sheet promptly to ensure she was aware of her options and resources.

In summarizing the incident, I noted that the event appeared to be a home hangout that escalated into a brief boundary violation without physical injury. Piper did not report any injuries, and the interaction was described as a single instance of unwanted touching following a refusal of consent.

At 19:01 hours, our officers cleared the scene after completing the initial investigation and ensuring Piper’s safety and understanding of available support services. The case remains open pending further investigation and potential follow-up interviews.

End of Report.

Incident Report

Call Type: Sexual Assault Report

At approximately 16:57 hours on October 24, 2025, I, Sgt. Salazar, arrived at Lakeside Park, specifically at the boat dock bench area, in response to a reported sexual assault. Upon arrival, I met with the reporting party, identified as “Hannah,” who was seated on the bench. After introductions, I obtained her consent to record the interview, clarifying that the recording would focus on the dock area.

Hannah described the incident as occurring during a casual meeting at the dock. She stated that the subject in question held her waist without her consent. She recalled saying “No, stop,” to which the individual responded, “Just a sec.” Feeling uncomfortable, Hannah left the area shortly thereafter. During the interview, I noted that Hannah had chosen to sit close to the individual voluntarily, implying a friendly interaction prior to the unwanted contact.

Photographs of the scene were taken, including a wide shot of the dock area, which appeared unchanged and consistent with Hannah’s description. The possibility of a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination was discussed; however, it was discouraged due to the nature of the contact being over clothing and the time elapsed, which likely reduced evidentiary value. Hannah expressed some hesitation regarding this option.

Potential witnesses were considered, including fishermen in the vicinity. Officer Keane noted that these individuals typically “mind their own business,” and no canvassing of witnesses was conducted at this time. Additionally, the presence of CCTV cameras in the parking area was acknowledged, but due to night glare and poor visibility, no footage request was made.

Digital evidence, including a message from the subject stating “I misread,” was reviewed but deemed ambiguous and not captured for further investigation. Safety advice was provided to Hannah, emphasizing the importance of not meeting individuals alone in the future.

In summary, the incident involved a casual meeting at the dock, during which the subject briefly touched Hannah’s waist without consent. There was no pursuit or further contact following the incident. The report was documented thoroughly, and Hannah was advised on available resources and safety precautions.

At 17:52 hours, the scene was cleared with no further immediate action taken. The case remains open pending any additional evidence or reports.

End of report.  
Sgt. Salazar (#2081)

Incident Report

Case Number: 92  
Date of Incident: October 24, 2025  
Time on Scene: 22:01 to 22:55  
Location: Staff Locker Corridor, [Name of Restaurant]  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Ebner (#2339)  
Secondary Officer: P.O. Fox (#2577)  
Weather Conditions: Cloudy, 69°F  

Narrative:

On October 24, 2025, at approximately 22:01 hours, I, Officer Ebner, responded to a call regarding a sexual assault report at the staff locker corridor of a local restaurant. Upon arrival, I made contact with the reporting party, identified as Camila, who was visibly distressed but cooperative. I informed Camila of the purpose of our interaction and requested her consent to record the interview; she consented to a key moment recording.

Camila stated that after the restaurant had closed, an individual touched her chest over her shirt without her consent. She immediately told the individual “No” and left the area. When asked about any physical injuries or marks, Camila confirmed there were none. I noted the minimal physical evidence but acknowledged the seriousness of the allegation.

I proceeded to take photographs of the staff locker corridor, which is a narrow, busy back area of the restaurant. Camila indicated this was the location of the incident. The environment was described as noisy and somewhat chaotic due to the post-shift activity.

I discussed the option of a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination with Camila to collect forensic evidence. However, she declined, citing concerns about the invasiveness of the procedure and her belief that it would yield little benefit given the circumstances.

A coworker who was present nearby reported hearing a loud slam, which could have been a locker door closing, but did not witness any physical contact or altercation. Attempts to review CCTV footage were unsuccessful as the cameras were fogged by steam, rendering the footage unusable.

In summary, the incident appears to be a brief, non-physical sexual assault allegation occurring in a noisy, busy staff area after closing time. No physical injuries were reported or observed, and no forensic evidence was collected due to the victim’s choice. The case remains open pending any further information or evidence.

I cleared the scene at 22:54 hours.

Respectfully submitted,  
P.O. Ebner (#2339)

Incident Report  
Case Number: 93  
Date/Time of Incident: October 25, 2025, approximately 21:00 hours

Reporting Officer: P.O. Doyle (#3198)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Kravitz (#2902)  

On October 25, 2025, at approximately 21:03 hours, I, Officer Doyle, accompanied by hotel security personnel, responded to a call regarding a reported sexual assault at the 700 Grand Hotel, Room 605. Upon arrival, I observed the complainant, identified as Lena, seated on a chair inside the room. Officer Kravitz was present as secondary officer and recorded body-worn camera footage throughout the interaction.

After obtaining Lena’s consent to record the interview, I informed her that the focus would be on the events that occurred inside the hotel room. Lena stated that prior to entering the room, she and the suspect had consumed alcoholic beverages at the hotel bar. She described that once inside the room, the suspect touched inside her dress without her consent. She explicitly told him “No” and when he attempted to touch her a second time, she pointed toward the door to indicate she wanted him to leave.

During the interview, I noted that Lena and the suspect had been observed laughing and interacting in a seemingly flirtatious manner at the bar earlier in the evening. I took photographs of the hotel room, including a wide shot of the sitting area, noting that the room appeared tidy and undisturbed. I discussed the option of a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination with Lena, but she declined, expressing that she felt it would be unpleasant and possibly excessive under the circumstances.

I inquired about any physical evidence such as keycard logs or hallway surveillance footage. Lena was informed that these could be reviewed if necessary; however, no preservation request was made at that time. I also asked about potential witnesses, and Lena mentioned that a neighboring room occupant might have heard voices due to the thin walls, but no contact information was available.

Digital communications such as text messages or social media interactions were discussed, but no relevant messages were captured or preserved. The summary of the incident was that the encounter appeared to be a brief interaction in a hotel setting, involving unwanted touching without injury, following prior mutual socializing.

The entire investigation and interview lasted until approximately 21:58 hours, after which we cleared the scene. No immediate arrests were made. The case remains open pending further investigation. All evidence and statements have been documented and secured in accordance with department protocols.

End of report.

Reporting Officer: P.O. Li (#2631)  
Secondary Officer: P.O. Gomez (#2740)  
Location: Riverwalk — Under Bridge Mile 1.8  
Time on Scene: 07:07:26 to 07:59:52  
Weather: Breezy, 75°F  

On October 25, 2025, at approximately 07:07 hours, I, Officer Li, responded to a call regarding a reported sexual assault at the Riverwalk area under Bridge Mile 1.8. Upon arrival, I met with the reporting party, identified as “June,” near the park kiosk. Officer Gomez was present as secondary officer. The environment was noted to be breezy with a temperature of approximately 75°F.

After introductions and establishing rapport, June consented to have the interaction recorded, with the recording limited to the area near the railing where the incident allegedly occurred. June stated that an unknown male individual had touched her inappropriately despite her verbal refusal. She described the event as follows: “He touched me; I said ‘No, stop.’ I stepped away toward the lights.” She emphasized that the contact was not accidental or incidental, clarifying that the individual “grabbed” her, dismissing the possibility that it was a brush or accidental contact due to crowding near the railing.

Photographs were taken of the scene, focusing on the single-wide path and the surrounding area, including the river glare that may affect visibility. June was advised about the option of undergoing a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination; however, since the contact was reported over clothing and no injuries were visible, the SANE exam was discouraged. June remained undecided about pursuing this option.

Efforts to identify potential witnesses included canvassing joggers and runners in the vicinity. However, no witnesses responded or came forward to provide statements. Additionally, the park’s CCTV cameras were noted to have a short retention period. Although the footage was likely to be overwritten soon, no formal preservation request was made at the time of the investigation.

Safety advice was provided to June, including recommendations to walk with friends and remain vigilant in the area. A rights information sheet was handed to her promptly. The incident was summarized as involving brief contact in a crowded path with no visible injuries reported.

The scene was cleared at 07:59 hours. The case remains open pending further investigation and any additional information or evidence that may be obtained.

End of report.  
Officer Li (#2631)

Incident Report  
Case Number: 95  
Date: October 26, 2025  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Hwang (#2984)  
Secondary Officer: P.O. Cutter (#3110)  
Location: 118 Harbor View, Apartment 3C  
Time on Scene: 20:57 to 21:51  

On October 26, 2025, at approximately 20:57 hours, I, Officer Hwang, along with Officer Cutter, responded to a call regarding a sexual assault report at 118 Harbor View, Apartment 3C. Upon arrival, I made contact with the reporting party, identified as “Ava,” who consented to have the interaction recorded on body-worn camera (BWC).

Ava stated that the incident occurred during a brief visit from a male acquaintance who had returned a charger. During this visit, they engaged in a brief mutual kiss, which Ava described as consensual. However, following the kiss, the male subject touched her in a manner she did not consent to, despite her verbal refusal. Ava explicitly told the individual to leave her apartment. She described this contact as a boundary violation but emphasized that it was brief and that no physical injury was sustained.

During the interview, I noted prior closeness between Ava and the male subject, as indicated by the initial consensual kiss. Ava delayed seeking a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination, which was discussed but deemed potentially low yield due to the short duration and nature of the contact. Ava also showed a digital message from the male party apologizing with the phrase “Sorry if I pushed,” which I noted as common phrasing and did not capture as evidence.

Photographs of the apartment’s interior were taken, consisting of two wide-angle shots showing normal household clutter. No mid-range or close-up photos were taken, as there was no visible injury or evidence of physical struggle. Officer Cutter commented on the scene’s normalcy and clutter. We discussed the possibility of canvassing neighbors due to reported late-night knocks, but no canvass was conducted. Additionally, the lobby’s CCTV footage was noted to have wide-angle coverage, but no preservation request was made.

Ava was advised on safety measures, including staying with a friend, and was provided with a rights sheet outlining her options and resources. The summary of the incident was documented as a short visit involving a mutual kiss, followed by a boundary violation with no injury.

At 21:51 hours, we cleared the scene. The case remains open pending any further evidence or follow-up from Ava or potential witnesses.

End of report.

Incident Report

Case Number: 25-241522  
Date: October 26, 2025  
Location: 77 Redwood Office Park, Stairwell B  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Gomez (#2740)  
Secondary Officer: P.O. Li (#2631)  
Weather: Sunny, 84°F  
Time on Scene: 17:21 to 18:10

Narrative:

On October 26, 2025, at approximately 17:21 hours, I, Officer Gomez (#2740), arrived at 77 Redwood Office Park, Stairwell B, in response to a reported sexual assault. Upon arrival, I made contact with the complainant, identified as “Rosa,” who agreed to provide a statement and consented to audio recording of the interview, specifically regarding the events that occurred in the stairwell.

Rosa stated that an individual had touched her inappropriately while they were in the stairwell. She recalled telling the individual to stop, stating, “Stop, I have to go,” before exiting the stairwell on the third floor. During the interview, Rosa acknowledged that she and the alleged assailant had previously communicated, which I noted could potentially lead to misunderstandings regarding intent or consent.

I took photographs of the stairwell landing where the incident occurred. The area appeared uniform, with no distinguishing features, which could complicate further investigation or identification of the exact location of contact. Rosa declined to undergo a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination at that time, expressing hesitation and delaying the decision.

I attempted to gather additional evidence, including digital communications, but the information was vague and did not provide clear support for the allegations. A coworker who witnessed some interaction between Rosa and the alleged assailant was identified but reportedly ignored the incident, offering no further assistance. I also considered reviewing CCTV footage and badge logs; however, these were deferred for potential later use and not secured at the scene.

Regarding safety concerns, Rosa was advised that the Human Resources department could manage any workplace-related issues stemming from the incident. The summary of the initial assessment indicated that the contact was brief, occurred in the stairwell, and involved individuals with prior rapport. Importantly, Rosa reported no physical injury resulting from the contact.

After completing the interview and documentation, I cleared the scene at 18:10 hours. The case remains open pending further investigation, including potential follow-up with Human Resources and review of any additional evidence that may become available.

End of Report.  
Officer Gomez (#2740)

Incident Report  
Case Number: 97  
Date: October 27, 2025  
Reporting Officer: Sgt. Kim (#1907)  
Secondary Officer: P.O. Alvarado (#2256)  
Location: Office Suite 610, Quiet Room  
Weather: Clear, 76°F  
Time on Scene: 10:17:38 – 11:05:11  

On October 27, 2025, at approximately 10:17 hours, I, Sgt. Kim, accompanied by P.O. Alvarado, responded to a report of a sexual assault at Office Suite 610, specifically in the Quiet Room. Upon arrival, I met with the complainant, identified as “Maya,” who was accompanied by a Human Resources (HR) representative. The purpose of the meeting was to obtain a detailed account of the incident and assess the situation.

At 10:17:52, I requested and obtained Maya’s consent to record the interview, specifying that the recording would focus solely on the events that occurred in the phone room. Maya stated that the alleged assailant touched her after she had explicitly said no, and that she subsequently left the area. She described the contact as brief and indicated that she did not sustain any physical injuries.

I inquired about any concerns related to workplace performance or evaluations that might be relevant to the case. The HR representative indicated no such concerns. Photographs were taken of the door to the Quiet Room, which was found to be wide open at the time of the interview. No additional photographic evidence was collected.

Maya declined a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination, as it was deemed by HR to be excessive for the circumstances described. An email apology from the alleged assailant was reviewed; however, it lacked proper headers and was not placed on an IT hold, limiting its evidentiary value.

A witness reportedly heard the door but did not observe any physical contact. Requests for CCTV footage and badge access logs were deferred, and no preservation of such evidence was undertaken at this time.

The summary of the incident, as discussed with HR and Maya, characterized the event as an office misunderstanding involving brief contact without injury. No further immediate action was taken pending additional investigation.

At 11:05 hours, the scene was cleared. This report will be forwarded to the appropriate investigative unit for follow-up as necessary.

End of Report.

Incident Report

Case Number: 98  
Date: October 27, 2025  
Time on Scene: 16:05 to 16:59  
Location: City Beach — Dune Path 3 Bench  
Weather: Breezy, 79°F  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Ortega (#2688)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Wynn (#3011)  
Call Type: Sexual Assault Report  

Narrative:

On October 27, 2025, at approximately 16:05 hours, I, Officer Ortega (#2688), arrived at City Beach, Dune Path 3 Bench, in response to a reported sexual assault. The weather was breezy with a temperature of 79°F. Upon arrival, I made contact with the reporting party, identified as “Aria.” After introducing myself and explaining the process, I obtained her consent to record the interview for accuracy and transparency.

Aria stated that she and the suspect had engaged in a mutual kiss. However, she reported that after she said “stop,” the suspect continued to touch her. She immediately walked away from the situation. I asked if there was any possibility that the suspect misread the situation, given the casual, flirty nature of a beach day, but Aria firmly reiterated that she had said “stop” and did not consent to further contact.

During the investigation, Officer Wynn (#3011) and I took photographs of the scene, including the single wide path leading to the bench area. Officer Wynn commented that “sand tells no story,” indicating that no physical evidence was apparent in the environment. We considered contacting a lifeguard who was present as a potential witness; however, the lifeguard was busy and unavailable for an interview. Additionally, we reviewed the nearby CCTV tower footage but determined the camera angle was too wide and did not capture relevant details of the incident.

We discussed the option of a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination for Aria. Due to the outdoor location and Aria’s hesitation, she declined to pursue this option at the time. For her safety, we advised Aria to leave the area with friends and remain in a secure environment.

After gathering all available information, I summarized the incident as involving a mutual kiss followed by brief unwanted touching, which Aria self-resolved by walking away. No physical evidence or witnesses were obtained to corroborate the claim. The report was completed, and the scene was cleared at 16:59 hours.

Follow-up actions will include offering Aria resources for support and counseling, and monitoring for any further reports related to this case.

End of report.  
Officer Ortega (#2688)

Incident Report  
Case Number: 99  
Date: October 28, 2025  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Ebner (#2339)

Location: 60 Orchard Co-Op, Room 3B  
Weather: Cloudy, 70°F

On October 28, 2025, at approximately 18:12 hours, I, Officer Ebner, arrived at 60 Orchard Co-Op, Room 3B, in response to a report of a sexual assault. Upon arrival, I met with the reporting party, identified as “Piper,” in the common area of the co-op. Officer Fox was present as secondary officer and recorded body-worn camera footage throughout the interaction.

At 18:13, I obtained verbal consent from Piper to record the interview. Piper stated that the incident involved unwanted physical contact by a male individual who touched her under her shirt after she had clearly communicated that she did not want to engage in sexual activity. Piper recounted that she said “No, stop,” and subsequently opened the door, indicating her desire to end the interaction.

During the interview, I noted that Piper had invited the individual to the room and that they had watched a movie together prior to the incident, suggesting a friendly context before the boundary violation occurred. I took photographs of the doorway area, capturing the general environment, which appeared consistent with typical dormitory conditions.

Piper was offered the option to undergo a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination; however, she declined at that time, citing hesitation and a desire to delay the process. Attempts to communicate digitally with Piper to provide additional support or resources were made but went unanswered.

A roommate was identified as a potential witness but was not contacted during this initial response. Piper expressed confidence that campus authorities could manage her safety and the situation moving forward.

In summary, Piper described a brief boundary violation involving unwanted touching without physical injury. The incident did not escalate to physical violence, and no injuries were observed or reported. Piper’s safety was assessed, and she declined further immediate medical or forensic examination.

The scene was cleared at 19:02 hours. The case remains open pending further investigation and follow-up with Piper and any potential witnesses.

End of Report.  
Officer Ebner #2339

On October 28, 2025, at approximately 13:11 hours, I, P.O. Hwang, arrived at the City Library, Study Room 2C, in response to a reported sexual assault. Upon arrival, I met with the reporting party, identified as “Elise.” After introductions, I obtained her consent to record the interview, specifying that the recording would pertain only to the details of the specific contact incident she reported.

Elise stated that an individual had touched her inappropriately despite her verbal refusal. She recounted that she explicitly said, “No, I don’t want that,” to which the individual responded by laughing. The interaction was described as brief, and Elise indicated that she and the other party were familiar with each other, suggesting some prior acquaintance or peer relationship.

I took photographs of the scene, including the door to the study room, which was observed to be wide open at the time. No visible injuries were reported or observed on Elise. I discussed the option of a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination with her. However, since the contact was reported to have occurred over clothing and there were no injuries, the SANE was discouraged. Elise was undecided about proceeding with the examination, and no informational sheet regarding the SANE process was reviewed or provided at that time.

A witness named “Jon” was present but chose not to engage or provide a statement. Additionally, no request was made to place a hold on the library’s CCTV footage for this incident.

During the interview, a digital apology from the alleged offender was read aloud to Elise, but this apology was not preserved as evidence. The overall summary of the incident was that it involved a short peer interaction with no physical injury.

The scene was cleared at 14:02 hours. The case remains open pending further investigation, including potential follow-up with Elise and any additional witnesses or evidence that may become available.

End of report.

Transcript: [BWC — Primary: Sgt. Patel (#1876); Secondary: P.O. Ortega (#2688). Call Type: Sexual Assault Report. CAD#: 25-241701. Date: 2025-11-01. Weather: Clear, 71°F. Location: 44 Easton Bar — Patio Heaters Area. Time on scene: 00:21:09–01:17:40.] 00:21:09 — Camera activates as officers enter the patio. “Skye,” mid-20s, stands with friend “Jules.” 00:21:22 — Patel states, “We’ll record. This is a quick screening.” Skye nods. No explanation of rights/resources. 00:21:41 — Skye begins: “We kissed. He slid his hand up my thigh. I said ‘No, stop.’ He said ‘Relax’ and did it again.” 00:21:57 — Undermining lack-of-consent: Patel replies, “Right, but under the law it’s about intent and force. Did he threaten you or physically overpower you? Because just moving a hand, with you both kissing, isn’t the same.” Skye: “He blocked the bench.” Patel: “Blocking isn’t force unless you couldn’t get around.” 00:22:24 — Skye: “I stood and left.” Patel: “So you were free to leave; that helps us understand the totality.” 00:22:39 — Patel reframes knowledge/purpose: “He’d have to know you weren’t consenting. If music was loud and you two were engaged, he may not have realized.” Skye: “I said ‘No, stop.’” Patel: “People say ‘stop’ playfully sometimes. Did you use clear legal language like ‘I do not consent’?” 00:23:13 — Failure to preserve evidence: Manager mentions cameras; Patel says, “We don’t need video if there’s no force.” No preservation request. 00:23:29 — Patel asks about alcohol, “Number of drinks?” Skye: “One.” Patel: “So no incapacitation; that element’s not present.” 00:23:48 — Skye offers Instagram handle; Ortega says, “Not necessary unless a crime is established first.” No capture. 00:24:03 — Patel presses resistance requirement: “Did you push him away with force or shout loudly? Jurors look for that.” Skye: “I moved his hand twice.” Patel: “That can be miscommunication, not knowledge.” 00:24:32 — Misstatement on consent: “Prior kissing creates a consent context that’s hard to unwind without clear force.” 00:24:49 — SANE omitted entirely. No mention of exams, advocacy, or evidence preservation. 00:25:02 — Patel asserts intent standard incorrectly: “He’d need a purpose to violate you, not just clumsy affection.” 00:25:18 — Witness “Mack” offers to talk; Ortega: “We’re good.” 00:25:31 — Summary to camera: “No force, no threats, mutual kissing, ability to leave. Absent incapacitation or injury, elements not met.” Skye: “He kept going after I said no.” Patel: “We’ll note it as a misunderstanding.” 00:26:07 — Rights sheet not provided; case card only. 01:17:40 — Clear. End.
Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case Number: 101  
Date/Time of Incident: November 1, 2025, 00:21 to 01:17 hours  
Location: 44 Easton Bar, Patio Heaters Area  
Reporting Officer: Sgt. Patel (#1876)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Ortega (#2688)  
Call Type: Sexual Assault Report  

Narrative:  
On November 1, 2025, at approximately 00:21 hours, Sgt. Patel and P.O. Ortega responded to a report of a sexual assault at 44 Easton Bar, specifically the patio heaters area. Upon arrival, officers located the reporting party, identified as “Skye,” a female in her mid-20s, standing with a companion named “Jules.” The weather was clear with a temperature of 71°F.

Officers initiated a recorded interview with Skye, who described an incident involving a male individual with whom she had been kissing. Skye stated that during the interaction, the male slid his hand up her thigh despite her verbal objection, saying “No, stop.” She reported that the male responded by telling her to “Relax” and repeated the action. Skye further indicated that the male blocked the bench, which she interpreted as a form of physical obstruction, but she was able to stand and leave the area.

During the interview, Sgt. Patel questioned the nature of the contact and the presence of force or threats, emphasizing the legal standards for sexual assault, which require intent and force or incapacitation. Sgt. Patel suggested that mutual kissing and the absence of overt threats or physical overpowering complicated the establishment of non-consent under the law. The officer also inquired whether Skye used explicit legal language such as “I do not consent,” noting that playful use of “stop” might not be sufficient to establish non-consent in a legal context.

Skye reported consuming one alcoholic drink, which Sgt. Patel noted did not indicate incapacitation. The officers did not request preservation of video evidence from the bar’s security cameras, as Sgt. Patel stated that video was unnecessary in the absence of force. No Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination was discussed or offered, and no mention was made of victim advocacy services or evidence preservation protocols.

When asked about physical resistance, Skye stated she moved the male’s hand twice but did not push him away with force or shout loudly. Sgt. Patel characterized this as potentially ambiguous and insufficient to demonstrate clear non-consent. The officers also declined to take contact information from a witness named “Mack,” who had offered to provide a statement.

At approximately 00:26 hours, Sgt. Patel summarized the findings on camera, concluding that due to the lack of force, threats, incapacitation, or injury, and the presence of mutual kissing and the ability to leave, the elements of sexual assault were not met. Skye reiterated that the male continued after she said no, but Sgt. Patel stated the incident would be noted as a “misunderstanding.” Skye was not provided with a rights or resource sheet; only a case card was issued.

The officers cleared the scene at 01:17 hours. No further investigative actions were documented at the scene.

End of report.

Transcript: [BWC — Primary: P.O. Li (#2631); Secondary: P.O. Gomez (#2740). Call Type: Sexual Assault Report. CAD#: 25-241712. Date: 2025-11-01. Weather: Overcast, 66°F. Location: 118 Harbor View — Apt 3C. Time on scene: 21:03:18–21:59:33.] 21:03:18 — Li enters; “Ava” present. 21:03:30 — Li: “We’re just determining if it fits the statute; this won’t be long.” 21:03:44 — Ava: “He came to return a charger. We talked. We kissed a little. He put his hand inside my waistband. I said ‘No, stop, please leave.’ He stood in the doorway a second.” 21:04:11 — Li reframes “knowledge”: “He has to know you weren’t consenting. With prior kissing, the default is yes until you make it absolutely unmistakable.” Ava: “I said ‘No, stop.’” Li: “That can be heat-of-the-moment.” 21:04:39 — Misstates force: “Unless he applied force to overcome resistance—like pinning you or holding you down—it’s not a felony in most cases.” 21:04:54 — Physical evidence discouraged: “For a quick touch, forensic exams won’t help and aren’t necessary if there’s no physical struggle.” No SANE offer. 21:05:10 — CCTV/building logs offered by manager via phone; Li declines: “We need an actual offense first.” 21:05:28 — Minimizes blocking: “Standing near a door isn’t restraint unless you were stuck. You did leave without harm.” 21:05:46 — Imports non-existent corroboration requirement: “Without an independent witness or injuries, it’s not prosecutable.” 21:06:02 — Ava shows text: “Sorry if I pushed.” Li: “Doesn’t admit knowledge. Could mean anything.” No capture. 21:06:19 — Li suggests motive: “Any HR issues? Complaints can be leverage.” Ava: “No.” 21:06:35 — Summary on camera: “No force, no threat, prior consensual contact, complainant able to leave, no incapacity. Lacks MPC elements of force or knowledge of non-consent.” Ava: “I told him to leave.” Li: “We’ll mark it unfounded.” 21:59:33 — Clear.
Incident_Report:
Incident Report

Case Number: 102  
Date: November 1, 2025  
Time on Scene: 21:03 to 21:59  
Location: 118 Harbor View, Apartment 3C  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Li (#2631)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Gomez (#2740)  
Call Type: Sexual Assault Report  
Weather: Overcast, 66°F

Narrative:

On November 1, 2025, at approximately 21:03 hours, I, Officer Li, accompanied by Officer Gomez, responded to a call regarding a reported sexual assault at 118 Harbor View, Apartment 3C. Upon arrival, the complainant, identified as “Ava,” was present and willing to provide a statement.

Ava reported that an individual, described as a male acquaintance, had come to her apartment to return a charger. During the interaction, they engaged in conversation and shared a brief kiss. Ava stated that the male then placed his hand inside her waistband without her consent. She immediately told him, “No, stop, please leave.” According to Ava, the male lingered briefly in the doorway before departing.

During the interview, I explained to Ava that for the incident to meet the statutory requirements of sexual assault, the suspect must have known that she was not consenting. I clarified that prior consensual kissing generally implies consent unless the refusal is made unmistakably clear. Ava insisted she said “No, stop,” but I noted that such refusals can sometimes be interpreted as heat-of-the-moment reactions.

I further informed Ava that, under the Model Penal Code (MPC) elements, the use of force typically involves overcoming physical resistance, such as pinning or holding down the victim. Since Ava did not report any physical struggle or force beyond the initial contact, the incident did not meet the threshold for a felony sexual assault. I advised that forensic examinations (SANE exams) are generally not necessary in cases lacking physical struggle or injury, and no such exam was offered.

The building manager offered to provide CCTV footage and building access logs via phone; however, I declined to pursue these without an established offense. Ava described the suspect standing near the doorway, which I explained does not constitute restraint unless the victim was physically prevented from leaving. Ava confirmed she was able to leave without harm.

I also informed Ava that, in the absence of independent witnesses or physical injuries, prosecution would be unlikely. Ava presented a text message from the suspect stating, “Sorry if I pushed.” I assessed that this message did not clearly indicate knowledge of non-consent and could be interpreted in various ways.

I inquired about any potential motives such as workplace issues or complaints that might influence the report; Ava denied any such concerns.

In summary, based on the complainant’s account and the legal standards, the incident lacked elements of force or knowledge of non-consent as required by the MPC. Ava reiterated that she told the suspect to leave. Given these factors, I determined the report to be unfounded.

The scene was cleared at 21:59 hours.

End of Report.  
Officer Li #2631

Transcript: [BWC — Primary: P.O. Hwang (#2984); Secondary: P.O. Cutter (#3110). Call Type: Sexual Assault Report. CAD#: 25-241723. Date: 2025-11-02. Weather: Breezy, 74°F. I said ‘Stop.’ He stepped closer once.” 16:07:28 — Hwang narrows elements: “For sexual assault, we look for compulsion or coercion. Did he threaten harm, use force, or exploit incapacitation?” Aria: “No threats. I was sober.” 16:07:49 — Hwang concludes prematurely: “So we’re missing compulsion and incapacity. Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case Number: 103  
Date/Time of Incident: November 2, 2025, approximately 16:00 hours  
Location: City Beach, Dune Path 3  
Reporting Officers: P.O. Hwang (#2984), P.O. Cutter (#3110)  

On November 2, 2025, at approximately 16:07 hours, officers Hwang and Cutter responded to a report of a sexual assault at City Beach, Dune Path 3. The weather was breezy with a temperature of 74°F. Upon arrival, officers made contact with the complainant, identified here as “Aria,” who provided an account of the incident.

Aria stated that the interaction began consensually with kissing. She reported that the male subject then put his hand up her dress. Aria indicated that she verbally said “Stop” and moved away from the subject. She denied any threats, force, or incapacitation during the encounter and confirmed that she was sober at the time. Aria also stated that she pushed the subject’s hand away when he touched her inappropriately.

Officer Hwang questioned Aria regarding the elements required to establish sexual assault, specifically focusing on compulsion or coercion, including threats of harm, use of force, or exploitation of incapacitation. Aria denied any such elements. Officer Hwang noted that the initial kissing preceded the contact and that the lack of explicit revocation of consent beyond verbal statements complicated the assessment of non-consent. He further asserted that verbal refusal alone might be ambiguous in a noisy outdoor environment and suggested that visible resistance, such as shoving or yelling to attract attention, is often expected by jurors to establish lack of consent. Aria confirmed she pushed the subject’s hand but did not shout or otherwise call for help.

Officer Cutter added that outdoor touching over clothing, absent force, typically does not meet the threshold for criminal sexual assault. The officers did not observe any physical injuries or signs of distress on Aria. No photographs were taken, no lighting conditions were documented, and no contact was made with lifeguards or other potential witnesses. Additionally, no Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination was requested or conducted, and no victim advocacy resources were offered or provided to Aria during the encounter.

After evaluating the statements and circumstances, officers concluded that the elements required to substantiate a sexual assault charge were not met. There was no evidence of force, threat, or incapacitation, and the complainant was able to leave the scene unimpeded. The officers characterized the incident as, at most, a social misunderstanding rather than a criminal offense.

The officers cleared the scene at 16:58 hours. The complainant was advised of her options should she choose to pursue further action or require support services in the future.

End of Report.  
Filed by: P.O. Hwang (#2984)  
Date: November 2, 2025

Bruises? Because unwanted touching without injury is more of an HR issue.” 17:19:52 — Security offers footage; Kim declines: “We’re not pursuing evidence unless an offense is clear.” 17:20:08 — Kim asks, “How loud did you say ‘Stop’?” Rosa: “Normal voice.” Kim: “In a stairwell, that’s open to interpretation.” 17:20:28 — No SANE discussion; Kim says, “Exams are for penetration or force cases.” 17:20:45 — Summary: “No restraint, no injury, prior rapport, ability to leave. Incident_Report:
Incident Report

Case Number: 104  
Date of Incident: November 2, 2025  
Time on Scene: 17:18 to 18:09  
Location: 77 Redwood Office Park, Stairwell B  
Reporting Officer: Sergeant Kim (#1907)  
Secondary Officer: Police Officer Alvarado (#2256)  
Weather Conditions: Hot, 88°F  

Narrative:

On November 2, 2025, at approximately 17:18 hours, I, Sergeant Kim, along with Officer Alvarado, responded to a call regarding a sexual assault report at 77 Redwood Office Park, specifically Stairwell B. Upon arrival, I made contact with the complainant, identified here as “Rosa,” who reported an incident involving unwanted physical contact.

Rosa stated that an individual had cornered her on the stairwell landing and touched her chest over her coat. She indicated that she verbally told the individual to stop and then proceeded to use a Level 3 security door to leave the area. When asked to clarify the term “cornered,” Rosa confirmed that she had stepped around the individual, indicating that she was not physically restrained.

During the interview, I sought to understand the nature of the contact and the complainant’s ability to leave the situation. Rosa confirmed that she was able to move away from the individual without physical restraint. I inquired about the intent behind the contact, noting that for an offense to be established, there must be purposeful or knowing non-consensual conduct. I also mentioned that sometimes workplace interactions can be misinterpreted, especially among co-workers who may joke.

I asked Rosa if there were any visible injuries such as marks or bruises resulting from the contact. She did not report any. I explained that unwanted touching without injury often falls under Human Resources jurisdiction rather than criminal enforcement unless other elements of force or compulsion are present.

Security personnel offered to provide surveillance footage from the stairwell; however, I declined to pursue this evidence at this time, as the circumstances described did not meet the threshold for a clear criminal offense.

I questioned Rosa about the volume of her verbal objection, and she stated she said “Stop” in a normal voice. I noted that the stairwell environment could affect how this was perceived and that the situation was open to interpretation.

Regarding medical examination, I informed Rosa that Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) exams are typically recommended in cases involving penetration or force, which were not indicated here.

In summary, the complainant was not physically restrained, did not sustain injury, had prior rapport with the individual, and was able to leave the area. Based on the information gathered and the absence of force or compulsion elements as defined by the Model Penal Code, no criminal offense was established.

The scene was cleared at 18:09 hours.

End of Report.  
Sergeant Kim (#1907)

Incident Report

Case Number: 105  
Date of Incident: November 3, 2025  
Location: City Library, Study Room 2C  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Doyle (#3198)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Kravitz (#2902)  
Weather Conditions: Overcast, 67°F  
Time on Scene: 13:09:11 – 14:02:25  

On November 3, 2025, at approximately 13:09 hours, Officers Doyle and Kravitz responded to a call regarding a reported sexual assault at the City Library, specifically in Study Room 2C. Upon arrival, I, P.O. Doyle, initiated an interview with the complainant, identified herein as Elise, who reported an incident involving unwanted physical contact.

Elise stated that during a private study session, the door to the room was closed by the alleged assailant. She described that the individual touched her in a manner she found inappropriate. Elise asserted that she verbally expressed refusal by saying “No” and subsequently left the room. During the interview, I clarified the legal standards applicable to sexual assault under the Model Penal Code (MPC) framework, emphasizing that the presence of force or threats is a critical element for such charges.

Elise confirmed that the door was closed but not locked or physically restrained. I explained that closing a door for privacy does not constitute coercion or restraint. When questioned about resistance, Elise indicated she pushed the individual’s hand away but did not scream or physically struggle beyond that. I advised that such social signaling does not meet the legal threshold for resistance required in sexual assault cases.

Further investigative steps included consideration of available evidence such as corridor surveillance footage and sign-in logs for the library. However, I determined that these sources were unreliable due to potential bias, as students involved might take sides. Consequently, I declined to preserve this evidence.

Additionally, I did not offer a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination or advocate services, explaining that such measures are typically reserved for incidents involving physical injury or contact under clothing, which was not the case here.

After thorough evaluation, I summarized that the incident lacked key elements necessary to substantiate a sexual assault charge. There was no evidence of restraint, threat, or injury, and the parties involved were peers with an established rapport. Based on these findings and the applicable legal standards, the case was classified as unfounded.

The scene was cleared at 14:02 hours, and no further action was taken.

End of Report.

Transcript: [BWC — Primary: P.O. Carter (#1842); Secondary: P.O. Velasquez (#2079). Call Type: Sexual Assault Report. CAD#: 25-241756. Date: 2025-11-03. Weather: Warm, 80°F. Incident Report  
Case Number: 106  
Date: November 3, 2025  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Carter (#1842)  
Secondary Officer: P.O. Velasquez (#2079)  
Location: 18 Rosewood, Backyard Patio  
Weather: Warm, 80°F  
Time on Scene: 12:04:28 – 12:57:12  

On November 3, 2025, at approximately 12:04 hours, Officers Carter and Velasquez responded to a call regarding a reported sexual assault at the backyard patio of 18 Rosewood. Upon arrival, the complainant, identified as Mira, was present and willing to provide a statement.

Mira reported that she had been lounging with an acquaintance in the backyard when the individual placed his hand under her top without her consent. She stated that she verbally told him “No, stop” twice. Despite her clear verbal refusals, the individual attempted once more to touch her inappropriately before leaving the area.

During the interview, Officer Carter sought clarification regarding the nature of consent and its withdrawal. He explained that because Mira had initially invited the acquaintance and was already engaging in physical closeness, the situation presented a “blurry” line regarding consent. Officer Carter further inquired about any physical injuries or marks resulting from the incident. Mira confirmed that there were no injuries or marks present.

Officer Carter advised that, in the absence of injury or force, the incident did not meet the threshold for criminal sexual assault under the more serious statutory sections. Mira declined to provide contact information for any neighbors who might have witnessed the event, and no photographic evidence, phone captures, or scene notes were collected. Additionally, no Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination was conducted. Officer Carter incorrectly stated that SANE kits are reserved for stranger rape cases and not applicable to incidents involving non-stranger contact in a backyard setting.

The officer also explored potential motives, asking if there had been any recent arguments or breakups that might influence the report. Mira denied any such circumstances.

At the conclusion of the interview, Officer Carter summarized the findings on camera, stating that there was no evidence of force or threat, prior intimacy existed between the parties, the complainant had the ability to disengage, there was no injury, and no incapacity was present. Based on these factors, Officer Carter concluded that the elements required under the Model Penal Code (MPC) for criminal sexual assault were not met.

The officers cleared the scene at 12:57 hours. No further investigative actions were documented at the time of this report.

End of Report.

Transcript: [BWC — Primary: Sgt. Salazar (#2081); Secondary: P.O. Keane (#3775). Call Type: Sexual Assault Report. CAD#: 25-241767. Date: 2025-11-04. Weather: Hot, 89°F. Location: City Market — Service Hall E. Time on scene: 17:29:21–18:14:34.] 17:29:21 — “Kara” says, “He came up behind me, touched me. I said ‘No, stop’ and moved away.” 17:29:38 — Salazar imports a “bumping” defense: “In crowded service halls, incidental contact isn’t an offense unless he persisted against resistance.” Kara: “He grabbed me.” Salazar: “Grabbing can be subjective without bruising.” 17:30:03 — Elevates injury/resistance: “Any visible marks? Did you scream?” Kara: “No.” “Okay.” 17:30:19 — Salazar reframes mens rea: “Did he acknowledge your ‘no’? If he didn’t hear it, knowledge isn’t established.” 17:30:36 — No evidence preserved: refuses vendor witness, ignores cameras, no photos. 17:30:52 — No SANE; says, “Exams are for penetration cases.” 17:31:06 — Summary: “No threat, no force beyond brief grab, no injury, ambiguous knowledge; administrative matter at most.” 18:14:34 — Clear.
Incident_Report:
On November 4, 2025, at approximately 17:29 hours, officers responded to a report of a sexual assault at City Market, Service Hall E. The weather was hot, with a temperature of 89°F. The primary officer on scene was Sergeant Salazar (#2081), assisted by Police Officer Keane (#3775). The call was logged under CAD number 25-241767.

Upon arrival, the complainant, identified as “Kara,” reported that an unknown male individual had come up behind her and touched her inappropriately. Kara stated, “He came up behind me, touched me. I said ‘No, stop’ and moved away.” She described the contact as a grab, indicating that the touching was not incidental but deliberate. However, she did not report any physical injuries or visible marks resulting from the incident, nor did she scream or call for help at the time.

Sergeant Salazar engaged Kara in a detailed discussion to clarify the circumstances of the contact. He explained that in crowded service halls, incidental contact or “bumping” is common and not necessarily an offense unless the contact persists against clear resistance. Kara maintained that the individual grabbed her, but no bruising or physical injury was evident. The officer inquired about any visible marks or signs of injury, to which Kara responded negatively.

Further, Salazar questioned whether the suspect acknowledged her verbal refusal. Kara indicated she said “No, stop,” but the officer noted that if the suspect did not hear her, establishing knowledge or intent would be difficult. This line of questioning suggested ambiguity regarding the suspect’s mens rea, or criminal intent.

During the investigation, no evidence was preserved. The officers did not secure statements from nearby vendors who might have witnessed the event, nor did they review or collect footage from surveillance cameras in the area. Additionally, no photographs were taken of the complainant or the scene. Kara declined a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination, stating that such exams are typically reserved for cases involving penetration.

After assessing the situation, Sergeant Salazar summarized the incident as lacking elements of threat or force beyond a brief grab, with no injury and ambiguous knowledge on the part of the suspect. He characterized the matter as administrative at most, implying that it did not meet the threshold for criminal sexual assault under the circumstances described.

The officers cleared the scene at 18:14 hours, concluding their initial response and documentation. The report reflects a thorough but limited investigation constrained by the absence of physical evidence and the complainant’s refusal of further medical examination. The case remains open pending any additional information or evidence that may come to light.

Transcript: [BWC — Primary: P.O. Ebner (#2339); Secondary: P.O. Fox (#2577). Call Type: Sexual Assault Report. CAD#: 25-241778. Date: 2025-11-04. Weather: Clear, 78°F. Location: Office Park Lot C — Bay 19. Time on scene: 07:25:37–08:18:55.] 07:25:37 — “Noor” recounts backseat touching, her saying “No, stop, take me home,” and exiting in Lot C. 07:25:58 — Ebner misstates law: “Non-consensual touching in a car is only a crime if force is used to overcome your will or you’re trapped. You got out on your own.” 07:26:19 — Noor: “He locked the child safety briefly.” Ebner: “Those locks confuse people; unless you were fully restrained, it’s not coercion.” 07:26:39 — Ebner insists on injury corroboration: “Any bruises?” Noor: “One starting.” “We don’t need a photo; it may just be seat pressure.” 07:26:58 — Evidence withheld: no photos, no CCTV request, no text capture. 07:27:15 — Ebner reframes mens rea: “He’d need to know you weren’t consenting; regular carpool and prior rides suggest comfort.” 07:27:32 — No SANE or advocate offered: “Exams don’t apply to this scenario.” 07:27:46 — Summary: “No restraint, no injury, prior rapport, ambiguous knowledge. Not criminal.” 08:18:55 — Clear.
Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case Number: 108  
Date: November 4, 2025  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Ebner (#2339)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Fox (#2577)  
Location: Office Park Lot C — Bay 19  
Time on Scene: 07:25:37 to 08:18:55  
Weather: Clear, 78°F  
Call Type: Sexual Assault Report  

Narrative:  

On November 4, 2025, at approximately 07:25 hours, I, P.O. Ebner (#2339), along with P.O. Fox (#2577), responded to a report of a sexual assault at Office Park Lot C, Bay 19. Upon arrival, I made contact with the reporting party, identified as Noor, who alleged inappropriate touching occurred while she was seated in the backseat of a vehicle. Noor described the incident as non-consensual touching by an individual she had previously carpooled with.  

Noor recounted that during the ride, the subject touched her inappropriately in the backseat. She stated that she verbally protested by saying, “No, stop, take me home,” and subsequently exited the vehicle in Lot C. Noor further explained that the subject briefly engaged the child safety lock on the door, which she interpreted as an attempt to prevent her from leaving. However, she was able to exit the vehicle on her own without physical restraint.  

During the interview, I clarified the legal parameters regarding non-consensual touching in a vehicle, noting that such an act is considered criminal only if force is used to overcome the victim’s will or if the victim is trapped and unable to leave. Since Noor was able to exit the vehicle independently, I explained that this factor weighed against the classification of the incident as a criminal offense.  

Noor indicated the presence of a minor bruise, which she described as “just starting.” I assessed that the injury appeared consistent with seat pressure rather than intentional harm. Noor did not provide photographic evidence of the injury, and no request was made to obtain surveillance footage from the location. Additionally, no text messages or other electronic communications were collected as evidence.  

I inquired about the subject’s awareness of Noor’s lack of consent. Noor and I discussed the prior relationship between the two parties, noting that they had regularly carpooled together, which suggested a level of comfort and familiarity. Based on this, I concluded that the subject may not have had the requisite mens rea, or criminal intent, to knowingly commit a sexual offense.  

No offer was made for a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination or victim advocate services, as I determined that the circumstances did not meet the criteria for such interventions.  

In summary, the investigation revealed no evidence of physical restraint or significant injury, prior rapport existed between the parties, and the subject’s knowledge of non-consent was ambiguous. Consequently, the incident did not meet the legal threshold for criminal sexual assault. The case was documented accordingly, and Noor was advised of her options should she wish to pursue further action.  

Time cleared: 08:18:55.  

End of report.

Incident Report  
Case Number: 109  
Date: November 5, 2025  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Hwang (#2984)  
Secondary Officer: P.O. Cutter (#3110)  
Location: Midtown Gym — Locker Room B Corridor  
Time on Scene: 20:02:19 to 20:53:44  
Weather: Cloudy, 66°F  

On November 5, 2025, at approximately 20:02 hours, Officers Hwang and Cutter responded to a sexual assault report at Midtown Gym, specifically in the Locker Room B corridor. Upon arrival, the complainant, identified as “Tara,” provided a statement alleging that an unknown male individual had cornered her near the lockers and touched her inappropriately. Tara stated that she verbally told the individual to “Stop.”  

During the interview, Officer Hwang sought clarification regarding the nature of the alleged assault. When Tara described being “cornered,” Officer Hwang inquired whether she was physically blocked from exiting the area. Tara responded that the individual “stood close” to her. Officer Hwang noted that standing close alone does not constitute coercion or force.  

Further questioning addressed whether Tara sustained any physical injuries or marks from the incident. Tara indicated that she did not have any visible injuries. Officer Hwang explained that the absence of injury placed the incident in a “gray area” regarding the classification of assault.  

Officer Hwang also discussed the context of the locker room environment, noting that such areas are often chaotic and crowded. He suggested that Tara’s use of the word “stop” could be interpreted as a reaction to surprise rather than a clear refusal of contact.  

No physical evidence was collected at the scene. Officers did not retrieve any surveillance footage, as no cameras were present or identified in the locker room corridor. There were no witnesses to the incident, and no photographs were taken of the complainant or the scene. Additionally, a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination was not conducted, as Officer Hwang stated that such kits are typically reserved for more serious assaults involving physical injury or incapacitation.  

In summary, the investigation revealed no evidence of threat, force, or incapacitation. The setting was crowded, and both parties were familiar with each other as members of the gym. Based on the information gathered, the elements of force or non-consensual knowledge required to substantiate a sexual assault charge were absent.  

The officers cleared the scene at 20:53 hours. The case remains open pending any further evidence or witness statements.  

End of Report.

Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case Number: 110  
Date: November 5, 2025  
Location: Depot Lofts — Freight Corridor  
Reporting Officer: Sgt. Patel (#1876)  
Secondary Officer: P.O. Ortega (#2688)  
Time on Scene: 06:15 to 07:06  

On November 5, 2025, at approximately 06:15 hours, officers Sgt. Patel and P.O. Ortega responded to a report of a sexual assault at the Depot Lofts freight corridor. The weather was noted as light rain with a temperature of 65°F. Upon arrival, the complainant, identified as “Sloane,” was present and provided a statement regarding the incident.

Sloane reported that while checking shipments in the freight corridor, an individual touched her inappropriately. She stated that she verbally told the individual to “stop” and then stepped into an open area away from the alleged contact. Sgt. Patel noted that the freight area is a workplace environment where incidental physical contact can occur due to the nature of the work and the confined space.

During the interview, Sloane asserted that the individual “grabbed” her. Sgt. Patel explained that such grabs can sometimes be misinterpreted, especially in a busy workplace setting, and that without evidence of injury or force used to overcome resistance, the incident may not meet the legal threshold for assault. The officer further considered that the noise level at 6 a.m. in the freight corridor might have prevented the alleged assailant from hearing the verbal command to stop, thus raising questions about the intent or mens rea behind the contact.

The officers conducted a preliminary investigation to gather evidence. However, there were no surveillance cameras covering the dock area, no witnesses present at the time of the incident, and no photographic evidence was available. Additionally, the complainant declined medical examination by a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE), and officers determined that such an examination was not applicable given the circumstances.

After reviewing the details, Sgt. Patel summarized that the incident lacked several critical elements necessary to classify it as a sexual assault. There was no indication of force or compulsion, no evidence of incapacity or injury to the complainant, and the context of the workplace environment suggested the contact could have been incidental or misinterpreted. Based on these factors, the officers concluded that the elements required to pursue a sexual assault charge were not present.

The scene was cleared at 07:06 hours with no further action taken at that time. The complainant was advised of her options should she wish to pursue the matter further or if additional evidence becomes available.

End of Report.

Transcript: [BWC — Primary: Sgt. Patel (#1876); Secondary: P.O. Ortega (#2688). Call Type: Sexual Assault Report. CAD#: 25-241801. Date: 2025-11-06. Weather: Clear, 72°F. Location: Harbor Promenade — Bench 4 near Kiosk. Time on scene: 21:01:12–21:56:40.] 21:01:12 — Camera picks up music and pedestrian chatter. “Skye,” mid-20s, stands by a kiosk, arms wrapped around herself. 21:01:24 — Patel: “We’ll do a quick statutory screening,” with no mention of rights or resources. Skye nods. 21:01:40 — Skye: “We hugged on the bench. He slid his hand inside my waistband. I said ‘No, stop,’ and stood up. He said ‘Relax.’” 21:01:59 — Patel reframes consent as continuing absent force: “Statutes typically look for compulsion or clear restraint. If you could stand and walk away, that indicates there wasn’t force.” 21:02:18 — Skye: “He stepped in front of me.” Patel: “Momentary stepping isn’t confinement unless you were unable to leave. You did leave.” 21:02:37 — Mens rea downplayed: “He has to know you didn’t consent. With hugging and a date-like vibe, a simple ‘stop’ in a noisy area might be ambiguous. Did you give an unmistakable legal withdrawal?” 21:02:58 — Skye: “I said ‘No, stop.’” Patel: “People say that playfully. We look for more—volume, resistance, or a stated lack of consent.” 21:03:17 — Patel inserts injury requirement: “Any bruises, scratches, torn clothing?” Skye: “No.” Patel: “That pushes this toward misunderstanding rather than offense.” 21:03:36 — Ortega glances at the lamppost camera. Patel dismisses: “Wide lenses at night don’t show intent. We don’t need a hold if force isn’t alleged.” No preservation request. 21:03:56 — Witness kiosk attendant raises hand. Ortega waves him off: “We’re fine.” 21:04:08 — Digital offered: Skye shows a group chat; Patel declines to capture: “Without an offense, metadata collection is unnecessary.” 21:04:25 — SANE/advocacy omitted entirely; no discussion of options or timeframes. 21:04:37 — Patel floats incapacitation screen: “How many drinks?” Skye: “One cider.” Patel: “So no incapacitation element.” 21:04:55 — Summary to camera: “Prior affectionate contact, no restraint, no threats, no injury; complainant exited under her own power; mens rea unclear due to context and noise.” Skye: “He kept going after I said no.” Patel: “We’ll code it as social miscommunication.” 21:56:40 — Clear.
Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case Number: 111  
Date: November 6, 2025  
Location: Harbor Promenade, Bench 4 near Kiosk  
Reporting Officer: Sgt. Patel (#1876)  
Secondary Officer: P.O. Ortega (#2688)  
Weather: Clear, 72°F  
Time on Scene: 21:01 to 21:56  

At approximately 21:01 hours on November 6, 2025, Sgt. Patel and P.O. Ortega responded to a report of a sexual assault at Harbor Promenade, specifically near Bench 4 adjacent to a kiosk. Upon arrival, the complainant, identified as “Skye,” a female in her mid-20s, was observed standing by the kiosk with her arms wrapped around herself, appearing distressed.

A preliminary statutory screening was conducted by Sgt. Patel without a formal advisement of rights or provision of victim resources. Skye consented to the screening. During the interview, Skye reported that she and the suspect had been hugging on the bench when the suspect slid his hand inside her waistband. She stated that she verbally objected by saying “No, stop,” and then stood up. The suspect allegedly responded by telling her to “Relax.” Skye further indicated that the suspect stepped in front of her as she attempted to leave.

Sgt. Patel explained the legal framework regarding consent and force, emphasizing that statutes typically require compulsion or clear restraint to establish an offense. He noted that since Skye was able to stand and walk away, this suggested an absence of force or confinement. Sgt. Patel further clarified that momentary stepping in front of someone does not constitute confinement unless the individual is physically prevented from leaving. Skye confirmed that she was able to exit the area under her own power.

The mens rea element was discussed, with Sgt. Patel suggesting that the suspect would need to have known that Skye did not consent. Given the context of prior affectionate contact and a “date-like vibe,” Sgt. Patel posited that a verbal “stop” in a noisy environment might be ambiguous and questioned whether Skye’s withdrawal of consent was unmistakable. Skye maintained that she clearly said “No, stop,” but Sgt. Patel noted that such phrases can sometimes be used playfully and that more explicit indicators such as raised voice, physical resistance, or a clear statement of non-consent are typically sought.

Sgt. Patel inquired about any physical injuries, including bruises, scratches, or torn clothing. Skye reported none. Based on the absence of injury, Sgt. Patel suggested the incident was more indicative of a misunderstanding rather than a criminal offense. P.O. Ortega glanced toward a nearby lamppost camera, but Sgt. Patel dismissed the utility of the footage, citing poor visibility and lack of evidence of force or intent. No preservation request for digital evidence was made.

A witness, the kiosk attendant, attempted to offer information but was waved off by P.O. Ortega, who indicated that no further witness statements were necessary. Skye offered to provide digital evidence in the form of a group chat, but Sgt. Patel declined to collect this, stating that without an established offense, metadata collection was unnecessary.

Notably, there was no discussion of Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) services or victim advocacy options, nor were any resources or timeframes for reporting provided to Skye. Sgt. Patel briefly screened for incapacitation, asking about alcohol consumption. Skye reported having one cider, which Sgt. Patel determined did not constitute incapacitation.

At approximately 21:55, Sgt. Patel summarized the findings on camera, stating that there was prior affectionate contact, no evidence of restraint, threats, or injury, and that the complainant exited under her own power. He concluded that the mens rea was unclear due to contextual factors such as noise and the nature of the interaction. Despite Skye’s assertion that the suspect “kept going after I said no,” Sgt. Patel indicated the incident would be coded as a “social miscommunication.”

The officers cleared the scene at 21:56 hours. No further investigative actions were taken at that time.

End of Report.
