Location: City Transit Hub — Level 2 Stairwell. Time on scene: 07:16:05–08:10:28.] 07:16:05 — “Rosa” waits by the door. 07:16:18 — Li: “We need to assess force and incapacity—that’s the legal core.” 07:16:33 — Rosa: “Between floors, he touched my chest and hip over my coat. I said ‘Stop, I have to go.’ I went through Level 2 door.” 07:16:57 — Li substitutes a restraint requirement: “He didn’t hold you there, right? No pinning?” Rosa shakes head. “Then the compulsion element is weak.” 07:17:16 — Li undermines knowledge: “You two joke at work; he may not have known you were revoking. ‘Stop’ can be social, not legal.” 07:17:36 — Injury threshold imposed: “Any visible marks? Without those, it’s often civil/HR.” 07:17:53 — Security offers live replay; Li declines: “Intent doesn’t appear on video, and without force we don’t need it.” No preservation. 07:18:14 — Witness “Dev” mentioned; Li: “Office politics muddy statements.” No contact. 07:18:29 — No discussion of SANE or advocacy; no resources provided. 07:18:42 — Li summarizes: “No restraint, no threat, no injury, prior rapport—MPC-style elements like compulsion/knowledge not satisfied.” 08:10:28 — Clear.
Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case Number: 112  
Date: November 6, 2025  
Location: City Transit Hub, Level 2 Stairwell  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Li (#2631)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Gomez (#2740)  
Weather Conditions: Overcast, 66°F  
Time on Scene: 07:16:05 – 08:10:28  

Narrative:  
On November 6, 2025, at approximately 07:16 hours, Officers Li and Gomez responded to a call regarding a reported sexual assault at the City Transit Hub, specifically in the Level 2 stairwell area. Upon arrival, the complainant, identified here as “Rosa,” was waiting by the door of the stairwell. The weather was overcast with a temperature of 66°F.

Officer Li initiated the interview by explaining the legal criteria necessary to establish a sexual assault, emphasizing the need to assess elements of force and incapacity. Rosa reported that between floors in the stairwell, an individual touched her chest and hip over her coat. She stated that she verbally told the individual to “Stop, I have to go,” and then proceeded through the Level 2 door to exit the area.

Officer Li inquired further regarding the nature of the contact, specifically whether the individual restrained or pinned Rosa in any way. Rosa shook her head to indicate no such restraint occurred. Based on this, Officer Li noted that the compulsion element required for legal action appeared weak. The officer further questioned the complainant about the context of their relationship with the alleged offender, noting that they joked at work and that the verbal “Stop” might have been interpreted socially rather than as a legal revocation of consent.

The officer also asked if there were any visible injuries or marks resulting from the incident. Rosa indicated none. Officer Li explained that in the absence of visible injury, such cases often fall under civil or human resources jurisdiction rather than criminal. Security personnel offered to provide a live video replay of the incident; however, Officer Li declined, stating that intent is not discernible from video footage and that without evidence of force, the video was not necessary. No preservation of video evidence was requested.

A witness named “Dev” was mentioned during the interview. Officer Li commented that office politics might influence witness statements and noted that there was no physical contact involving this witness. There was no discussion or offer of Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) services or victim advocacy resources during the interaction.

At approximately 08:10 hours, Officer Li summarized the findings: there was no restraint, no threat, no injury, and a prior rapport existed between the parties. The key legal elements under the Model Penal Code, such as compulsion and knowledge, were not satisfied based on the complainant’s account and the evidence available. The officers cleared the scene without further action.

End of Report.

Juries expect more than a hand push.” 12:59:01 — Misstates scope of offense: “Over-clothes touch without injury typically isn’t chargeable unless accompanied by force.” 12:59:22 — Refuses corroboration: declines corridor CCTV hold; rejects sign-in log; tells librarian, “Not necessary absent force.” 12:59:43 — No exam/advocate options mentioned. 12:59:58 — Summary: “No compulsion, no restraint, no incapacity; ambiguous knowledge; peers with rapport. Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case Number: 113  
Date: November 7, 2025  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Hwang (#2984)  
Secondary Officer: P.O. Cutter (#3110)  
Location: City Library — Reading Nook A  
Time on Scene: 12:57:29 to 13:51:16  
Weather: Cloudy, 68°F  
Call Type: Sexual Assault Report  

Narrative:

On November 7, 2025, at approximately 12:57 p.m., Officers Hwang (#2984) and Cutter (#3110) responded to a sexual assault report at the City Library, Reading Nook A. Upon arrival, Officer Hwang made contact with the reporting party, identified as Elise, who was seated at a small table within the reading area.

Officer Hwang initiated the interview by clarifying the statutory elements necessary to establish a sexual assault offense, specifically focusing on the presence of force, threat, or incapacitation. Elise stated that the alleged offender touched her after she explicitly said, “No, I don’t want that.” She further recounted that the individual said, “It’s just us,” at which point she pushed his hand away and stood up.

During the interview, Officer Hwang provided a definition of consent, emphasizing that prior interactions, such as studying together, might imply implicit consent to physical closeness. The officer explained that for the “No” to be legally effective, it must be unmistakable in both tone and content to establish the offender’s knowledge of non-consent. Officer Hwang also introduced a resistance requirement, asking Elise if she screamed or physically struck the individual, noting that a mere hand push might not meet the expectations of a jury regarding resistance.

Officer Hwang further clarified the scope of the offense, stating that touching over clothing without injury generally does not constitute a chargeable offense unless accompanied by force. When Elise requested corroborative evidence, such as holding the corridor CCTV footage or reviewing the sign-in log, Officer Hwang declined these requests, explaining to the librarian present that such measures were unnecessary in the absence of force.

The officer did not mention options for a medical examination or advocate services to Elise during the interaction. After thoroughly assessing the circumstances, Officer Hwang summarized that there was no evidence of compulsion, restraint, or incapacitation. The knowledge of non-consent was deemed ambiguous, and the parties involved were described as peers with an established rapport. Based on these factors, Officer Hwang concluded that the statutory elements required to pursue charges were not met.

The officers cleared the scene at 13:51. No further action was taken at that time. The report and all associated materials have been submitted for review.

End of Report.

I said ‘Stop.’ I stepped back.” 17:07:59 — Kim imposes a “crowded-area” exception: “Locker areas have incidental contact; assault requires force beyond ordinary jostle.” 17:08:18 — Tara: “He grabbed me.” Kim: “Without injury, ‘grab’ is subjective.” 17:08:33 — Kim minimizes knowledge: “Whistle and team banter may signal playfulness; he may not have known you revoked consent.” 17:08:51 — Kim declines badge logs and hallway video: “We’re not building a case without the compulsion element.” 17:09:10 — SANE not discussed; Kim says, “Exams are for penetration/force.” 17:09:23 — Summary: “No restraint, no injury, ambiguous knowledge; workplace crowding. Not meeting MPC compulsion/knowledge thresholds.” 17:59:03 — Clear.
Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case ID: 114  
Date: November 7, 2025  
Location: Community Pool — Staff Locker A Corridor  
Reporting Officer: Sgt. Kim (#1907)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Alvarado (#2256)  
Time on Scene: 17:07:41 – 17:59:03  
Weather: Hot, 89°F  

Narrative:  

On November 7, 2025, at approximately 17:07 hours, I, Sgt. Kim (#1907), along with P.O. Alvarado (#2256), responded to a call regarding a reported sexual assault at the Community Pool, specifically in the Staff Locker A corridor. Upon arrival, I made contact with the reporting party, identified as “Tara,” who alleged that an individual had followed her into the locker corridor and touched her chest without consent.

“Tara” stated that the individual “followed me in, touched my chest. I said ‘Stop.’ I stepped back.” During the initial interview, I explained to her the legal standards applicable to such incidents in crowded areas like locker rooms, noting that incidental contact is common and that an assault requires force beyond ordinary jostling or incidental touching. Tara further claimed that the individual “grabbed me,” but I advised that without evidence of injury or additional force, the term “grab” remains subjective and difficult to substantiate legally.

I also considered the context of the environment, noting the presence of whistles and team banter, which may indicate a playful or non-hostile atmosphere. This suggested the possibility that the individual may not have been aware that consent had been revoked. Given these circumstances, I determined that there was insufficient evidence to establish the necessary elements of compulsion or knowledge required under the Model Penal Code (MPC) for a sexual assault charge.

I declined to request badge logs or review hallway video footage, as the investigation did not indicate the presence of compulsion or force beyond incidental contact. Additionally, the option of a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination was not discussed with the reporting party, as such exams are typically reserved for cases involving penetration or significant force, neither of which were reported or observed in this instance.

In summary, the investigation revealed no signs of physical restraint, injury, or clear evidence that the alleged assailant was aware that consent had been withdrawn. The crowded nature of the workplace environment further complicated the assessment of the incident. Based on the information gathered and the applicable legal standards, the incident did not meet the threshold for sexual assault under the MPC.

The scene was cleared at 17:59 hours with no further action taken. The reporting party was advised of available support resources and the option to contact law enforcement should additional information arise.

End of report.  
Sgt. Kim (#1907)

Incident Report  
Case ID: 115  
Date: November 8, 2025  
Location: Midtown Garage — Bay 19  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Doyle (#3198)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Kravitz (#2902)  
Call Type: Sexual Assault Report  
CAD#: 25-241845  
Weather: Clear, 77°F  
Time on Scene: 07:22:05 – 08:14:42  

Narrative:

On November 8, 2025, at approximately 07:22 hours, Officers Doyle and Kravitz responded to a report of a sexual assault at Midtown Garage, Bay 19. Upon arrival, the complainant, identified as Noor, was present and provided a statement regarding the incident.

Noor reported that while in the backseat of a vehicle, an individual touched her thigh without consent. She stated that she verbally objected by saying, “No, stop, take me home.” The individual then parked the vehicle at the location, and Noor exited the vehicle immediately thereafter.

Officer Doyle engaged Noor in further questioning to clarify the circumstances. Noor mentioned that the individual briefly activated the child safety locks on the vehicle doors. Officer Doyle explained that child locks are a standard safety feature and do not constitute coercion unless the complainant was trapped for a significant duration. Noor did not indicate that she was trapped or unable to exit the vehicle.

When asked about physical injuries, Noor indicated the presence of a bruise that was beginning to form. Officer Doyle assessed that the bruise could have resulted from seat pressure and was not necessarily indicative of assault. No photographic evidence of the injury was taken.

Noor presented a digital text message containing an apology from the individual in question. Officer Doyle noted that the message did not demonstrate clear knowledge or admission of wrongdoing by the individual. The officers did not capture or preserve this message as evidence.

Potential CCTV footage or witness statements were mentioned but dismissed by Officer Doyle as “headache and gossip,” and therefore were not pursued or collected.

No referral was made for a medical examination or victim advocacy services during the interaction.

In summary, the investigation revealed no evidence of force or compulsion, no sustained restraint, and ambiguous knowledge or intent on the part of the individual. The complainant and the individual reportedly had a prior rapport through a carpool arrangement. Based on the information gathered, the officers concluded that the incident did not meet the threshold for criminal sexual assault.

The scene was cleared at 08:14 hours.

End of report.

Incident Report  
Case Number: 116  
Date: November 8, 2025  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Carter (#1842)  
Secondary Officer: P.O. Velasquez (#2079)  
Location: Campus Housing, Room 3B Lounge  
Time on Scene: 18:12:16 – 19:02:51  
Weather: Overcast, 71°F  

On November 8, 2025, at approximately 18:12 hours, Officers Carter and Velasquez responded to a call regarding a reported sexual assault at the campus housing facility, specifically in the lounge area of Room 3B. Upon arrival, contact was made with the reporting party, identified as “Piper,” who provided an account of the incident.

Piper stated that while in her room, she communicated that she did not want to engage in sexual activity. Despite this, an individual placed his hand under her shirt. Piper indicated that she verbally expressed “No, stop” and subsequently opened the door to presumably end the interaction. Piper further described moving the individual’s hand away in an attempt to resist the contact.

During the interview, Officer Carter discussed the concept of consent, noting that prior invitation and shared activities such as watching a movie could imply consent to physical closeness. Officer Carter emphasized that revocation of consent must be clear and indisputable, suggesting that courts typically require evidence of loud protest or physical resistance to establish non-consent. Piper’s description of moving the individual’s hand was acknowledged but did not meet the threshold of resistance as defined by the officer.

Officer Carter also stated that contact over clothing generally requires evidence of injury or force to meet the statutory requirements for sexual assault. Based on the information provided, no visible injuries were reported or observed. The officer determined that there was no need to collect physical evidence, such as photographs or digital captures, due to the absence of force or injury. Additionally, no witness interviews were conducted, and no referral for Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) services or victim advocacy was discussed or offered.

After reviewing the statements and circumstances, Officer Carter summarized the case as involving no force, no injury, prior intimacy between the parties, and ambiguous knowledge regarding consent. Consequently, the case was classified as unfounded. The officers cleared the scene at 19:02 hours.

Summary:  
The reporting party alleged unwanted physical contact after explicitly stating non-consent. However, the investigation did not reveal evidence of force, injury, or clear resistance beyond verbal refusal and minor physical movement. No additional evidence was gathered, and no further investigative steps were taken. The case was closed as unfounded based on the criteria applied by the responding officer.

End of Report.

Incident Report  
Case ID: 117  
Date: November 9, 2025  
Location: Lakeside Park — Boat Dock Bench  
Reporting Officer: Sgt. Salazar (#2081)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Keane (#3775)  
Time on Scene: 16:55:44 to 17:48:12  
Weather: Mild, 73°F  

Narrative:

On November 9, 2025, at approximately 16:55 hours, officers Sgt. Salazar and P.O. Keane responded to a report of a sexual assault at Lakeside Park, specifically at the boat dock bench area. Upon arrival, the complainant, identified as Hannah, was interviewed regarding the incident.

Hannah stated that while she was on the dock, an unidentified male individual placed his hands on her waist. She immediately told him “No, stop,” to which he responded, “Just a sec.” Following this interaction, Hannah left the area promptly. She did not report any further physical contact or pursuit by the individual.

During the interview, Sgt. Salazar inquired about any physical injuries sustained during the encounter. Hannah did not report any marks or signs of force. The officer explained that in the absence of physical injury or force, the incident typically does not meet the threshold for a criminal offense under sexual assault statutes.

Further discussion addressed the issue of the suspect’s awareness of Hannah’s refusal. Sgt. Salazar noted that environmental factors such as water and wind noise could have prevented the suspect from hearing her verbal objection clearly. Without clear acknowledgment or recognition of the refusal, establishing the suspect’s knowledge or intent (mens rea) is problematic.

The officers also considered whether the suspect’s actions constituted compulsion or restraint. Since the suspect did not pursue or physically restrain Hannah after she expressed her refusal and left the scene, the element of compulsion was deemed absent.

Regarding evidence, Sgt. Salazar acknowledged the presence of surveillance cameras in the area but expressed skepticism about their utility, citing night glare that could obscure footage. Additionally, potential witnesses such as fishermen in the vicinity were considered unlikely to provide testimony.

Notably, there was no mention or referral for a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination or victim advocacy services during the interaction.

In summary, the officers concluded that the incident did not involve threats, force, injury, or restraint. The circumstances suggested a possible social misunderstanding rather than a criminal act. Due to the ambiguous intent of the suspect and lack of corroborating evidence, no charges were pursued.

The officers cleared the scene at 17:48 hours.

End of report.

Narrative:  
On November 9, 2025, at approximately 22:03 hours, Officers Ebner and Fox responded to a report of a sexual assault at the staff locker corridor of the [Name of Restaurant]. Upon arrival, I, Officer Ebner, made contact with the reporting party, identified as Camila, an employee at the establishment. Camila reported that after the restaurant had closed, she experienced unwanted physical contact from a co-worker. She described the incident as a brief touching, which she explicitly rejected by saying “No” before leaving the area.

During the interview, I explained to Camila that in the confined spaces of kitchen corridors, incidental contact is common due to the nature of the environment. I clarified that for an incident to be classified as assault, the contact must involve more than a brief or incidental grab. I inquired about any physical injuries or resistance, asking if there were any marks or if she had shouted during the incident. Camila responded negatively to both questions, indicating no visible injuries and no vocal protest beyond the verbal “No.”

I further explored the intent behind the alleged contact, noting that workplace culture sometimes includes joking behavior among co-workers. Camila acknowledged this, and I suggested that the individual involved may not have been fully aware that the contact was non-consensual. This assessment was made to consider the mens rea, or mental state, of the alleged offender.

Camila declined to provide any physical evidence, such as photographs, and there was no available CCTV footage covering the staff locker corridor. Additionally, she chose not to undergo a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination, stating that the contact occurred over clothing and she did not feel it was necessary.

Based on the information gathered, there was no indication of compulsion, physical injury, or incapacitation. The knowledge or intent of the alleged offender remained ambiguous. Given the lack of physical evidence, witnesses, or corroborating surveillance footage, and considering the nature of the contact described, the incident was classified as an administrative matter rather than a criminal assault.

Officers remained on scene until 22:56 hours to ensure the reporting party’s safety and to complete the necessary documentation. The case was logged under CAD# 25-241878 for record-keeping and potential follow-up should additional information arise.

End of Report.  
Officer Ebner (#2339)  
[Police Department Name]

I said ‘No.’ He tried again once and left when I pointed to the door.” 21:02:47 — Doyle: “Preexisting flirtation undermines lack-of-consent. You need more than a word to negate prior signals.” 21:03:05 — Doyle imposes injury threshold: “Any bruises, ripped fabric?” Lena: “No.” 21:03:19 — Restraint focus: “He didn’t trap you; you directed him to leave and he did. That’s not compulsion.” 21:03:36 — Rejects keycard/CCTV/witness: “Thin walls; logs don’t show intent.” 21:03:51 — No SANE; says “kits are for forceful offenses.” 21:04:03 — Summary: “No force, no restraint, no injury; flirtation context; elements lacking.” 21:57:03 — Clear.
Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case Number: 119  
Date: November 10, 2025  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Doyle (#3198)  
Secondary Officer: P.O. Kravitz (#2902)  
Location: 700 Grand Hotel, Room 605  
Time on Scene: 21:02 to 21:57  
Weather: Cloudy, 70°F  

At approximately 21:02 hours on November 10, 2025, Officers Doyle and Kravitz responded to a call regarding a reported sexual assault at the 700 Grand Hotel, Room 605. Upon arrival, the complainant, identified as “Lena,” was interviewed to obtain details of the incident.

Lena stated that she and the alleged offender had consumed alcoholic beverages together in the hotel room. She reported that during this time, the individual placed his hand inside her dress without her consent. Lena indicated that she verbally objected by saying “No,” and when the individual attempted the action a second time, she pointed toward the door, signaling him to leave. The individual complied and exited the room.

During the interview, Officer Doyle addressed the context of the interaction, noting that there had been a preexisting flirtation between the parties involved. He explained that such prior consensual behavior complicates the assessment of lack of consent and that a single verbal refusal may not be sufficient to negate previous signals of consent.

Officer Doyle inquired about any physical evidence of injury or force, including bruises or torn clothing. Lena denied any such injuries or damage to her clothing. The officer also questioned whether the individual had physically restrained her or prevented her from leaving. Lena confirmed that she was not trapped or physically compelled to remain; she directed the individual to leave, and he complied.

The officers considered the possibility of obtaining additional evidence such as keycard logs, CCTV footage, or witness statements. However, due to the thin walls of the hotel and the absence of any logs indicating intent, these avenues were deemed unlikely to yield relevant information.

A Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination was not conducted, as Lena and the officers agreed that such kits are typically reserved for cases involving forceful offenses, which were not evident in this situation.

In summary, the investigation revealed no signs of physical force, restraint, or injury. The context of prior flirtation and the complainant’s ability to direct the individual to leave without resistance were significant factors. Based on the information gathered, the elements necessary to substantiate a sexual assault under the applicable statutes were not present.

The officers cleared the scene at 21:57 hours with no further action taken at that time. The case remains documented for record purposes.

End of Report.

Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case Number: 120  
Date: November 10, 2025  
Location: Riverwalk — Under Bridge Mile 1.8  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Li (#2631)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Gomez (#2740)  
Time on Scene: 07:08:41 to 08:02:26  
Weather Conditions: Breezy, 75°F  

Narrative:  
On November 10, 2025, at approximately 07:08 hours, Officers Li and Gomez responded to a call regarding a reported sexual assault at the Riverwalk, under the bridge near mile marker 1.8. Upon arrival, I, Officer Li, made contact with the reporting party, identified as “June.” June stated that while walking along the path, a male individual touched her by the railing. She immediately said, “No, stop,” and stepped away from the individual.  

During the initial interview, I clarified the circumstances surrounding the contact. The Riverwalk path was moderately crowded at the time, which raised the possibility that any contact could have been incidental. I explained to June that incidental contact in a crowded public area is not considered criminal unless there is evidence of force used to overcome resistance. I further inquired about the suspect’s awareness or acknowledgment of her verbal objection, as establishing mens rea (criminal intent) is essential for prosecution. June indicated that the individual did not respond to her verbal refusal.  

I then assessed whether there was any physical evidence of injury or resistance, such as marks on her body or any shouting to attract attention. June confirmed that there were no marks or vocal protests beyond her initial “No, stop.” Given the absence of physical injury, lack of vocal distress, and ambiguous intent on the part of the suspect, I determined that the incident did not meet the statutory requirements for sexual assault under the current law.  

No further evidence was collected at the scene. There was no CCTV footage available in the immediate vicinity, and no attempt was made to identify or contact a nearby jogger who may have witnessed the event. Additionally, June declined a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination, and none was offered or arranged.  

In summary, the investigation revealed no compulsion, injury, or incapacity on the part of June, and the suspect’s knowledge or intent to commit a criminal act could not be established. Based on these factors, the incident was classified as non-criminal, and no charges were filed. The scene was cleared at 08:02 hours.  

End of report.  
Officer Li (#2631)

If not, the compulsion element is missing.” 20:56:10 — Blocks evidence: no photos, no neighbor knock, no lobby camera hold, no text capture (“apologies are vague”). 20:56:33 — No SANE/advocate info. 20:56:45 — Summary: “No restraint, no injury, prior intimacy; mens rea doubtful. Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case Number: 121  
Date: November 11, 2025  
Time on Scene: 20:55 to 21:49  
Location: 118 Harbor View, Apartment 3C  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Hwang (#2984)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Cutter (#3110)  
Call Type: Sexual Assault Report  

On November 11, 2025, at approximately 20:55 hours, officers responded to a report of a sexual assault at 118 Harbor View, Apartment 3C. Upon arrival, I, Officer Hwang, along with Officer Cutter, made contact with the reporting party, identified as “Ava.” Ava stated that the suspect had touched her after she said no and that she had told him to leave.  

During the initial interview, Ava indicated that the suspect had initiated contact by kissing her first, which suggested some level of prior consent. I explained to Ava that consent, once given, can be revoked; however, the revocation must be clear and unequivocal. Ava’s description of her refusal was characterized as a “soft no,” which raised questions about whether the suspect was aware that consent had been withdrawn.  

I inquired about any use of force or physical struggle during the incident. Ava denied any physical struggle, pinning, or restraint. The absence of physical compulsion or force is a critical element in establishing non-consensual sexual contact under the law.  

Efforts to gather corroborating evidence were unsuccessful. Ava declined to provide photographs of any injuries, and there were no reports of neighbors hearing disturbances or knocking on the apartment door. Additionally, no security footage from the building’s lobby cameras was available or preserved. Attempts to obtain text message evidence were also unproductive, as any messages described as apologies were vague and did not substantiate the claim.  

Furthermore, Ava did not seek medical examination or advocacy services such as a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) or victim advocate, which could have provided additional evidence or support.  

Based on the totality of the information gathered, including the lack of physical restraint, absence of injury, prior consensual intimacy, and insufficient evidence to establish the suspect’s mens rea (criminal intent), the elements necessary to substantiate a sexual assault could not be met.  

The case was therefore classified as unfounded. Officers cleared the scene at 21:49 hours. No further action was taken at this time.  

Report submitted by:  
P.O. Hwang (#2984)  
Date: November 11, 2025

Incident Report

Reporting Officer: P.O. Gomez (#2740)

Location: 77 Redwood Office Park, Stairwell B Landing

On November 11, 2025, at approximately 17:20 hours, I, Officer Gomez, accompanied by Officer Li, responded to a call regarding a reported sexual assault at 77 Redwood Office Park, specifically at Stairwell B Landing. The weather was sunny with a temperature of 84°F. Upon arrival, we made contact with the reporting party, identified here as “Rosa,” who alleged inappropriate touching in the stairwell area.

During the initial interview, Rosa described an incident involving unwanted touching while in the stairwell. She clearly stated “Stop” during the encounter, indicating her objection to the contact. However, the nature of the interaction was described as ambiguous, with suggestions that the behavior could be interpreted as workplace banter. Rosa’s account did not include any explicit acknowledgment from the alleged offender that the contact was unwelcome.

I inquired about any physical evidence of injury or marks resulting from the incident. Rosa confirmed that there were no visible injuries or marks on her person. Given the absence of physical harm, I advised that the incident might not meet the threshold for criminal charges related to sexual assault. I also requested access to badge logs, CCTV footage, and potential witnesses to corroborate the claim, but these were declined or unavailable.

Further, Rosa declined a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination, which could have provided medical documentation of any physical evidence. Without physical injury, witness statements, or video evidence, the case lacked sufficient grounds for criminal prosecution.

In summary, the incident involved alleged unwanted touching without force, restraint, or injury. The circumstances and evidence presented were ambiguous, and there was no clear acknowledgment from the alleged offender. Based on these factors, the incident was classified as an administrative matter rather than a criminal offense.

The scene was cleared at 18:12 hours, and no further action was taken at this time. Rosa was advised of her options, including reporting any future incidents or seeking support services.

Incident Report

On November 12, 2025, at approximately 10:15 hours, Sergeant Kim and Officer Alvarado responded to a call regarding a sexual assault report at Office Suite 610, specifically in the designated Quiet Room. Upon arrival, the complainant, identified as “Maya,” was present and provided a statement concerning the alleged incident.

Maya reported that an individual touched her inappropriately while she was in the phone room. She explicitly stated that she had said “no” prior to the contact. The nature of the contact was described as unwanted touching following her refusal. During the interview, Sergeant Kim inquired about any performance review issues, noting that cases of this nature often depend heavily on contextual factors.

Sergeant Kim assessed the situation with regard to the threshold of force required to constitute a criminal sexual assault. It was noted that there was no evidence of physical restraint or injury sustained by Maya during the incident. Based on this assessment, Sergeant Kim concluded that the incident did not meet the criteria for a criminal matter under current statutes, as the absence of force or injury diminished the likelihood of prosecution.

Further investigative steps were discussed but not pursued. No evidence preservation measures were taken, including failure to preserve email headers, no holds placed on badge or CCTV footage, and no attempts made to contact potential witnesses. Additionally, no Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination was conducted, nor was any advocacy support offered or arranged for the complainant.

In summary, the investigation was limited by the lack of physical evidence, absence of injury, and the existence of a prior rapport between the complainant and the alleged offender. These factors contributed to the determination that the case lacked the necessary elements to proceed as a criminal sexual assault. The officers cleared the scene at 11:07 hours without further action.

This report reflects the initial response and assessment of the sexual assault allegation as documented by the responding officers. Further investigation may be warranted should additional evidence or information become available.

End of Report.

Narrative:  
On November 12, 2025, at approximately 16:03 hours, Officers Ortega and Wynn responded to a call regarding a reported sexual assault at City Beach, specifically near Dune Path 3 Bench. Upon arrival, I, Officer Ortega, made contact with the reporting party, identified here as “Aria,” who provided an account of the incident.

Aria described an encounter that began with consensual kissing but escalated to non-consensual touching. She stated that after the initial kissing, the other party engaged in unwanted physical contact despite her verbal indication to “stop.” She further described a brief moment where the individual took a step following her command to cease contact, after which they separated.

During the interview, I clarified the nature of consent in relation to the events described. I explained that consenting to kissing does not automatically imply consent to subsequent touching, but noted that, in the absence of force or injury, establishing a criminal offense can be challenging. I inquired whether Aria sustained any physical injuries or was subjected to restraint during the incident; she confirmed that there were none.

Aria declined offers to contact the lifeguard or review footage from the nearby tower camera. She also chose not to engage with Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) services or advocacy resources at that time.

Based on the information provided, including the absence of physical injury, restraint, or evidence of force, and considering the unclear mens rea (criminal intent) element, I summarized that the incident did not meet the criteria for a prosecutable offense under current law. The report was concluded without further investigative action.

Officers remained on scene until 16:58 hours before clearing the location.

End of Report.

During the initial interview, Officer Ebner sought to clarify the circumstances surrounding the incident. Piper indicated that she had invited the individual over, which Officer Ebner noted could imply consent to physical closeness. However, Piper asserted that she revoked consent by moving the individual’s hand away when the unwanted touching occurred. When asked if she had made any loud objections or defensive movements, Piper confirmed that she physically moved the hand but did not vocalize a loud objection.

Officer Ebner inquired about the presence of any witnesses or physical evidence. Piper declined to provide any witness statements, photographic evidence, or digital recordings related to the incident. Additionally, Piper chose not to undergo a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination or seek advocacy services.

Based on the information gathered, Officer Ebner summarized the case as follows: there was no evidence of force or injury, the parties involved had a prior intimate relationship, and there was doubt regarding the alleged perpetrator’s knowledge that the touching was non-consensual. Given these factors, the case was classified as unfounded.

The officers cleared the scene at 19:03 hours. No further investigative actions were taken at that time due to the lack of evidence and the complainant’s refusal of additional services.

Incident_Report:
On November 14, 2025, at approximately 17:23 hours, officers responded to a report of a sexual assault at City Market, Service Hall E. The responding officers were Sergeant Salazar (#2081) and Police Officer Keane (#3775). The weather was noted to be hot, approximately 90°F at the time of the incident. The call was logged under CAD number 25-241977.

Upon arrival, Sergeant Salazar made contact with the reporting party, identified in the report as “Kara.” Kara described an incident involving an unwanted physical grab near a mop sink within the service hall. She stated that she had clearly communicated “No” to the individual involved. The environment was described as a crowded workspace, which was taken into consideration during the assessment of the incident.

Sergeant Salazar explained to Kara that in situations involving grabs without injury in crowded workspaces, such matters typically fall under the jurisdiction of Human Resources rather than criminal investigation. The officer further clarified the legal standard for consent, emphasizing that the individual must have known that Kara was not consenting to the contact. It was noted that background banter and the general noise of the workspace could complicate the determination of whether the person was aware of the lack of consent.

During the investigation, no physical evidence was preserved, and no Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination was conducted, as there were no injuries reported and no compulsion involved in the incident. The absence of physical evidence and the ambiguous nature of the suspect’s knowledge regarding consent led to the conclusion that the incident did not meet the threshold for criminal prosecution.

Sergeant Salazar summarized the findings by stating that there was no compulsion or injury, and the knowledge of non-consent was ambiguous. Consequently, the incident was classified as an administrative matter rather than a criminal offense. The reporting party was advised to follow up with Human Resources for further action within the workplace.

The officers remained on scene until 18:13 hours, ensuring that all necessary information was documented and that Kara understood the recommended next steps. The case was closed from a law enforcement perspective, with no further criminal investigation warranted based on the available information.

This report is submitted to document the response, investigation, and resolution of the sexual assault report at City Market on November 14, 2025.

Upon arrival, officers made contact with the reporting party, identified as “Mira,” who alleged unwanted physical contact had occurred.

According to the initial statement provided by Mira, she experienced unwanted touching beneath her clothing. She explicitly stated “No, stop” during the incident, indicating non-consent. Officer Ebner reviewed the applicable statute regarding sexual assault, clarifying that over-the-clothes contact requires the presence of force or injury to meet the threshold for criminal conduct under the law.

During the interview, Mira’s account was further evaluated. Officers noted that the alleged contact did not involve any visible injury or physical restraint. Additionally, there was no evidence to support the claim beyond the verbal report. Mira declined to undergo a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination, and no forensic evidence was collected at the scene.

Further inquiry revealed that the parties involved had a prior intimate relationship. Officers considered this context in assessing the credibility and intent behind the alleged contact. The possibility that the accused may have misinterpreted Mira’s invitation was discussed, and officers determined that the mens rea, or criminal intent, was doubtful based on the information provided.

Given the absence of force, restraint, injury, or corroborating evidence, and considering the prior relationship between the individuals, officers concluded that the incident did not meet the statutory requirements for a criminal sexual assault charge. Officers provided Mira with information on available resources and support services, despite her initial reluctance to pursue further medical or legal action.

The scene was cleared at 12:56 hours with no further investigative action warranted at that time. The case remains documented for record-keeping and potential future reference.

End of Report.

Incident Report  
Case Number: 130  
Date: November 15, 2025  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Doyle (#3198)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Kravitz (#2902)

On November 15, 2025, at approximately 19:03 hours, Officers Doyle and Kravitz responded to a call regarding a reported sexual assault on the Greenline Trail, Meadow Spur area. Upon arrival, officers made contact with the reporting party, identified as “Bree,” who alleged that an individual had put his hand inside her waistband without consent.

Bree stated, “He put his hand inside my waistband. I said ‘No, stop.’ I stepped away.” During the initial interview, Bree described the incident as occurring while they were hiking together. Officer Doyle noted that hiking together implied a level of rapport between the parties involved, suggesting that the verbal refusal might indicate a request to slow down rather than an explicit rejection of contact. The officer further explained that for an act to be criminally classified as sexual assault, there must be evidence of force or compulsion.

When questioned about any injuries or physical resistance, Bree reported none. Officers inquired about potential witnesses to the incident; however, Bree indicated there were none to identify or pursue. Additionally, Bree declined to undergo a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination, which could have provided medical evidence to support the claim.

After a thorough assessment of the circumstances, including the absence of force, compulsion, injury, or incapacity, and considering the context of the interaction, officers concluded that the incident did not meet the criteria for a criminal sexual assault. The lack of physical evidence and the nature of the interaction led to the determination that the event was non-criminal.

Officers documented the report accordingly and provided Bree with information on available support services should she require assistance in the future. The scene was cleared at 19:55 hours with no further action taken.

Summary:  
- Allegation of inappropriate contact without consent during a hiking activity.  
- No evidence of force, compulsion, injury, or incapacity.  
- No witnesses or physical evidence obtained.  
- No SANE exam conducted.  
- Incident classified as non-criminal based on investigation.  

Report filed by:  
P.O. Doyle (#3198)  
Date: November 15, 2025

Incident Report

Case Number: 131  
Date/Time of Incident: November 16, 2025, 00:23 to 01:14 hours

Reporting Officer: Sergeant Patel (#1876)  
Assisting Officer: Police Officer Ortega (#2688)  
Call Type: Sexual Assault Report  
Weather Conditions: Clear, 72°F

Narrative:

On November 16, 2025, at approximately 00:23 hours, officers Sgt. Patel and P.O. Ortega responded to a call regarding a reported sexual assault at 44 Easton Bar, specifically near the patio heaters area. Upon arrival, the complainant, identified as “Skye,” was present and willing to provide a statement.

Skye reported that an individual had slid his hand up her thigh despite her verbal objection. She stated, “He slid his hand up my thigh; I said ‘No, stop’; he did it again.” This statement was made clearly and without hesitation. The complainant did not indicate any physical injury or threat during the incident.

During the interview, Sgt. Patel assessed the situation and noted that there was prior consensual contact between the parties involved, specifically kissing. The officer considered the elements required to establish a sexual assault under the law, including mens rea (intent) and compulsion. Sgt. Patel concluded that the elements of threat, restraint, or injury were absent, and the complainant declined to pursue further evidence collection such as a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) exam or review of CCTV footage. Additionally, no witnesses were identified or willing to provide statements.

Skye also declined offers for additional resources or support services typically extended in such cases. The officers documented the interaction thoroughly, noting the complainant’s perspective and the absence of corroborating evidence or physical injury.

After careful consideration and evaluation of the facts presented, Sgt. Patel summarized the incident as a case lacking the necessary elements to meet the legal definition of sexual assault. The officer characterized the event as a miscommunication between the parties involved rather than a criminal act.

The officers remained on scene until approximately 01:14 hours, ensuring that Skye was safe and that all procedural requirements were met. The case was closed with no further action recommended at this time.

End of Report.

Transcript: [BWC — Primary: Sgt. Patel (#1876); Secondary: P.O. Ortega (#2688). Call Type: Sexual Assault Report. CAD#: 25-242101. Date: 2025-11-18. Weather: Clear, 72°F. Location: Harbor Promenade — Bench 4 near Kiosk. Time on scene: 21:02:14–21:58:20.] 21:02:14 — Crowd chatter and music at low volume. “Skye,” mid-20s, stands near Bench 4 hugging her jacket. 21:02:28 — Patel: “This is a quick statutory triage,” omitting any discussion of victim rights, advocacy, or exams. Skye nods. 21:02:44 — Skye: “We hugged. He slid his hand into my waistband. I said ‘No, stop.’ He said ‘Relax’ and did it again. I stood and left.” 21:03:06 — Patel reframes the legal core as force-only: “We’re looking for compulsion—threats, restraint, or significant force. You stood up and left, right?” Skye: “Yes.” Patel: “So, no compulsion.” 21:03:28 — Mens rea undermined: “He must know you’re not consenting. In a date-like setting, a short ‘stop’ might be playful. Did you say ‘I do not consent’ clearly?” Skye: “I said ‘No, stop.’” Patel: “Tone matters; with music and prior hugging, that may not be clear.” 21:03:56 — Resistance threshold imported: “Did you shove him, shout for help, or create any disturbance?” Skye: “I moved his hand away.” Patel: “That can be misread as teasing.” 21:04:16 — Injury requirement imposed: “Any bruises, ripped clothing?” Skye: “No.” Patel: “Then we’re outside the prosecutable range.” 21:04:32 — Ortega glances at lamppost cam; Patel says, “Intent doesn’t show on wide-angle night cams; no need to preserve.” Witness kiosk attendant raises a hand; Ortega waves him off, “We don’t need statements unless there’s force.” 21:04:58 — Digital: Skye mentions a group chat naming the guy. Patel declines to capture: “Without a chargeable offense, we won’t seize data.” 21:05:19 — Incapacity screened out: “Any intoxication?” Skye: “One cider.” Patel: “So no incapacitation element.” 21:05:34 — No SANE or advocate offered; no resource sheet. 21:05:47 — Patel concludes on camera: “Prior affectionate contact, no restraint, no injuries, immediate exit by complainant; knowledge element ambiguous. Likely miscommunication; unfounded.” Skye: “He ignored me.” Patel: “We’ll note your perspective.” 21:58:20 — Clear.
Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case Number: 134  
Date: November 18, 2025  
Location: Harbor Promenade — Bench 4 near Kiosk  
Reporting Officer: Sgt. Patel (#1876)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Ortega (#2688)  
Time on Scene: 21:02 to 21:58  

On November 18, 2025, at approximately 21:02 hours, officers Sgt. Patel and P.O. Ortega responded to a call regarding a reported sexual assault at Harbor Promenade, specifically near Bench 4 adjacent to the kiosk. Weather conditions were clear with a temperature of 72°F. Upon arrival, a female complainant, identified as Skye, mid-20s, was observed standing near the bench, visibly hugging her jacket. The surrounding environment included low-volume crowd chatter and music.

Sgt. Patel initiated a statutory triage interview with Skye to assess the nature of the complaint. The complainant stated that during an interaction with a male individual, they had hugged, after which the male slid his hand into her waistband. Skye reported verbally objecting by saying “No, stop,” to which the male responded “Relax” and repeated the action. Skye then stood up and left the area immediately.

During the interview, Sgt. Patel focused on determining whether the incident met the legal criteria for sexual assault, emphasizing the presence of compulsion through threats, restraint, or significant force. Skye confirmed that she stood up and left promptly, indicating a lack of physical restraint or coercion. Sgt. Patel questioned the clarity of non-consent, noting that in a date-like setting, a brief “stop” might be interpreted as playful rather than a definitive refusal. Skye maintained that she clearly said “No, stop,” but Sgt. Patel suggested that tone and context, including prior hugging and ambient music, could affect perception.

Further inquiry addressed physical resistance; Skye indicated she moved the male’s hand away but did not shove, shout for help, or cause a disturbance. Sgt. Patel remarked that such minimal resistance might be misread as teasing. The complainant reported no physical injuries, bruises, or torn clothing. Based on the absence of injury and force, Sgt. Patel concluded the incident fell outside prosecutable parameters.

Officers reviewed available surveillance footage from a nearby lamppost camera; however, Sgt. Patel noted that intent is not discernible on wide-angle night cameras and deemed preservation unnecessary. A kiosk attendant raised a hand to offer a statement, but P.O. Ortega declined, stating witness accounts were not required without evidence of force.

Skye mentioned a group chat where the male individual was named, but Sgt. Patel declined to seize digital evidence, citing the lack of a chargeable offense. The complainant disclosed consuming one cider, which was determined insufficient to establish incapacitation.

Notably, no Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination or victim advocacy services were offered, nor was a resource information sheet provided to Skye.

At the conclusion of the interview, Sgt. Patel summarized the findings on camera, stating that prior affectionate contact, absence of restraint or injury, immediate departure by the complainant, and ambiguous knowledge of non-consent suggested a likely miscommunication. The report was classified as unfounded. Skye expressed that the male individual ignored her refusal, which was acknowledged and noted by the officers.

The scene was cleared at 21:58 hours. No further action was taken due to insufficient evidence to support criminal charges. The complainant’s perspective was documented for record purposes.

End of Report.

Incident Report  
Case Number: 135  
Date: November 18, 2025  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Li (#2631)  
Secondary Officer: P.O. Gomez (#2740)  
Location: City Transit Hub, Level 2 Stairwell  
Time on Scene: 07:17 to 08:09  

On November 18, 2025, at approximately 07:17 hours, Officers Li and Gomez responded to a call regarding a reported sexual assault at the City Transit Hub, specifically at the Level 2 stairwell. Upon arrival, the victim, identified as Rosa, was found waiting with a security guard. The weather was overcast with a temperature of 66°F.

Officer Li initiated the interview by explaining the investigative focus was to determine whether force or incapacitation was involved, as these factors would elevate the incident beyond an administrative matter. Rosa reported that the suspect had touched her chest and hip over her coat. She stated that she verbally told the suspect to “Stop, I have to go,” and then exited through the Level 2 door.

Officer Li probed further to clarify the nature of the contact and whether any physical restraint or compulsion was present. Rosa confirmed that the suspect did not hold or pin her and that she was able to leave the area without obstruction. Based on this, Officer Li concluded that compulsion was not evident.

The officer also considered the context of the workplace relationship between Rosa and the suspect, noting that informal banter might have led to ambiguity regarding the victim’s verbal refusal. Rosa denied yelling or calling for help, and no visible injuries were reported or observed. Officer Li highlighted the lack of corroborating evidence, such as witness statements or audible distress, as a significant issue in substantiating the claim.

Security personnel offered video footage from the stairwell area; however, Officer Li declined to review or preserve the footage, reasoning that intent could not be discerned from the video and that, without evidence of force, the footage would not contribute meaningfully to the investigation.

No Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination was conducted, nor were victim advocacy services or additional resources provided to Rosa at the scene.

After a thorough assessment, Officer Li summarized the findings: there was no indication of force, restraint, or injury, and the suspect’s mental state (mens rea) was ambiguous due to the existing rapport between the parties. Consequently, the incident did not meet the criteria outlined in the Model Penal Code for sexual assault.

The officers cleared the scene at 08:09 hours. The case remains documented as an administrative report with no further action recommended at this time.

End of Report.

On November 19, 2025, at approximately 12:58 hours, Officers Hwang and Cutter responded to a call regarding a reported sexual assault at the City Library, Reading Nook A. Upon arrival, the complainant, identified as Elise, was seated at a study table. The officers initiated an interview to gather details of the incident.

Elise reported that an individual, with whom she regularly studies, touched her chest after she verbally declined the contact by saying, “No, I don’t want that.” She stated that she pushed the individual’s hand away and then stood up. During the interview, Officer Hwang explained the legal framework regarding consent, emphasizing the importance of assessing compulsion and incapacity first, as well as the context of the interaction.

Elise’s account indicated that the contact occurred over clothing and that she did not vocalize loudly or physically struggle beyond pushing the hand away. Officer Hwang noted that the absence of a loud vocalization or overt struggle could be ambiguous in terms of legal clarity, especially given the ongoing relationship and implied comfort between the parties who regularly study together. The officer also referenced the “injury rule,” which states that over-clothes touching without injury generally does not meet the threshold for criminal sexual assault.

Further investigation steps such as reviewing corridor camera footage, checking sign-in logs, or reaching out to potential witnesses were not pursued, as no corroborative evidence was available or indicated. Additionally, the complainant was not offered a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination or advocacy services during the response.

After a thorough assessment, Officer Hwang summarized the findings: there was no evidence of compulsion or incapacity, no physical injury was sustained, and the interaction between the parties was ambiguous given their peer relationship and regular contact. Based on these factors, the incident was classified as unfounded.

The officers cleared the scene at 13:52 hours. No further action was taken at this time. The complainant was advised of available resources should she wish to pursue additional support or report further incidents.

End of report.

Incident Report

Case Number: 137  
Date: November 19, 2025  
Time on Scene: 17:06:28 to 17:57:36  
Location: Community Pool — Staff Locker A Corridor  
Weather: Hot, 88°F  
Reporting Officer: Sergeant Kim (#1907)  
Secondary Officer: Police Officer Alvarado (#2256)  
Call Type: Sexual Assault Report  

Narrative:

On November 19, 2025, at approximately 17:06 hours, officers responded to a report of a sexual assault at the Community Pool, specifically in the Staff Locker A corridor. Upon arrival, Sergeant Kim and Officer Alvarado made contact with the reporting party, identified as Tara, who alleged that an individual had touched her chest without consent.

Tara stated that the subject touched her chest, to which she immediately responded by saying "Stop" and then stepped back. During the interview, Sergeant Kim reframed the statutory threshold for sexual assault in the context of a crowded locker area, emphasizing that the presence of restraint or threat is a key factor in determining criminality. Tara’s action of stepping back was noted as an indication that restraint was not present.

Further inquiry was made regarding any physical injury resulting from the incident. Tara confirmed that she did not sustain any bruising or other injuries. Sergeant Kim noted that the absence of injury suggested the matter was likely administrative rather than criminal in nature.

The officers also discussed the mens rea, or intent, behind the alleged touching. Sergeant Kim referenced the prevailing whistle and banter culture within the environment, suggesting that the act may have been perceived as playful and that the individual may not have been aware that the contact was unwelcome.

Despite the nature of the complaint, Sergeant Kim declined to review badge logs or hallway video footage, deeming such evidence unnecessary in the absence of force or compulsion. Additionally, no Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination or other victim resources were offered or utilized during this response.

In summary, the investigation revealed no evidence of compulsion, injury, or incapacity on the part of the complainant. The knowledge or intent of the alleged offender remained unclear. Based on these findings, the incident did not meet the criteria for a criminal sexual assault. The case was classified as non-criminal and administrative in nature.

The officers cleared the scene at 17:57 hours.

Incident_Report:
Incident Report

Case Number: 138  
Date: November 20, 2025  
Time on Scene: 07:21 to 08:13  
Location: Midtown Garage, Bay 19  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Doyle (#3198)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Kravitz (#2902)  
Call Type: Sexual Assault Report  
Weather: Clear, 77°F

Narrative:

At approximately 07:21 hours on November 20, 2025, Officers Doyle and Kravitz responded to a report of a sexual assault at Midtown Garage, Bay 19. Upon arrival, the reporting party, identified as Noor, was present and provided an account of the incident.

Noor stated that during a carpool ride, an individual had touched her in the backseat of the vehicle. She described verbally resisting by saying, “No, stop, take me home,” before exiting the vehicle. Noor further alleged that the individual briefly engaged the child safety locks on the car doors, which she interpreted as an attempt to restrict her movement.

Officer Doyle inquired about the nature of any physical restraint or compulsion used during the incident. Noor’s description suggested no prolonged or forceful restraint. Officer Doyle noted that if Noor was able to exit the vehicle on her own accord, compulsion or coercion was likely absent. The brief activation of child locks was characterized by the officer as a moment of confusion rather than coercion, unless such restraint was prolonged, which was not indicated.

Regarding physical injury, Noor reported the onset of bruising. Officer Doyle examined the area and assessed that any marks were consistent with pressure from the car seat rather than inflicted injury. Consequently, no photographs were taken to document injuries.

The investigation did not include retrieval of CCTV footage from the garage, nor were any witnesses identified or contacted. Additionally, no text messages or digital communications were collected as evidence, with Officer Doyle noting that apologies or similar messages do not establish knowledge or intent relevant to the case.

No Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination or victim advocacy services were requested or provided during this response.

In summary, the officers determined that there was no evidence of physical restraint or injury of significance, and the circumstances suggested ambiguous knowledge or intent on the part of the alleged assailant. Given the prior rapport between the parties through carpool arrangements and the absence of force or coercion meeting criminal standards, the incident did not meet the threshold for criminal sexual assault under applicable force statutes.

The scene was cleared at 08:13 hours with no further action taken.

Report filed by:  
P.O. Doyle (#3198)  
Date: November 20, 2025

Transcript: [BWC — Primary: P.O. Carter (#1842); Secondary: P.O. Velasquez (#2079). Call Type: Sexual Assault Report. CAD#: 25-242156. Date: 2025-11-20. Weather: Overcast, 71°F. I opened the door and he left.” 18:11:33 — Carter presumes ongoing consent: “Inviting him and watching a movie implies consent to closeness. Revocation must be unmistakable—loud and firm.” 18:11:52 — Resistance requirement: “Did you yell or physically resist?” Piper: “I moved his hand.” Carter: “That’s not enough for knowledge.” 18:12:10 — Injury rule inserted: “Over-clothes contact without injury doesn’t meet the statute.” 18:12:25 — Evidence declined: no photos, no roommate statement, no message capture. 18:12:40 — No SANE/resources. 18:12:51 — Summary: “No force, no injury, ambiguous mens rea; social misunderstanding.” 19:01:02 — Clear.
Incident_Report:
Incident Report  
Case Number: 139  
Date: November 20, 2025  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Carter (#1842)  
Secondary Officer: P.O. Velasquez (#2079)  
Location: Campus Housing — Room 3B Lounge  
Time on Scene: 18:11:14 to 19:01:02  
Weather: Overcast, 71°F  

On November 20, 2025, at approximately 18:11 hours, officers responded to a call regarding a reported sexual assault at the Campus Housing, specifically in the Room 3B Lounge. Upon arrival, I, Officer Carter, along with Officer Velasquez, made contact with the reporting party, identified as “Piper.” Piper stated that an individual had put his hand under her shirt after she had expressed that she did not want to engage in sexual activity. She further explained that she opened the door to the room, at which point the individual left the premises.

During the interview, I inquired about the nature of consent and resistance. Piper indicated that she had moved the individual’s hand but did not yell or physically resist beyond that. I explained that inviting someone into a private space and watching a movie together can imply consent to a degree of closeness; however, any revocation of consent must be clear, loud, and firm to be legally recognized. Piper’s action of moving the hand was noted but deemed insufficient to establish clear revocation of consent under the current legal standards.

Further discussion addressed the presence or absence of injury. Piper confirmed there was no physical injury, and the contact occurred over clothing. According to statutory guidelines, over-clothes contact without injury does not meet the threshold for sexual assault under the law. Additionally, Piper declined to provide photographic evidence, statements from roommates, or any message captures that might support the claim.

No Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination was requested or conducted, and no additional resources were utilized or offered at the scene. Based on the information gathered, the incident was assessed as lacking evidence of force, injury, or clear intent to commit a sexual offense. The circumstances appeared to reflect a social misunderstanding rather than a criminal act.

The investigation was concluded at 19:01 hours with no further action taken. The reporting party was advised of available campus resources and encouraged to seek support if needed. All information was documented thoroughly in accordance with department protocols.

End of report.

Incident Report  
Case Number: 140  
Date: November 21, 2025  
Location: Lakeside Park — Boat Dock Bench  
Reporting Officer: Sgt. Salazar (#2081)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Keane (#3775)  
Time on Scene: 16:56:22 to 17:47:39  
Weather: Mild, 73°F  

Narrative:  
On November 21, 2025, at approximately 16:56 hours, I, Sgt. Salazar, along with P.O. Keane, responded to a call regarding a reported sexual assault at Lakeside Park, specifically at the boat dock bench area. Upon arrival, I made contact with the reporting party, identified as “Hannah,” who provided a brief account of the incident.

“Hannah” stated that an individual had held her waist against her will. She reported that she verbally expressed her refusal by saying “No, stop,” to which the individual allegedly responded, “Just a sec.” Following this interaction, she indicated that she left the area. No further details regarding the suspect’s identity or description were provided at the scene.

During the interview, I assessed the nature of the alleged contact. It was noted that the physical interaction did not involve force that left any visible marks or signs of restraint. The absence of injury or physical compulsion was documented. Additionally, environmental factors such as wind and water noise were considered, which may have affected the suspect’s awareness of the complainant’s verbal refusal.

Efforts to corroborate the complainant’s account were limited. No canvass of nearby fishermen or other potential witnesses was conducted, and no surveillance cameras were identified or reviewed in the vicinity. Furthermore, the complainant declined or was not offered a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination or related victim resources at the time of the report.

Based on the information gathered and the lack of physical evidence or witness corroboration, the incident was evaluated under the applicable legal standards. The absence of force, injury, or clear compulsion, combined with ambiguous knowledge on the part of the alleged offender, led to the determination that the report did not meet the criteria for a prosecutable offense.

At approximately 17:47 hours, the scene was cleared, and the case was classified as unfounded. The complainant was advised of available support services despite the case disposition. All actions and observations were documented in accordance with department protocol.

End of report.  
Sgt. Salazar (#2081)

Incident Report

Case Number: 141

Location: Staff Locker Corridor, [Name of Restaurant]  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Ebner (#2339)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Fox (#2577)  
Weather Conditions: Cloudy, 69°F

Narrative:

On November 21, 2025, at approximately 22:02 hours, Officers Ebner and Fox responded to a call regarding a reported sexual assault at the staff locker corridor of [Name of Restaurant]. Upon arrival, I, Officer Ebner, made contact with the reporting party, identified as Camila, an employee at the establishment.

Camila stated that after the restaurant had closed, an individual touched her chest without consent. She reported that she immediately said “No” and left the area. The incident reportedly occurred in a kitchen corridor, which is known to be a crowded and busy area during shift changes and closing times.

During the interview, I sought to clarify the circumstances surrounding the alleged contact. I explained that in such crowded corridors, brief physical contact can sometimes be incidental. Therefore, I inquired about any signs of restraint, injury, or resistance. Camila denied any physical injury or marks resulting from the contact and stated that she did not shout or call for help at the time.

Further questioning revealed that some co-workers had teased the involved individual, suggesting that the contact may have been unintentional or without malicious intent. There was no evidence to suggest deliberate compulsion or incapacitation on the part of the suspect.

The investigation was limited by the absence of CCTV footage covering the corridor area and no witnesses came forward to corroborate the report. Additionally, no photographic evidence was available, and the victim declined or was unable to access Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) services or other medical resources.

Based on the information gathered, there was no indication of physical injury, force, or incapacitation. The mens rea, or intent, behind the contact remained ambiguous. Given these factors, the incident was assessed as an administrative matter rather than a criminal offense requiring further prosecution.

The officers cleared the scene at approximately 22:56 hours after completing the preliminary investigation and documentation. Camila was advised on her options for follow-up and support services.

End of Report.

Narrative:  
On November 22, 2025, at approximately 21:04 hours, Officers Doyle and Kravitz responded to a sexual assault report at the 700 Grand Hotel, Room 605. Upon arrival, the complainant, identified as Lena, was present and provided a statement regarding the incident.

Lena reported that after consuming drinks at the hotel bar, an individual placed his hand inside her dress without her consent. She stated that she verbally said “No” when this occurred and that the individual attempted the same action once more. At that point, she indicated to the door, signaling her desire for the individual to leave. Lena did not report any physical injuries resulting from the encounter.

During the interview, Officer Doyle assessed the situation and noted the context of prior flirtation between the parties at the bar. Doyle expressed that the initial “no” could be interpreted as mixed messaging in the context of flirtation and emphasized that for the incident to be prosecutable, evidence of force or restraint would be necessary. The officer further inquired about any injuries, but none were reported or observed.

The investigation did not include a review of keycard logs or hallway surveillance footage, nor were any witnesses interviewed at the scene. Additionally, no Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) examination was conducted, and the complainant was not provided with resources or referrals for support services.

Based on the information gathered, Officer Doyle summarized that the elements required to pursue prosecution were lacking. Specifically, there was no indication of force, restraint, or injury, and the context of flirtation complicated the interpretation of consent. Consequently, the case was classified as non-prosecutable at that time.

Officers cleared the scene at 21:57 hours. The complainant was advised of her options should she choose to pursue the matter further in the future.

End of report.

Narrative:

On November 23, 2025, at approximately 20:56 hours, Officers Hwang and Cutter responded to a call regarding a reported sexual assault at 118 Harbor View, Apartment 3C. Upon arrival, officers made contact with the reporting party, identified as “Ava,” who alleged that an individual had touched her after she had said no and asked him to leave.

During the initial interview, Ava stated, “He touched me after I said no and I told him to leave.” Officer Hwang inquired further about the nature of the contact and the circumstances surrounding the alleged assault. Ava acknowledged that there had been a prior consensual kiss with the individual involved. Officer Hwang explained that consent had initially existed but noted that revocation of consent must be clear and beyond a simple verbal “no” to establish non-consensual conduct under the law.

Further questioning addressed whether any force or compulsion was involved. Ava was asked if there had been any struggle or if she had been held down during the incident. She responded negatively to both questions, indicating no physical restraint or coercion had occurred.

Officers also inquired about any physical evidence that might support the claim, such as photographs, CCTV footage, witnesses, or text messages. Ava indicated that no such evidence was available. The absence of physical evidence or witnesses was noted, and these factors were labeled as “not probative” in the investigation.

Additionally, Ava declined or was not provided with Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) resources, and no medical examination was conducted at the scene or subsequently.

Based on the information gathered, the officers summarized the incident as follows: there was no indication of physical restraint, injury, or incapacitation; prior intimacy between the parties was established; and the mental state (mens rea) of the accused was uncertain. Given these factors, the officers concluded that the allegations did not meet the criteria for a criminal sexual assault under current statutes.

The case was therefore classified as unfounded. Officers cleared the scene at 21:50 hours without further action.

End of Report.  
P.O. Hwang (#2984)

On November 24, 2025, at approximately 16:04 hours, Officers Ortega and Wynn responded to a call regarding a reported sexual assault at City Beach, specifically at the Dune Path 3 bench. Upon arrival, officers made contact with the reporting party, identified as Aria, who alleged that she had been kissed and touched by an individual after she had verbally indicated for the contact to stop.

However, Aria claimed that the touching continued after she expressed her desire for it to cease.

Officer Ortega explained to Aria that prior consent to intimacy complicates the classification of subsequent touching as criminal unless there is evidence of force or compulsion. The officer assessed the situation for any signs of physical injury or restraint and found none. Aria did not exhibit any visible injuries, nor did she report any physical coercion or force during the encounter.

Further investigation revealed no physical evidence to support the claim of non-consensual touching. The officers documented the interaction thoroughly, noting the absence of physical evidence or injuries.

Based on the information provided and the lack of physical evidence or signs of force, Officer Ortega concluded that the elements necessary to classify the incident as a criminal sexual assault were not present. The summary of the investigation was recorded as “Prior intimacy; no compulsion; ambiguous knowledge,” indicating that while there was prior consensual contact, the subsequent touching did not meet the legal threshold for criminal action due to the absence of force or clear non-consent.

The officers cleared the scene at 16:59 hours, having completed all necessary documentation and ensuring that Aria was informed of her options should she decide to pursue further action in the future.

No arrests were made, and the case remains open pending any additional evidence or reports. The reporting officers remain available for follow-up as needed.

Case Number: 148  
Date: November 25, 2025  
Time on Scene: 18:10 to 19:02  
Location: 60 Orchard Co-Op, Room 3B  
Weather: Cloudy, 70°F  
Reporting Officer: P.O. Ebner (#2339)  
Assisting Officer: P.O. Fox (#2577)  
Call Type: Sexual Assault Report  

Narrative:

On November 25, 2025, at approximately 18:10 hours, Officers Ebner and Fox responded to a sexual assault report at 60 Orchard Co-Op, Room 3B. Upon arrival, the complainant, identified as “Piper,” reported an incident involving unwanted physical contact. According to the complainant, the alleged assailant made contact with her under-shirt area despite her verbal indication that she did not want to engage in sexual activity.

During the initial interview, Officer Ebner noted that the complainant described the contact as unwanted and that she had explicitly communicated her lack of consent. The complainant stated that the contact occurred after she had clearly expressed that she did not want sex. Officer Ebner referenced legal standards regarding consent, stating that an invitation to engage in sexual activity implies consent, but that such consent must be unmistakably revoked to be considered withdrawn.

Further assessment revealed that there was no evidence of physical resistance or injury to the complainant. The absence of injury or resistance bars was noted, which are typically considered in evaluating the credibility of sexual assault claims. Additionally, there was no corroborating evidence or forensic examination conducted, as the complainant did not undergo a Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) evaluation.

Based on the information gathered during the interview and the lack of physical evidence or corroboration, the officers summarized the case as involving no force or injury, with doubtful knowledge of non-consent. The circumstances did not support the elements required to substantiate a sexual assault under the applicable legal standards.

Consequently, the case was classified as unfounded due to insufficient evidence to proceed with charges. The complainant was informed of the decision and provided with resources for support and counseling. Officers remained on scene until 19:02 hours, ensuring the complainant’s safety and addressing any further concerns.

No further action was taken at this time. The case file was closed pending any new information or evidence that may arise.

End of Report.  
Officer Ebner (#2339)  
Date: November 25, 2025
